children.comment: The TIFF format is perhaps the most versatile and diverse bitmap format in existence. Its extensible nature and support for numerous data compression schemes allow developers to customize the TIFF format to fit any peculiar data storage needs.
children.label: TIFF

children.hasDefinition: Standard bitmap storage format in the Microsoft Windows environment.
children.comment: Although it is based on Windows internal bitmap data structures, it is supported by many non-Windows and non-PC applications.
children.label: BMP

children.hasDefinition: IM is a format used by LabEye and other applications based on the IFUNC image processing library.
children.comment: IFUNC library reads and writes most uncompressed interchange versions of this format.
children.label: im

children.hasDefinition: Photo CD format, which is the highest resolution format for images on a CD.
children.comment: PCD was developed by Kodak. A PCD file contains five different resolution (ranging from low to high) of a slide or film negative. Due to it PCD is often used by many photographers and graphics professionals for high-end printed applications.
children.label: pcd

children.hasDefinition: PCX is an image file format that uses a simple form of run-length encoding. It is lossless.
children.label: pcx

children.hasDefinition: The PPM format is a lowest common denominator color image file format.
children.label: ppm

children.hasDefinition: PSD (Photoshop Document) is a proprietary file that allows the user to work with the images' individual layers even after the file has been saved.
children.label: psd

children.hasDefinition: X BitMap is a plain text binary image format used by the X Window System used for storing cursor and icon bitmaps used in the X GUI.
children.comment: The XBM format was replaced by XPM for X11 in 1989.
children.label: xbm

children.hasDefinition: X PixMap (XPM) is an image file format used by the X Window System, it is intended primarily for creating icon pixmaps, and supports transparent pixels.
children.comment: Sequence of segments with markers. Begins with byte of 0xFF and follows by marker type.
children.label: xpm

children.hasDefinition: RGB file format is the native raster graphics file format for Silicon Graphics workstations.
children.label: rgb

children.hasDefinition: The PBM format is a lowest common denominator monochrome file format. It serves as the common language of a large family of bitmap image conversion filters.
children.label: pbm

children.hasDefinition: The PGM format is a lowest common denominator grayscale file format.
children.comment: It is designed to be extremely easy to learn and write programs for.
children.label: pgm

children.hasDefinition: PNG is a file format for image compression.
children.comment: It iis expected to replace the Graphics Interchange Format (GIF).
children.label: PNG

children.hasDefinition: Scalable Vector Graphics (SVG) is an XML-based vector image format for two-dimensional graphics with support for interactivity and animation.
children.comment: The SVG specification is an open standard developed by the World Wide Web Consortium (W3C) since 1999.
children.label: SVG

children.hasDefinition: Sun Raster is a raster graphics file format used on SunOS by Sun Microsystems
children.comment: The SVG specification is an open standard developed by the World Wide Web Consortium (W3C) since 1999.
children.label: rast

children.hasDefinition: Blocked GNU Zip format.
children.comment: BAM files are compressed using a variant of GZIP (GNU ZIP), into a format called BGZF (Blocked GNU Zip Format).
children.label: bgzip

children.hasDefinition: TAB-delimited genome position file index format.
children.label: tabix

children.hasDefinition: Image file format used by the Open Microscopy Environment (OME).
comment: An OME-TIFF dataset consists of one or more files in standard TIFF or BigTIFF format, with the file extension .ome.tif or .ome.tiff, and an identical (or in the case of multiple files, nearly identical) string of OME-XML metadata embedded in the ImageDescription tag of each file's first IFD (Image File Directory). BigTIFF file extensions are also permitted, with the file extension .ome.tf2, .ome.tf8 or .ome.btf, but note these file extensions are an addition to the original specification, and software using an older version of the specification may not be able to handle these file extensions.

OME develops open-source software and data format standards for the storage and manipulation of biological microscopy data. It is a joint project between universities, research establishments, industry and the software development community.
children.label: OME-TIFF

children.hasDefinition: Microsoft Powerpoint format.
children.label: pptx

children.hasDefinition: Vega is a visualization grammar, a declarative language for creating, saving, and sharing interactive visualization designs. With Vega, you can describe the visual appearance and interactive behavior of a visualization in a JSON format, and generate web-based views using Canvas or SVG.
children.label: Vega

children.hasDefinition: Vega-Lite is a high-level grammar of interactive graphics. It provides a concise JSON syntax for rapidly generating visualizations to support analysis. Vega-Lite specifications can be compiled to Vega specifications.
children.label: Vega-lite

children.hasDefinition: The proprietary native video format of various Microsoft programs such as Windows Media Player.
children.label: WMV

children.hasDefinition: Zeiss' proprietary image format based on TIFF.
children.comment: LSM files are the default data export for the Zeiss LSM series confocal microscopes (e.g. LSM 510, LSM 710). In addition to the image data, LSM files contain most imaging settings.
children.label: LSM

children.hasDefinition: Audio Video Interleaved (AVI) format is a multimedia container format for AVI files, that allows synchronous audio-with-video playback.
children.label: AVI

children.hasDefinition: STL is a file format native to the stereolithography CAD software created by 3D Systems.  The format is used to save and share surface-rendered 3D images and also for 3D printing.
children.label: Stereolithography format

children.hasDefinition: U3D (Universal 3D) is a compressed file format and data structure for 3D computer graphics. It contains 3D model information such as triangle meshes, lighting, shading, motion data, lines and points with color and structure.
children.label: U3D

children.hasDefinition: Bitmap image format used for storing textures.
children.comment: Texture files can create the appearance of different surfaces and can be applied to both 2D and 3D objects. Note the file extension .tex is also used for LaTex documents which are a completely different format and they are NOT interchangable.
children.label: Texture file format

children.hasDefinition: A digital multimedia container format most commonly used to store video and audio.
children.label: MPEG-4

children.hasDefinition: An open file format from the Neuroimaging Informatics Technology Initiative (NIfTI) commonly used to store brain imaging data obtained using Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) methods.
children.label: NIFTI format

children.hasDefinition: Format used for images and image metadata.
children.label: Image format

children.hasDefinition: FASTQ format subset for Phred sequencing quality score data only (no sequences) for Solexa/Illumina 1.0 format.
children.comment: Solexa/Illumina 1.0 format can encode a Solexa/Illumina quality score from -5 to 62 using ASCII 59 to 126 (although in raw read data Solexa scores from -5 to 40 only are expected)
children.label: qualsolexa

children.hasDefinition: FASTQ format subset for Phred sequencing quality score data only (no sequences) from Illumina 1.5 and before Illumina 1.8.
children.comment: Starting in Illumina 1.5 and before Illumina 1.8, the Phred scores 0 to 2 have a slightly different meaning. The values 0 and 1 are no longer used and the value 2, encoded by ASCII 66 "B", is used also at the end of reads as a Read Segment Quality Control Indicator.
children.label: qualillumina

children.hasDefinition: FASTQ format subset for Phred sequencing quality score data only (no sequences) for SOLiD data.
children.comment: For SOLiD data, the sequence is in color space, except the first position. The quality values are those of the Sanger format.
children.label: qualsolid

children.hasDefinition: FASTQ format subset for Phred sequencing quality score data only (no sequences) from 454 sequencers.
children.label: qual454

children.hasDefinition: FASTQ format subset for Phred sequencing quality score data only (no sequences).
children.comment: Phred quality scores  are defined as a property which is logarithmically related to the base-calling error probabilities.
children.label: qual

children.hasDefinition: Textual report format for sequence quality for reports from sequencing machines.
children.label: Sequence quality report format (text)

children.hasDefinition: XML-based format used to store graph descriptions within Galaxy.
children.label: xgmml

children.hasDefinition: A list of k-mers and their occurences in a dataset. Can also be used as an implicit De Bruijn graph.
children.label: K-mer countgraph

children.hasDefinition: Data format for graph data.
children.label: Graph format

children.hasDefinition: Exchange format of the Access to Biological Collections Data (ABCD) Schema; a standard for the access to and exchange of data about specimens and observations (primary biodiversity data).
children.label: ABCD format

children.hasDefinition: The BIological Observation Matrix (BIOM) is a format for representing biological sample by observation contingency tables in broad areas of comparative omics. The primary use of this format is to represent OTU tables and metagenome tables.
children.comment: BIOM is a recognised standard for the Earth Microbiome Project, and is a project supported by Genomics Standards Consortium. Supported in QIIME, Mothur, MEGAN, etc.
children.label: BIOM format

children.comment: Multi-Crop Passport Descriptors is a format available in 2 successive versions, V.1 (FAO/IPGRI 2001) and V.2 (FAO/Bioversity 2012).
children.hasDefinition: The FAO/Bioversity/IPGRI Multi-Crop Passport Descriptors (MCPD) is an international standard format for exchange of germplasm information.
children.label: MCPD

children.hasDefinition: Data format for biodiversity data.
children.label: Biodiversity data format

children.hasDefinition: A query language (format) for structured database queries.
children.label: Query language

children.hasDefinition: nmrML is an MSI supported XML-based open access format for metabolomics NMR raw and processed spectral data. It is accompanies by an nmrCV (controlled vocabulary) to allow ontology-based annotations.
children.label: nmrML

children.hasDefinition: MReData is a text based data standard for processed NMR data. It is relying on SDF molecule data and allows to store assignments of NMR peaks to molecule features.  The NMR-extracted data (or "NMReDATA") includes: Chemical shift,scalar coupling, 2D correlation, assignment, etc.
children.comment: NMReData is a text based data standard for processed NMR data. It is relying on SDF molecule data and allows to store assignments of NMR peaks to molecule features. The NMR-extracted data (or "NMReDATA") includes: Chemical shift,scalar coupling, 2D correlation, assignment, etc. Find more in the paper at D. Jeannerat, Magn. Reson. in Chem., 2017, 55, 7-14.
children.label: NMReDATA

children.hasDefinition: Data format for raw data from a nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectroscopy experiment.
children.hasExactSynonym: Nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy data format
children.label: NMR data format

children.hasDefinition: GenePix Results (GPR) text file format developed by Axon Instruments that is used to save GenePix Results data.
children.label: GPR

children.hasDefinition: Data format for raw microarray data.
children.label: Raw microarray data format

children.hasDefinition: NLP format used by a specific type of corpus (collection of texts).
children.label: NLP corpus format

children.hasDefinition: An NLP format used for annotated textual documents.
children.label: NLP annotation format

children.hasDefinition: Data format used in Natural Language Processing.
children.label: NLP format

children.hasDefinition: mirGFF3 is a common format for microRNA data resulting from small-RNA RNA-Seq workflows.
children.comment: mirGFF3 is a specialisation of GFF3; produced by small-RNA-Seq analysis workflows, usable and convertible with the miRTop API (https://mirtop.readthedocs.io/en/latest/), and consumable by tools for downstream analysis.
children.label: mirGFF3

children.hasDefinition: A "placeholder" concept for formats of annotated RNA data, including e.g. microRNA and RNA-Seq data.
children.label: RNA annotation format

children.hasDefinition: The Loom file format is based on HDF5, a standard for storing large numerical datasets. The Loom format is designed to efficiently hold large omics datasets. Typically, such data takes the form of a large matrix of numbers, along with metadata for the rows and columns.
children.label: Loom

children.hasDefinition: HDF5 is a data model, library, and file format for storing and managing data, based on Hierarchical Data Format (HDF).
comment: An HDF5 file appears to the user as a directed graph. The nodes of this graph are the higher-level HDF5 objects that are exposed by the HDF5 APIs: Groups, Datasets, Named datatypes. Currently supported by the Python MDTraj package.
HDF5 is the new version, according to the HDF group, a completely different technology (https://support.hdfgroup.org/products/hdf4/ compared to HDF.
children.label: HDF5

children.comment: Network Common Data Form (NetCDF) library is supported by AMBER MD package from version 9.
children.hasDefinition: Format used by netCDF software  library for writing and reading chromatography-MS data files.  Also used to store trajectory atom coordinates information, such as the ones obtained by Molecular Dynamics simulations.
children.label: netCDF

children.hasDefinition: HDF is the name of a set of file formats and libraries designed to store and organize large amounts of numerical data, originally developed at the National Center for Supercomputing Applications at the University of Illinois.
children.comment: HDF is currently supported by many commercial and non-commercial software platforms such as Java, MATLAB/Scilab, Octave, Python and R.
children.label: HDF

children.hasDefinition: PCAZip format is a binary compressed file to store atom coordinates based on Essential Dynamics (ED) and Principal Component Analysis (PCA).
children.comment: The compression is made projecting the Cartesian snapshots collected along the trajectory into an orthogonal space defined by the most relevant eigenvectors obtained by diagonalization of the covariance matrix (PCA). In the compression/decompression process, part of the original information is lost, depending on the final number of eigenvectors chosen. However, with a reasonable choice of the set of eigenvectors the compression typically reduces the trajectory file to less than one tenth of their original size with very acceptable loss of information. Compression with PCAZip can only be applied to unsolvated structures.
children.label: PCAzip

children.hasDefinition: Portable binary format for trajectories produced by GROMACS package.
children.comment: XTC uses the External Data Representation (xdr) routines for writing and reading data which were created for the Unix Network File System (NFS). XTC files use a reduced precision (lossy) algorithm which works multiplying the coordinates by a scaling factor (typically 1000), so converting them to pm (GROMACS standard distance unit is nm). This allows an integer rounding of the values. Several other tricks are performed, such as making use of atom proximity information: atoms close in sequence are usually close in space (e.g. water molecules). That makes XTC format the most efficient in terms of disk usage, in most cases reducing by a factor of 2 the size of any other binary trajectory format.
children.label: XTC

children.hasDefinition: Trajectory Next Generation (TNG) is a format for storage of molecular simulation data. It is designed and implemented by the GROMACS development group, and it is called to be the substitute of the XTC format.
children.comment: Fully architecture-independent format, regarding both endianness and the ability to mix single/double precision trajectories and I/O libraries. Self-sufficient, it should not require any other files for reading, and all the data should be contained in a single file for easy transport. Temporal compression of data, improving the compression rate of the previous XTC format. Possibility to store meta-data with information about the simulation. Direct access to a particular frame. Efficient parallel I/O.
children.label: TNG

children.hasDefinition: Scripps Research Institute BinPos format is a binary formatted file to store atom coordinates.
children.comment: It is basically a translation of the ASCII atom coordinate format to binary code. The only additional information stored is a magic number that identifies the BinPos format and the number of atoms per snapshot. The remainder is the chain of coordinates binary encoded. A drawback of this format is its architecture dependency. Integers and floats codification depends on the architecture, thus it needs to be converted if working in different platforms (little endian, big endian).
children.label: BinPos

children.hasDefinition: Binary file format to store trajectory information for a 3D structure .
children.label: Trajectory format (binary)

children.hasDefinition: The XYZ chemical file format is widely supported by many programs, although many slightly different XYZ file formats coexist (Tinker XYZ, UniChem XYZ, etc.). Basic information stored for each atom in the system are x, y and z coordinates and atom element/atomic number.
children.comment: XYZ files are structured in this way:  First line contains the number of atoms in the file.  Second line contains a title, comment, or filename. Remaining lines contain atom information. Each line starts with the element symbol, followed by x, y and z coordinates in angstroms separated by whitespace. Multiple molecules or frames can be contained within one file, so it supports trajectory storage. XYZ files can be directly represented by a molecular viewer, as they contain all the basic information needed to build the 3D model.
children.label: XYZ

children.hasDefinition: AMBER trajectory (also called mdcrd), with 10 coordinates per line and format F8.3 (fixed point notation with field width 8 and 3 decimal places).
children.label: mdcrd

children.hasDefinition: AMBER coordinate/restart file with 6 coordinates per line and decimal format F12.7 (fixed point notation with field width 12 and 7 decimal places)
children.label: RST

children.comment: The first 4 bytes of any trr file containing 1993. See https://github.com/galaxyproject/galaxy/pull/6597/files#diff-409951594551183dbf886e24de6cb129R760
children.hasDefinition: Format of trr files that contain the trajectory of a simulation experiment used by GROMACS.
children.label: trr

children.hasDefinition: Textual file format to store trajectory information for a 3D structure .
children.label: Trajectory format (text)

children.hasDefinition: File format to store trajectory information for a 3D structure .
children.comment: Formats differ on what they are able to store (coordinates, velocities, topologies) and how they are storing it (raw, compressed, textual, binary).
children.label: Trajectory format

children.hasDefinition: GROMACS MD package top textual files define an entire structure system topology, either directly, or by including itp files.
children.comment: There is currently no tool available for conversion between GROMACS topology format and other formats, due to the internal differences in both approaches. There is, however, a method to convert small molecules parameterized with AMBER force-field into GROMACS format, allowing simulations of these systems with GROMACS MD package.
children.label: GROMACS top

children.hasDefinition: AMBER Prmtop file (version 7) is a structure topology text file divided in several sections designed to be parsed easily using simple Fortran code. Each section contains particular topology information, such as atom name, charge, mass, angles, dihedrals, etc.
comment: It can be modified manually, but as the size of the system increases, the hand-editing becomes increasingly complex. AMBER Parameter-Topology file format is used extensively by the AMBER software suite and is referred to as the Prmtop file for short.

version 7 is written to distinguish it from old versions of AMBER Prmtop. Similarly to HDF5, it is a completely different format, according to AMBER group: a drastic change to the file format occurred with the 2004 release of Amber 7 (http://ambermd.org/prmtop.pdf)
children.label: AMBER top

children.hasDefinition: X-Plor Protein Structure Files (PSF) are structure topology files used by NAMD and CHARMM molecular simulations programs. PSF files contain six main sections of interest: atoms, bonds, angles, dihedrals, improper dihedrals (force terms used to maintain planarity) and cross-terms.
children.comment: The high similarity in the functional form of the two potential energy functions used by AMBER and CHARMM force-fields gives rise to the possible use of one force-field within the other MD engine. Therefore, the conversion of PSF files to AMBER Prmtop format is possible with the use of AMBER chamber (CHARMM - AMBER) program.
children.label: PSF

children.hasDefinition: GROMACS itp files (include topology) contain structure topology information, and are tipically included in GROMACS topology files (GROMACS top). Itp files are used to define individual (or multiple) components of a topology as a separate file. This is particularly useful if there is a molecule that is used frequently, and also reduces the size of the system topology file, splitting it in different parts.
children.comment: GROMACS itp files are used also to define position restrictions on the molecule, or to define the force field parameters for a particular ligand.
children.label: GROMACS itp

children.hasDefinition: Format of CHARMM Residue Topology Files (RTF), which define groups by including the atoms, the properties of the group, and bond and charge information.
children.comment: There is currently no tool available for conversion between GROMACS topology format and other formats, due to the internal differences in both approaches. There is, however, a method to convert small molecules parameterized with AMBER force-field into GROMACS format, allowing simulations of these systems with GROMACS MD package.
children.label: CHARMM rtf

children.hasDefinition: Format of topology files; containing the static information of a structure molecular system that is needed for a molecular simulation.
children.comment: Many different file formats exist describing structural molecular topology. Tipically, each MD package or simulation software works with their own implementation (e.g. GROMACS top, CHARMM psf, AMBER prmtop).
children.label: Topology format

children.hasDefinition: GROMACS itp files (include topology) contain structure topology information, and are tipically included in GROMACS topology files (GROMACS top). Itp files are used to define individual (or multiple) components of a topology as a separate file. This is particularly useful if there is a molecule that is used frequently, and also reduces the size of the system topology file, splitting it in different parts.
children.comment: GROMACS itp files are used also to define position restrictions on the molecule, or to define the force field parameters for a particular ligand.
children.label: GROMACS itp

children.hasDefinition: AMBER frcmod (Force field Modification) is a file format to store any modification to the standard force field needed for a particular molecule to be properly represented in the simulation.
children.label: AMBER frcmod

children.hasDefinition: AMBER Object File Format library files (OFF library files) store residue libraries (forcefield residue parameters).
children.label: AMBER off

children.hasDefinition: Format of force field parameter files, which store the set of parameters (charges, masses, radii, bond lengths, bond dihedrals, etc.) that are essential for the proper description and simulation of a molecular system.
children.comment: Many different file formats exist describing force field parameters. Tipically, each MD package or simulation software works with their own implementation (e.g. GROMACS itp, CHARMM rtf, AMBER off / frcmod).
children.label: FF parameter format

children.hasDefinition: A placeholder concept for visual navigation by dividing data formats by the content of the data that is represented.
children.comment: This concept exists only to assist EDAM maintenance and navigation in graphical browsers.  It does not add semantic information. The concept branch under 'Format (typed)' provides an alternative organisation of the concepts nested under the other top-level branches ('Binary', 'HTML', 'RDF', 'Text' and 'XML'. All concepts under here are already included under those branches.
children.label: Format (by type of data)

children.hasDefinition: A human-readable encoding for the Web Ontology Language (OWL).
children.label: OWL Functional Syntax

children.hasDefinition: A syntax for writing OWL class expressions.
children.comment: This format was influenced by the OWL Abstract Syntax and the DL style syntax.
children.label: Manchester OWL Syntax

children.hasDefinition: OWL ontology XML serialisation format.
children.label: OWL/XML

children.hasDefinition: A serialisation format conforming to the Web Ontology Language (OWL) model.
children.label: OWL format

children.hasDefinition: The Terse RDF Triple Language (Turtle) is a human-friendly serialisation format for RDF (Resource Description Framework) graphs.
children.comment: The SPARQL Query Language incorporates a very similar syntax.
children.label: Turtle

children.hasDefinition: A plain text serialisation format for RDF (Resource Description Framework) graphs, and a subset of the Turtle (Terse RDF Triple Language) format.
children.comment: N-Triples should not be confused with Notation 3 which is a superset of Turtle.
children.label: N-Triples

children.hasDefinition: A shorthand non-XML serialisation of Resource Description Framework model, designed with human-readability in mind.
children.label: Notation3

children.hasDefinition: Resource Description Framework (RDF) XML format.
children.comment: RDF/XML is a serialisation syntax for OWL DL, but not for OWL Full.
children.label: RDF/XML

children.hasDefinition: A format of text annotation using the linked-data Open Annotation Data Model, serialised typically in RDF or JSON-LD.
children.label: Open Annotation format

children.hasDefinition: JSON-LD, or JavaScript Object Notation for Linked Data, is a method of encoding Linked Data using JSON.
children.hasExactSynonym: JavaScript Object Notation for Linked Data
children.label: JSON-LD

children.hasDefinition: UniProtKB RDF sequence features format is an RDF format available for downloading UniProt entries (in RDF/XML).
children.label: UniProtKB RDF

children.hasDefinition: A format of text annotation using the linked-data Open Annotation Data Model, serialised typically in RDF or JSON-LD.
children.label: Open Annotation format

children.hasDefinition: N-Quads is a line-based, plain text format for encoding an RDF dataset. It includes information about the graph each triple belongs to.
children.comment: N-Quads should not be confused with N-Triples which does not contain graph information.
children.label: N-Quads

children.hasDefinition: A serialisation format conforming to the Resource Description Framework (RDF) model.
children.label: RDF format

children.hasDefinition: A format of text annotation using the linked-data Open Annotation Data Model, serialised typically in RDF or JSON-LD.
children.label: Open Annotation format

children.hasDefinition: JSON-LD, or JavaScript Object Notation for Linked Data, is a method of encoding Linked Data using JSON.
children.hasExactSynonym: JavaScript Object Notation for Linked Data
children.label: JSON-LD

children.comment: Work in progress. 'BioXSD' belongs to the 'BioXSD|GTrack' ecosystem of generic formats. 'BioJSON' is the JSON format based on the common, unified 'BioXSD data model', a.k.a. 'BioXSD|BioJSON|BioYAML'.
children.hasDefinition: BioJSON is a BioXSD-schema-based JSON format of sequence-based data and some other common data - sequence records, alignments, feature records, references to resources, and more - optimised for integrative bioinformatics, web applications and APIs, and object-oriented programming.
children.label: BioJSON (BioXSD)

children.hasDefinition: BioJSON is a JSON format of single multiple sequence alignments, with their annotations, features, and custom visualisation and application settings for the Jalview workbench.
children.label: BioJSON (Jalview)

children.hasDefinition: JSON format of annotated scientific text used by PubAnnotations and other tools.
children.label: PubAnnotation format

children.hasDefinition: Vega is a visualization grammar, a declarative language for creating, saving, and sharing interactive visualization designs. With Vega, you can describe the visual appearance and interactive behavior of a visualization in a JSON format, and generate web-based views using Canvas or SVG.
children.label: Vega

children.hasDefinition: Vega-Lite is a high-level grammar of interactive graphics. It provides a concise JSON syntax for rapidly generating visualizations to support analysis. Vega-Lite specifications can be compiled to Vega specifications.
children.label: Vega-lite

children.hasDefinition: JavaScript Object Notation format; a lightweight, text-based format to represent tree-structured data using key-value pairs.
children.label: JSON

children.hasDefinition: A format of text annotation using the linked-data Open Annotation Data Model, serialised typically in RDF or JSON-LD.
children.label: Open Annotation format

children.hasDefinition: JSON-LD, or JavaScript Object Notation for Linked Data, is a method of encoding Linked Data using JSON.
children.hasExactSynonym: JavaScript Object Notation for Linked Data
children.label: JSON-LD

children.comment: Work in progress. 'BioXSD' belongs to the 'BioXSD|GTrack' ecosystem of generic formats. 'BioJSON' is the JSON format based on the common, unified 'BioXSD data model', a.k.a. 'BioXSD|BioJSON|BioYAML'.
children.hasDefinition: BioJSON is a BioXSD-schema-based JSON format of sequence-based data and some other common data - sequence records, alignments, feature records, references to resources, and more - optimised for integrative bioinformatics, web applications and APIs, and object-oriented programming.
children.label: BioJSON (BioXSD)

children.hasDefinition: BioJSON is a JSON format of single multiple sequence alignments, with their annotations, features, and custom visualisation and application settings for the Jalview workbench.
children.label: BioJSON (Jalview)

children.hasDefinition: JSON format of annotated scientific text used by PubAnnotations and other tools.
children.label: PubAnnotation format

children.hasDefinition: Vega is a visualization grammar, a declarative language for creating, saving, and sharing interactive visualization designs. With Vega, you can describe the visual appearance and interactive behavior of a visualization in a JSON format, and generate web-based views using Canvas or SVG.
children.label: Vega

children.hasDefinition: Vega-Lite is a high-level grammar of interactive graphics. It provides a concise JSON syntax for rapidly generating visualizations to support analysis. Vega-Lite specifications can be compiled to Vega specifications.
children.label: Vega-lite

children.hasDefinition: JavaScript Object Notation format; a lightweight, text-based format to represent tree-structured data using key-value pairs.
children.label: JSON

children.comment: Work in progress. 'BioXSD' belongs to the 'BioXSD|GTrack' ecosystem of generic formats. 'BioYAML' is the YAML format based on the common, unified 'BioXSD data model', a.k.a. 'BioXSD|BioJSON|BioYAML'.
children.hasDefinition: BioYAML is a BioXSD-schema-based YAML format of sequence-based data and some other common data - sequence records, alignments, feature records, references to resources, and more - optimised for integrative bioinformatics, web APIs, human readability and editting, and object-oriented programming.
children.label: BioYAML

children.hasDefinition: Common Workflow Language (CWL) format for description of command-line tools and workflows.
children.label: CWL

children.hasDefinition: YAML (YAML Ain't Markup Language) is a human-readable tree-structured data serialisation language.
comment: Data in YAML format can be serialised into text, or binary format.
YAML version 1.2 is a superset of JSON; prior versions were "not strictly compatible".
children.label: YAML

children.hasDefinition: A defined way or layout of representing and structuring data in a computer file, blob, string, message, or elsewhere.
children.comment: The main focus in EDAM lies on formats as means of structuring data exchanged between different tools or resources. The serialisation, compression, or encoding of concrete data formats/models is not in scope of EDAM. Format 'is format of' Data.
children.label: Format

children.hasDefinition: Query scientific literature, in search for articles, article data, concepts, named entities, or for statistics.
children.label: Literature search

children.hasDefinition: Search a sequence database and retrieve sequences that are similar to a query sequence.
children.label: Sequence similarity search

children.hasDefinition: Search a sequence database and retrieve sequences with a specified property, typically a physicochemical or compositional property.
children.label: Sequence database search (by property)

children.hasDefinition: Search a sequence database by sequence comparison and retrieve similar sequences.sequences matching a given sequence motif or pattern, such as a Prosite pattern or regular expression.
children.comment: This excludes direct retrieval methods (e.g. the dbfetch program).
children.label: Sequence database search

children.hasDefinition: Search a sequence database and retrieve sequences that are similar to a query sequence.
children.label: Sequence similarity search

children.hasDefinition: Search a database of molecular structure and retrieve structures that are similar to a query structure.
children.label: Structural similarity search

children.hasDefinition: Search a tertiary structure database, typically by sequence and/or structure comparison, or some other means, and retrieve structures and associated data.
children.label: Structure database search

children.hasDefinition: Peptide database search for identification of known and unknown PTMs looking for mass difference mismatches.
children.label: Blind peptide database search

children.hasDefinition: Statistical estimation of false discovery rate from score distribution for peptide-spectrum-matches, following a peptide database search, and by comparison to search results with a database containing incorrect information.
children.label: Target-Decoy

children.hasDefinition: Determination of best matches between MS/MS spectrum and a database of protein or nucleic acid sequences.
children.label: Peptide database search

children.hasDefinition: Search a database (or other data resource) with a supplied query and retrieve entries (or parts of entries) that are similar to the query.
children.comment: Typically the query is compared to each entry and high scoring matches (hits) are returned. For example, a BLAST search of a sequence database.
children.label: Database search

children.hasDefinition: Retrieve an entry (or part of an entry) from a data resource that matches a supplied query. This might include some primary data and annotation. The query is a data identifier or other indexed term. For example, retrieve a sequence record with the specified accession number, or matching supplied keywords.
children.label: Data retrieval

children.hasDefinition: Search or query a data resource and retrieve entries and / or annotation.
children.label: Query and retrieval

children.hasDefinition: Merge two or more (typically overlapping) molecular sequences.
children.label: Sequence merging

children.hasDefinition: Translate a DNA sequence into protein.
children.label: DNA translation

children.hasDefinition: Transcribe a nucleotide sequence into mRNA sequence(s).
children.label: DNA transcription

children.hasDefinition: Back-translate a protein sequence into DNA.
children.label: DNA back-translation

children.hasDefinition: Convert a molecular sequence from one type to another.
children.label: Sequence conversion

children.hasDefinition: Mutate a molecular sequence a specified amount or shuffle it to produce a randomised sequence with the same overall composition.
children.label: Sequence mutation and randomisation

children.hasDefinition: Mask characters in a molecular sequence (replacing those characters with a mask character).
children.comment: For example, SNPs or repeats in a DNA sequence might be masked.
children.label: Sequence masking

children.hasDefinition: Cut (remove) the end from a molecular sequence.
children.comment: This includesennd trimmingTrim sequences (typically from an automated DNA sequencer) to remove misleading ends.For example trim polyA tails, introns and primer sequence flanking the sequence of amplified exons, or other unwanted sequence.trimming to a reference sequence,Trim sequences (typically from an automated DNA sequencer) to remove the sequence ends that extend beyond an assembled reference sequence.vector trimmingTrim sequences (typically from an automated DNA sequencer) to remove sequence-specific end regions, typically contamination from vector sequences.
children.label: Sequence trimming

children.hasDefinition: Remove forward and/or reverse primers from nucleic acid sequences (typically PCR products).
children.label: Primer removal

children.hasDefinition: Cut (remove) characters or a region from a molecular sequence.
children.label: Sequence cutting

children.hasDefinition: Create (or remove) restriction sites in sequences, for example using silent mutations.
children.label: Restriction site creation

children.hasDefinition: Perform basic (non-analytical) operations on a report or file of sequences (which might include features), such as file concatenation, removal or ordering of sequences, creation of subset or a new file of sequences.
children.label: Sequence file editing

children.hasDefinition: Edit or change a molecular sequence, either randomly or specifically.
children.label: Sequence editing

children.hasDefinition: Convert a molecular sequence alignment from one type to another (for example amino acid to coding nucleotide sequence).
children.label: Sequence alignment conversion

children.hasDefinition: Edit, convert or otherwise change a molecular sequence alignment, either randomly or specifically.
children.label: Sequence alignment editing

children.hasDefinition: Edit a phylogenetic tree.
children.label: Phylogenetic tree editing

children.hasDefinition: Edit, convert or otherwise change a  molecular tertiary structure, either randomly or specifically.
children.label: Structure editing

children.hasDefinition: Edit a data entity, either randomly or specifically.
children.label: Editing

children.hasDefinition: Reformat a file of data (or equivalent entity in memory).
children.label: Formatting

children.hasDefinition: Parse, prepare or load a user-specified data file so that it is available for use.
children.label: Parsing

children.hasDefinition: Process data in such a way that makes it hard to trace to the person which the data concerns.
children.label: Anonymisation

children.hasDefinition: Recognition of which format the given data is in.
children.comment: 'Format recognition' is not a bioinformatics-specific operation, but of great relevance in bioinformatics. Should be removed from EDAM if/when captured satisfactorily in a suitable domain-generic ontology.
children.label: Format detection

children.hasDefinition: Split a file containing multiple data items into many files, each containing one item
children.label: Splitting

children.hasDefinition: Deposit some data in a database or some other type of repository or software system.
children.comment: For non-analytical operations, see the 'Processing' branch.
children.label: Deposition

children.hasDefinition: Combine multiple files or data items into a single file or object.
children.label: Aggregation

children.hasDefinition: Filter a set of files or data items according to some property.
children.label: Filtering

children.hasDefinition: Sort a set of files or data items according to some property.
children.label: Sorting

children.hasDefinition: Basic (non-analytical) operations of some data, either a file or equivalent entity in memory, such that the same basic type of data is consumed as input and generated as output.
children.label: Data handling

children.hasDefinition: Annotate a genome sequence with terms from a controlled vocabulary.
children.label: Genome annotation

children.hasDefinition: Predict the effect or function of an individual single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP).
children.label: SNP annotation

children.hasDefinition: Annotate one or more sequences with functional information, such as cellular processes or metaobolic pathways, by reference to a controlled vocabulary - invariably the Gene Ontology (GO).
children.label: Gene functional annotation

children.hasDefinition: Annotate a molecular sequence record with terms from a controlled vocabulary.
children.label: Sequence annotation

children.hasDefinition: Make sequence tag to gene assignments (tag mapping) of SAGE, MPSS and SBS data.
children.comment: Sequence tag mapping assigns experimentally obtained sequence tags to known transcripts or annotate potential virtual sequence tags in a genome.
children.label: Sequence tag mapping

children.hasDefinition: Annotate a phylogenetic tree with terms from a controlled vocabulary.
children.label: Phylogenetic tree annotation

children.hasDefinition: Annotate an image of some sort, typically with terms from a controlled vocabulary.
children.label: Image annotation

children.hasDefinition: Text annotation is the operation of adding notes, data and metadata, recognised entities and concepts, and their relations to a text (such as a scientific article).
children.label: Text annotation

children.hasDefinition: Annotate an entity (typically a biological or biomedical database entity) with terms from a controlled vocabulary.
children.comment: This is a broad concept and is used a placeholder for other, more specific concepts.
children.label: Annotation

children.hasDefinition: Generate an index of a genome sequence.
children.comment: Many sequence alignment tasks involving many or very large sequences rely on a precomputed index of the sequence to accelerate the alignment.  The Burrows-Wheeler Transform (BWT) is a permutation of the genome based on a suffix array algorithm.  A suffix array consists of the lexicographically sorted list of suffixes of a genome.
children.label: Genome indexing

children.hasDefinition: Generate an index of (typically a file of) biological data.
children.label: Indexing

children.hasDefinition: Generate the reverse and / or complement of a nucleotide sequence.
hasExactSynonym: Nucleic acid sequence reverse and complement
children.label: Reverse complement

children.hasDefinition: Generate a random sequence, for example, with a specific character composition.
children.label: Random sequence generation

children.hasDefinition: Generate digest fragments for a nucleotide sequence containing restriction sites.
children.label: Restriction digest

children.comment: This is often followed by calculation of protein fragment masses (http://edamontology.org/operation_0398).
children.hasDefinition: Cleave a protein sequence into peptide fragments (corresponding to enzymatic or chemical cleavage).
children.label: Protein sequence cleavage

children.hasDefinition: Identify base (nucleobase) sequence from a fluorescence 'trace' data generated by an automated DNA sequencer.
children.label: Base-calling

children.hasDefinition: Generate sequences from some probabilistic model, e.g. a model that simulates evolution.
children.label: Probabilistic sequence generation

children.hasDefinition: Analytical process that derives a peptide's amino acid sequence from its tandem mass spectrum (MS/MS) without the assistance of a sequence database.
children.label: de Novo sequencing

children.hasDefinition: Generate a molecular sequence by some means.
children.label: Sequence generation

children.hasDefinition: Calculate codon usage statistics and create a codon usage table.
children.label: Codon usage table generation

children.hasDefinition: Calculate a sequence distance matrix or otherwise estimate genetic distances between molecular sequences.
children.label: Sequence distance matrix generation

children.hasDefinition: Clustering of molecular sequences on the basis of their function, typically using information from an ontology of gene function, or some other measure of functional phenotype.
children.label: Functional clustering

children.hasDefinition: Build clusters of similar sequences, typically using scores from pair-wise alignment or other comparison of the sequences.
children.comment: The clusters may be output or used internally for some other purpose.
children.label: Sequence clustering

children.hasDefinition: Align molecular sequences using sequence and structural information.
children.label: Structure-based sequence alignment

children.hasDefinition: Align molecular sequence(s) to sequence profile(s), or profiles to other profiles.  A profile typically represents a sequence alignment.
children.comment: A sequence profile typically represents a sequence alignment. Methods might perform one-to-one, one-to-many or many-to-many comparisons.
children.label: Sequence profile alignment

children.hasDefinition: Align exactly two molecular sequences.
children.comment: Methods might perform one-to-one, one-to-many or many-to-many comparisons.
children.label: Pairwise sequence alignment

children.hasDefinition: Align more than two molecular sequences.
children.comment: This includes methods that use an existing alignment, for example to incorporate sequences into an alignment, or combine several multiple alignments into a single, improved alignment.
children.label: Multiple sequence alignment

children.hasDefinition: Locally align two or more molecular sequences.
children.comment: Local alignment methods identify regions of local similarity.
children.label: Local alignment

children.hasDefinition: Globally align two or more molecular sequences.
children.comment: Global alignment methods identify similarity across the entire length of the sequences.
children.label: Global alignment

children.hasDefinition: Align multiple sequences using relative gap costs calculated from neighbors in a supplied phylogenetic tree.
hasExactSynonym: Phylogenetic tree-based multiple sequence alignment construction
children.comment: This is supposed to give a more biologically meaningful alignment than standard alignments.
children.label: Tree-based sequence alignment

children.hasDefinition: Align two or more (tpyically huge) molecular sequences that represent genomes.
children.label: Genome alignment

comment: Includes methods that align sequence profiles (representing sequence alignments): ethods might perform one-to-one, one-to-many or many-to-many comparisons.  See also 'Sequence alignment comparison'.
See also "Read mapping"
children.hasDefinition: Align (identify equivalent sites within) molecular sequences.
children.label: Sequence alignment

children.hasDefinition: Align (superimpose) exactly two molecular tertiary structures.
children.label: Pairwise structure alignment

children.hasDefinition: Align (superimpose) more than two molecular tertiary structures.
children.comment: This includes methods that use an existing alignment.
children.label: Multiple structure alignment

children.hasDefinition: Locally align (superimpose) two or more molecular tertiary structures.
children.comment: Local alignment methods identify regions of local similarity, common substructures etc.
children.label: Local structure alignment

children.hasDefinition: Globally align (superimpose) two or more molecular tertiary structures.
children.comment: Global alignment methods identify similarity across the entire structures.
children.label: Global structure alignment

children.comment: Includes methods that align structural (3D) profiles or templates (representing structures or structure alignments) - including methods that perform one-to-one, one-to-many or many-to-many comparisons.
children.hasDefinition: Align (superimpose) molecular tertiary structures.
children.label: Structure alignment

comment: This includes sequence-to-3D-profile alignment methods, which align molecular sequence(s) to structural (3D) profile(s) or template(s) (representing a structure or structure alignment) - methods might perform one-to-one, one-to-many or many-to-many comparisons.
Use this concept for methods that evaluate sequence-structure compatibility by assessing residue interactions in 3D. Methods might perform one-to-one, one-to-many or many-to-many comparisons.
children.hasDefinition: Align molecular sequence to structure in 3D space (threading).
children.label: Protein threading

children.hasDefinition: Recognize (predict and identify) known protein structural domains or folds in protein sequence(s) which (typically) are not accompanied by any significant sequence similarity to know structures.
children.comment: Methods use some type of mapping between sequence and fold, for example secondary structure prediction and alignment, profile comparison, sequence properties, homologous sequence search, kernel machines etc. Domains and folds might be taken from SCOP or CATH.
children.label: Fold recognition

children.hasDefinition: Compare two or more entities, typically the sequence or structure (or derivatives) of macromolecules, to identify equivalent subunits.
children.label: Alignment

children.hasDefinition: Generate some type of sequence profile (for example a hidden Markov model) from a sequence alignment.
children.label: Sequence profile generation

children.hasDefinition: Generate some type of structural (3D) profile or template from a structure or structure alignment.
children.label: 3D profile generation

children.hasDefinition: Comparison of a DNA sequence to orthologous sequences in different species and inference of a phylogenetic tree, in order to identify regulatory elements such as transcription factor binding sites (TFBS).
children.comment: Phylogenetic shadowing is a type of footprinting where many closely related species are used.  A phylogenetic 'shadow' represents the additive differences between individual sequences. By masking or 'shadowing' variable positions a conserved sequence is produced with few or none of the variations, which is then compared to the sequences of interest to identify significant regions of conservation.
children.label: Phylogenetic footprinting

children.hasDefinition: Phylogenetic tree construction from molecular sequences.
children.comment: Methods typically compare multiple molecular sequence and estimate evolutionary distances and relationships to infer gene families or make functional predictions.
children.label: Phylogenetic inference (from molecular sequences)

children.hasDefinition: Phylogenetic tree construction from continuous quantitative character data.
hasExactSynonym: Phylogenetic tree construction (from continuous quantitative characters)
Phylogenetic tree generation (from continuous quantitative characters)
children.label: Phylogenetic inference (from continuous quantitative characters)

children.hasDefinition: Phylogenetic tree construction from gene frequency data.
children.label: Phylogenetic inference (from gene frequencies)

children.hasDefinition: Phylogenetic tree construction from polymorphism data including microsatellites, RFLP (restriction fragment length polymorphisms), RAPD (random-amplified polymorphic DNA) and AFLP (amplified fragment length polymorphisms) data.
children.label: Phylogenetic inference (from polymorphism data)

children.hasDefinition: Construct a phylogenetic tree from a specific type of data.
children.comment: Subconcepts of this concept reflect different types of data used to generate a tree, and provide an alternate axis for curation.
children.label: Phylogenetic inference (data centric)

children.hasDefinition: Construct a phylogenetic tree by computing a sequence alignment and searching for the tree with the fewest number of character-state changes from the alignment.
children.comment: This includes evolutionary parsimony (invariants) methods.
children.label: Phylogenetic inference (parsimony methods)

children.hasDefinition: Construct a phylogenetic tree by computing (or using precomputed) distances between sequences and searching for the tree with minimal discrepancies between pairwise distances.
children.comment: This includes neighbor joining (NJ) clustering method.
children.label: Phylogenetic inference (minimum distance methods)

children.hasDefinition: Construct a phylogenetic tree by relating sequence data to a hypothetical tree topology using a model of sequence evolution.
hasExactSynonym: Phylogenetic tree construction (maximum likelihood and Bayesian methods)
Phylogenetic tree generation (maximum likelihood and Bayesian methods)
children.comment: Maximum likelihood methods search for a tree that maximizes a likelihood function, i.e. that is most likely given the data and model. Bayesian analysis estimate the probability of tree for branch lengths and topology, typically using a Monte Carlo algorithm.
children.label: Phylogenetic inference (maximum likelihood and Bayesian methods)

children.hasDefinition: Construct a phylogenetic tree by computing four-taxon trees (4-trees) and searching for the phylogeny that matches most closely.
children.label: Phylogenetic inference (quartet methods)

children.hasDefinition: Construct a phylogenetic tree by using artificial-intelligence methods, for example genetic algorithms.
children.label: Phylogenetic inference (AI methods)

children.hasDefinition: Construct a phylogenetic tree using a specific method.
children.comment: Subconcepts of this concept reflect different computational methods used to generate a tree, and provide an alternate axis for curation.
children.label: Phylogenetic inference (method centric)

children.hasDefinition: Construct a phylogenetic species tree, for example, from a genome-wide sequence comparison.
children.label: Species tree construction

children.hasDefinition: Construct a "gene tree" which represents the evolutionary history of the genes included in the study.  This can be used to predict families of genes and gene function based on their position in a phylogenetic tree.
children.comment: Gene trees can provide evidence for gene duplication events, as well as speciation events. Where sequences from different homologs are included in a gene tree, subsequent clustering of the orthologs can demonstrate evolutionary history of the orthologs.
children.label: Gene tree construction

children.hasDefinition: Compare two or more phylogenetic trees to produce a consensus tree.
children.comment: Methods typically test for topological similarity between trees using for example a congruence index.
children.label: Consensus tree construction

children.hasDefinition: Reconstructing the inner node labels of a phylogenetic tree from its leafes.
children.comment: Note that this is somewhat different from simply analysing an existing tree or constructing a completely new one.
children.label: Phylogenetic reconstruction

children.hasDefinition: Construct a phylogenetic tree.
children.comment: Phylogenetic trees are usually constructed from a set of sequences from which an alignment (or data matrix) is calculated.
children.label: Phylogenetic inference

children.hasDefinition: Align RNA secondary structures.
children.label: RNA secondary structure alignment

children.hasDefinition: Generate a heat map of expression data from e.g. microarray data.
children.comment: The heat map usually uses a coloring scheme to represent expression values. They can show how quantitative measurements were influenced by experimental conditions.
children.label: Heat map generation

children.hasDefinition: Calculate a 3D-1D scoring matrix from analysis of protein sequence and structural data.
children.comment: A 3D-1D scoring matrix scores the probability of amino acids occurring in different structural environments.
children.label: 3D-1D scoring matrix generation

children.hasDefinition: Fill the gaps in a sequence assembly (scaffold) by merging in additional sequences.
children.comment: Different techniques are used to generate gap sequences to connect contigs, depending on the size of the gap. For small (5-20kb) gaps, PCR amplification and sequencing is used.  For large (>20kb) gaps, fragments are cloned (e.g. in BAC (Bacterial artificial chromosomes) vectors) and then sequenced.
children.label: Scaffold gap completion

children.hasDefinition: Link together a non-contiguous series of genomic sequences into a scaffold, consisting of sequences separated by gaps of known length.  The sequences that are linked are typically typically contigs; contiguous sequences corresponding to read overlaps.
children.comment: Scaffold may be positioned along a chromosome physical map to create a "golden path".
children.label: Scaffolding

children.hasDefinition: Generate a checksum of a molecular sequence.
children.label: Sequence checksum generation

children.hasDefinition: Construct a bibliography from the scientific literature.
children.label: Bibliography generation

children.hasDefinition: Compute the covariance model for (a family of) RNA secondary structures.
children.label: RNA structure covariance model generation

children.hasDefinition: Generate sequences from some probabilistic model, e.g. a model that simulates evolution.
children.label: Probabilistic sequence generation

children.hasDefinition: Generate some data from a choosen probibalistic model, possibly to evaluate algorithms.
children.label: Probabilistic data generation

children.hasDefinition: Construct some data entity.
children.comment: For non-analytical operations, see the 'Processing' branch.
children.label: Generation

children.hasDefinition: Translate a DNA sequence into protein.
children.label: DNA translation

children.hasDefinition: Transcribe a nucleotide sequence into mRNA sequence(s).
children.label: DNA transcription

children.hasDefinition: Back-translate a protein sequence into DNA.
children.label: DNA back-translation

children.hasDefinition: Convert a molecular sequence from one type to another.
children.label: Sequence conversion

children.hasDefinition: Convert a molecular sequence alignment from one type to another (for example amino acid to coding nucleotide sequence).
children.label: Sequence alignment conversion

children.hasDefinition: Convert one set of sequence coordinates to another, e.g. convert coordinates of one assembly to another, cDNA to genomic, CDS to genomic, protein translation to genomic etc.
children.label: Sequence coordinate conversion

children.hasDefinition: Convert a data set from one form to another.
children.label: Conversion

children.hasDefinition: Calculate sequence complexity, for example to find low-complexity regions in sequences.
children.label: Sequence complexity calculation

children.hasDefinition: Calculate sequence ambiguity, for example identity regions in protein or nucleotide sequences with many ambiguity codes.
children.label: Sequence ambiguity calculation

children.hasDefinition: Analyse repeat sequence organisation such as periodicity.
children.label: Repeat sequence organisation analysis

children.hasDefinition: Calculate a density plot (of base composition) for a nucleotide sequence.
children.label: Nucleic acid density plotting

children.hasDefinition: Count k-mers (substrings of length k) in DNA sequence data.
children.comment: k-mer counting is used in genome and transcriptome assembly, metagenomic sequencing, and for error correction of sequence reads.
children.label: k-mer counting

children.hasDefinition: Calculate character or word composition or frequency of a molecular sequence.
children.label: Sequence composition calculation

children.hasDefinition: Compute Essential Dynamics (ED) on a simulation trajectory: an analysis of molecule dynamics using PCA (Principal Component Analysis) applied to the atomic positional fluctuations.
children.comment: Principal Component Analysis (PCA) is a multivariate statistical analysis to obtain collective variables and reduce the dimensionality of the system.
children.label: Essential dynamics

children.hasDefinition: Analyse flexibility and motion in protein structure.
children.comment: Use this concept for analysis of flexible and rigid residues, local chain deformability, regions undergoing conformational change, molecular vibrations or fluctuational dynamics, domain motions or other large-scale structural transitions in a protein structure.
children.label: Simulation analysis

children.hasDefinition: Calculate a residue contact map (typically all-versus-all inter-residue contacts) for a protein structure.
children.label: Contact map calculation

children.hasDefinition: Calculate a matrix of distance between residues (for example the C-alpha atoms) in a protein structure.
children.label: Protein distance matrix calculation

children.hasDefinition: Calculate clusters of contacting residues in protein structures.
children.comment: This includes for example clusters of hydrophobic or charged residues, or clusters of contacting residues which have a key structural or functional role.
children.label: Residue cluster calculation

children.hasDefinition: Calculate contacts between residues, or between residues and other groups, in a protein structure, on the basis of distance calculations.
children.comment: This includes identifying HET groups, which usually correspond to ligands, lipids, but might also (not consistently) include groups that are attached to amino acids. Each HET group is supposed to have a unique three letter code and a unique name which might be given in the output.  It can also include calculation of symmetry contacts, i.e. a contact between two atoms in different asymmetric unit.
children.label: Residue distance calculation

children.hasDefinition: Identify potential hydrogen bonds between amino acids and other groups.
children.comment: The output might include the atoms involved in the bond, bond geometric parameters and bond enthalpy.
children.label: Hydrogen bond calculation

children.hasDefinition: Detect cysteines that are bound to metal in a protein structure.
children.label: Metal-bound cysteine detection

children.hasDefinition: Calculate protein residue contacts with metal in a structure.
children.label: Protein-metal contact calculation

children.hasDefinition: Calculate (and possibly score) salt bridges in a protein structure.
children.comment: Salt bridges are interactions between oppositely charged atoms in different residues. The output might include the inter-atomic distance.
children.label: Salt bridge calculation

children.hasDefinition: Calculate or extract inter-atomic, inter-residue or residue-atom contacts, distances and interactions in protein structure(s).
children.label: Residue interaction calculation

children.hasDefinition: Calculate a Ramachandran plot of a protein structure.
children.label: Ramachandran plot calculation

children.hasDefinition: Calculate, visualise or analyse phi/psi angles of a protein structure.
children.label: Protein geometry calculation

children.hasDefinition: Predict antigenicity, allergenicity / immunogenicity, allergic cross-reactivity etc of peptides and proteins.
comment: Immunological system are cellular or humoral. In vaccine design to induces a cellular immune response, methods must search for antigens that can be recognized by the major histocompatibility complex (MHC) molecules present in T lymphocytes.  If a humoral response is required, antigens for B cells must be identified.
This includes methods that generate a graphical rendering of antigenicity of a protein, such as a Hopp and Woods plot.
This is usually done in the development of peptide-specific antibodies or multi-epitope vaccines. Methods might use sequence data (for example motifs) and / or structural data.
children.label: Peptide immunogenicity prediction

children.hasDefinition: Predict contacts, non-covalent interactions and distance (constraints) between amino acids in protein sequences.
children.comment: Methods usually involve multiple sequence alignment analysis.
children.label: Residue contact prediction

children.hasDefinition: Calculate Km, Vmax and derived data for an enzyme reaction.
children.label: Enzyme kinetics calculation

children.hasDefinition: Calculate whether a protein structure has an unusually large net charge (dipole moment).
children.label: Protein dipole moment calculation

children.hasDefinition: Calculate the molecular weight of a protein (or fragments) and compare it to another protein or reference data. Generally used for protein identification.
children.label: Protein fragment weight comparison

children.hasDefinition: Calculate the molecular weight of a protein sequence or fragments.
children.label: Protein molecular weight calculation

children.hasDefinition: Predict extinction coefficients or optical density of a protein sequence.
children.label: Protein extinction coefficient calculation

children.hasDefinition: Plot a protein titration curve.
children.label: Protein titration curve plotting

children.hasDefinition: Calculate isoelectric point of a protein sequence.
children.label: Protein isoelectric point calculation

children.hasDefinition: Estimate hydrogen exchange rate of a protein sequence.
children.label: Protein hydrogen exchange rate calculation

children.hasDefinition: Calculate pH-dependent properties from pKa calculations of a protein sequence.
children.label: Protein pKa calculation

children.hasDefinition: Calculate hydrophobic or hydrophilic / charged regions of a protein sequence.
children.label: Protein hydrophobic region calculation

children.hasDefinition: Calculate aliphatic index (relative volume occupied by aliphatic side chains) of a protein.
children.label: Protein aliphatic index calculation

children.hasDefinition: Calculate the hydrophobic moment of a peptide sequence and recognize amphiphilicity.
children.comment: Hydrophobic moment is a peptides hydrophobicity measured for different angles of rotation.
children.label: Protein hydrophobic moment plotting

children.hasDefinition: Predict the stability or globularity of a protein sequence, whether it is intrinsically unfolded etc.
children.label: Protein globularity prediction

children.hasDefinition: Predict the solubility or atomic solvation energy of a protein sequence.
children.label: Protein solubility prediction

children.hasDefinition: Predict crystallizability of a protein sequence.
children.label: Protein crystallizability prediction

children.hasDefinition: Analyse the hydrophobic, hydrophilic or charge properties of a protein (from analysis of sequence or structural information).
children.label: Protein hydropathy calculation

children.hasDefinition: Calculate a 3D-1D scoring matrix from analysis of protein sequence and structural data.
children.comment: A 3D-1D scoring matrix scores the probability of amino acids occurring in different structural environments.
children.label: 3D-1D scoring matrix generation

children.hasDefinition: Calculate a theoretical mass spectrometry spectra for given sequences.
children.label: Spectrum calculation

children.hasDefinition: Extract, calculate or predict non-positional (physical or chemical) properties of a protein, including any non-positional properties of the molecular sequence, from processing a protein sequence or 3D structure.
children.comment: This includes methods to render and visualise the properties of a protein sequence, and a residue-level search for properties such as solvent accessibility, hydropathy, secondary structure, ligand-binding etc.
children.label: Protein property calculation

children.hasDefinition: Generate digest fragments for a nucleotide sequence containing restriction sites.
children.label: Restriction digest

children.hasDefinition: Calculate a thermodynamic property of DNA or DNA/RNA, such as melting temperature, enthalpy and entropy.
children.label: Nucleic acid thermodynamic property calculation

children.hasDefinition: Calculate and plot a DNA or DNA/RNA stitch profile.
children.comment: A stitch profile represents the alternative conformations that partly melted DNA can adopt in a temperature range.
children.label: Nucleic acid stitch profile plotting

children.hasDefinition: Calculate and plot a DNA or DNA/RNA melting curve.
children.label: Nucleic acid melting curve plotting

children.hasDefinition: Calculate and plot a DNA or DNA/RNA probability profile.
children.label: Nucleic acid probability profile plotting

children.hasDefinition: Calculate and plot a DNA or DNA/RNA temperature profile.
children.label: Nucleic acid temperature profile plotting

children.hasDefinition: Calculate and plot a DNA or DNA/RNA melting profile.
children.comment: A melting profile is used to visualise and analyse partly melted DNA conformations.
children.label: Nucleic acid melting profile plotting

children.hasDefinition: Calculate curvature and flexibility / stiffness of a nucleotide sequence.
children.comment: This includes properties such as.
children.label: Nucleic acid curvature calculation

children.hasDefinition: Calculate or predict physical or chemical properties of nucleic acid molecules, including any non-positional properties of the molecular sequence.
children.label: Nucleic acid property calculation

children.hasDefinition: Standardize or normalize data by some statistical method.
children.comment: In the simplest normalisation means adjusting values measured on different scales to a common scale (often between 0.0 and 1.0), but can refer to more sophisticated adjustment whereby entire probability distributions of adjusted values are brought into alignment. Standardisation typically refers to an operation whereby a range of values are standardised to measure how many standard deviations a value is from its mean.
children.label: Standardisation and normalisation

children.hasDefinition: Replace missing data with substituted values, usually by using some statistical or other mathematical approach.
children.label: Imputation

children.hasDefinition: Analyse data in order to deduce properties of an underlying distribution or population.
children.label: Statistical inference

children.hasDefinition: A statistical calculation to estimate the relationships among variables.
children.label: Regression analysis

children.hasDefinition: Construction of a statistical model, or a set of assumptions around some observed data, usually by describing a set of probability distributions which approximate the distribution of data.
children.label: Statistical modelling

children.hasDefinition: A statistical procedure that uses an orthogonal transformation to convert a set of observations of possibly correlated variables into a set of values of linearly uncorrelated variables called principal components.
children.label: Principal component analysis

children.hasDefinition: Perform a statistical data operation of some type, e.g. calibration or validation.
children.label: Statistical calculation

children.hasDefinition: Calculate the isotope distribution of a given chemical species.
children.label: Isotopic distributions calculation

children.hasDefinition: Prediction of retention time in a mass spectrometry experiment based on compositional and structural properties of the separated species.
children.label: Retention time prediction

children.hasDefinition: The calculation of species richness for a number of individual samples, based on plots of the number of species as a function of the number of samples (rarefaction curves).
children.label: Rarefaction

children.hasDefinition: A dimensionality reduction process that selects a subset of relevant features (variables, predictors) for use in model construction.
children.label: Feature selection

children.hasDefinition: A dimensionality reduction process which builds (ideally) informative and non-redundant values (features) from an initial set of measured data, to aid subsequent generalization, learning or interpretation.
children.label: Feature extraction

children.hasDefinition: A process used in statistics, machine learning, and information theory that reduces the number of random variables by obtaining a set of principal variables.
children.label: Dimensionality reduction

children.hasDefinition: Mathematical determination of the value of something, typically a properly of a  molecule.
children.label: Calculation

children.hasDefinition: Discover new motifs or conserved patterns in sequences or sequence alignments (de-novo discovery).
children.comment: Motifs and patterns might be conserved or over-represented (occur with improbable frequency).
children.label: Sequence motif discovery

children.hasDefinition: Find (scan for) known motifs, patterns and regular expressions in molecular sequence(s).
children.label: Sequence motif recognition

children.hasDefinition: Predict, recognise and identify positional features in molecular sequences such as key functional sites or regions.
children.comment: Look at "Protein feature detection" (http://edamontology.org/operation_3092) and "Nucleic acid feature detection" (http://edamontology.org/operation_0415) in case more specific terms are needed.
children.label: Sequence feature detection

children.hasDefinition: Compute Essential Dynamics (ED) on a simulation trajectory: an analysis of molecule dynamics using PCA (Principal Component Analysis) applied to the atomic positional fluctuations.
children.comment: Principal Component Analysis (PCA) is a multivariate statistical analysis to obtain collective variables and reduce the dimensionality of the system.
children.label: Essential dynamics

children.hasDefinition: Analyse flexibility and motion in protein structure.
children.comment: Use this concept for analysis of flexible and rigid residues, local chain deformability, regions undergoing conformational change, molecular vibrations or fluctuational dynamics, domain motions or other large-scale structural transitions in a protein structure.
children.label: Simulation analysis

children.hasDefinition: Calculate a residue contact map (typically all-versus-all inter-residue contacts) for a protein structure.
children.label: Contact map calculation

children.hasDefinition: Calculate a matrix of distance between residues (for example the C-alpha atoms) in a protein structure.
children.label: Protein distance matrix calculation

children.hasDefinition: Calculate clusters of contacting residues in protein structures.
children.comment: This includes for example clusters of hydrophobic or charged residues, or clusters of contacting residues which have a key structural or functional role.
children.label: Residue cluster calculation

children.hasDefinition: Calculate contacts between residues, or between residues and other groups, in a protein structure, on the basis of distance calculations.
children.comment: This includes identifying HET groups, which usually correspond to ligands, lipids, but might also (not consistently) include groups that are attached to amino acids. Each HET group is supposed to have a unique three letter code and a unique name which might be given in the output.  It can also include calculation of symmetry contacts, i.e. a contact between two atoms in different asymmetric unit.
children.label: Residue distance calculation

children.hasDefinition: Identify potential hydrogen bonds between amino acids and other groups.
children.comment: The output might include the atoms involved in the bond, bond geometric parameters and bond enthalpy.
children.label: Hydrogen bond calculation

children.hasDefinition: Detect cysteines that are bound to metal in a protein structure.
children.label: Metal-bound cysteine detection

children.hasDefinition: Calculate protein residue contacts with metal in a structure.
children.label: Protein-metal contact calculation

children.hasDefinition: Calculate (and possibly score) salt bridges in a protein structure.
children.comment: Salt bridges are interactions between oppositely charged atoms in different residues. The output might include the inter-atomic distance.
children.label: Salt bridge calculation

children.hasDefinition: Calculate or extract inter-atomic, inter-residue or residue-atom contacts, distances and interactions in protein structure(s).
children.label: Residue interaction calculation

children.hasDefinition: Calculate a Ramachandran plot of a protein structure.
children.label: Ramachandran plot calculation

children.hasDefinition: Calculate, visualise or analyse phi/psi angles of a protein structure.
children.label: Protein geometry calculation

children.hasDefinition: Predict antigenicity, allergenicity / immunogenicity, allergic cross-reactivity etc of peptides and proteins.
comment: Immunological system are cellular or humoral. In vaccine design to induces a cellular immune response, methods must search for antigens that can be recognized by the major histocompatibility complex (MHC) molecules present in T lymphocytes.  If a humoral response is required, antigens for B cells must be identified.
This includes methods that generate a graphical rendering of antigenicity of a protein, such as a Hopp and Woods plot.
This is usually done in the development of peptide-specific antibodies or multi-epitope vaccines. Methods might use sequence data (for example motifs) and / or structural data.
children.label: Peptide immunogenicity prediction

children.hasDefinition: Predict contacts, non-covalent interactions and distance (constraints) between amino acids in protein sequences.
children.comment: Methods usually involve multiple sequence alignment analysis.
children.label: Residue contact prediction

children.hasDefinition: Calculate Km, Vmax and derived data for an enzyme reaction.
children.label: Enzyme kinetics calculation

children.hasDefinition: Calculate whether a protein structure has an unusually large net charge (dipole moment).
children.label: Protein dipole moment calculation

children.hasDefinition: Calculate the molecular weight of a protein (or fragments) and compare it to another protein or reference data. Generally used for protein identification.
children.label: Protein fragment weight comparison

children.hasDefinition: Calculate the molecular weight of a protein sequence or fragments.
