children.comment: Assemblers must handle (or be complicated by) alternative splicing, trans-splicing, single-nucleotide polymorphism (SNP), recoding, and post-transcriptional modification.
children.label: EST assembly

children.hasDefinition: Reconstruction of a sequence assembly in a localised area.
children.label: Localised reassembly

children.hasDefinition: Fill the gaps in a sequence assembly (scaffold) by merging in additional sequences.
children.comment: Different techniques are used to generate gap sequences to connect contigs, depending on the size of the gap. For small (5-20kb) gaps, PCR amplification and sequencing is used.  For large (>20kb) gaps, fragments are cloned (e.g. in BAC (Bacterial artificial chromosomes) vectors) and then sequenced.
children.label: Scaffold gap completion

children.hasDefinition: Link together a non-contiguous series of genomic sequences into a scaffold, consisting of sequences separated by gaps of known length.  The sequences that are linked are typically typically contigs; contiguous sequences corresponding to read overlaps.
children.comment: Scaffold may be positioned along a chromosome physical map to create a "golden path".
children.label: Scaffolding

children.hasDefinition: Analyse sequencing data from experiments aiming to selectively sequence the coding regions of the genome.
children.label: Exome assembly

children.hasDefinition: Infer a transcriptome sequence by analysis of short sequence reads.
children.label: Transcriptome assembly

children.hasDefinition: Construction of a single sequence assembly of all reads from different samples, typically as part of a comparative metagenomic analysis.
children.label: Cross-assembly

children.hasDefinition: Combine (align and merge) overlapping fragments of a DNA sequence to reconstruct the original sequence.
children.comment: For example, assemble overlapping reads from paired-end sequencers into contigs (a contiguous sequence corresponding to read overlaps). Or assemble contigs, for example ESTs and genomic DNA fragments, depending on the detected fragment overlaps.
children.label: Sequence assembly

children.hasDefinition: Annotate a genome sequence with terms from a controlled vocabulary.
children.label: Genome annotation

children.hasDefinition: The process of assembling many short DNA sequences together such thay they represent the original chromosomes from which the DNA originated.
children.label: Genome assembly

children.hasDefinition: Align two or more (tpyically huge) molecular sequences that represent genomes.
children.label: Genome alignment

children.hasDefinition: Compare the features of two genome sequences.
children.comment: Genomic elements that might be compared include genes, indels, single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs), retrotransposons, tandem repeats and so on.
children.label: Genome feature comparison

children.hasDefinition: Measure the overall level of methyl cytosines in a genome from analysis of experimental data, typically from chromatographic methods and methyl accepting capacity assay.
children.label: Whole genome methylation analysis

children.hasDefinition: Visualise, format or render a nucleic acid sequence that is part of (and in context of) a complete genome sequence.
children.label: Genome visualisation

children.hasDefinition: Compare the sequence or features of two or more genomes, for example, to find matching regions.
children.label: Genome comparison

children.hasDefinition: Generate an index of a genome sequence.
children.comment: Many sequence alignment tasks involving many or very large sequences rely on a precomputed index of the sequence to accelerate the alignment.  The Burrows-Wheeler Transform (BWT) is a permutation of the genome based on a suffix array algorithm.  A suffix array consists of the lexicographically sorted list of suffixes of a genome.
children.label: Genome indexing

children.hasDefinition: Detects chimeric sequences (chimeras) from a sequence alignment.
children.label: Genome analysis

children.hasDefinition: Predict splicing alternatives or transcript isoforms from analysis of sequence data.
children.label: Alternative splicing prediction

children.hasDefinition: Identify, predict or analyse splice sites in nucleotide sequences.
children.comment: Methods might require a pre-mRNA or genomic DNA sequence.
children.label: Splice site prediction

children.hasDefinition: Predict, analyse, characterize or model splice sites, splicing events and so on, typically by comparing multiple nucleic acid sequences.
children.label: Splicing analysis

children.hasDefinition: Find operons (operators, promoters and genes) in bacteria genes.
children.label: Operon prediction

children.hasDefinition: Predict translation initiation sites, possibly by searching a database of sites.
children.label: Translation initiation site prediction

children.hasDefinition: Predict protein-coding regions (CDS or exon) or open reading frames in nucleotide sequences.
children.label: Coding region prediction

children.hasDefinition: Predict selenocysteine insertion sequence (SECIS) in a DNA sequence.
children.comment: SECIS elements are around 60 nucleotides in length with a stem-loop structure directs the cell to translate UGA codons as selenocysteines.
children.label: SECIS element prediction

children.hasDefinition: Identify or predict transcription factor binding sites in DNA sequences.
children.label: Transcription factor binding site prediction

children.hasDefinition: Identify or predict exonic splicing enhancers (ESE) in exons.
children.comment: An exonic splicing enhancer (ESE) is 6-base DNA sequence motif in an exon that enhances or directs splicing of pre-mRNA or hetero-nuclear RNA (hnRNA) into mRNA.
children.label: Exonic splicing enhancer prediction

children.hasDefinition: Identify or predict whole promoters or promoter elements (transcription start sites, RNA polymerase binding site, transcription factor binding sites, promoter enhancers etc) in DNA sequences.
children.comment: Methods might recognize CG content, CpG islands, splice sites, polyA signals etc.
children.label: Promoter prediction

children.hasDefinition: Identify, predict or analyse cis-regulatory elements  in DNA sequences (TATA box, Pribnow box, SOS box, CAAT box, CCAAT box, operator etc.) or in RNA sequences (e.g. riboswitches).
children.comment: Cis-regulatory elements (cis-elements) regulate the expression of genes located on the same strand from which the element was transcribed. Cis-elements are found in the 5' promoter region of the gene, in an intron, or in the 3' untranslated region. Cis-elements are often binding sites of one or more trans-acting factors. They also occur in RNA sequences, e.g. a riboswitch is a region of an mRNA molecule that bind a small target molecule that regulates the gene's activity.
children.label: cis-regulatory element prediction

children.hasDefinition: Identify or predict microRNA sequences (miRNA) and precursors or microRNA targets / binding sites in a DNA sequence.
children.label: miRNA target prediction

children.hasDefinition: Assess binding specificity of putative siRNA sequence(s), for example for a functional assay, typically with respect to designing specific siRNA sequences.
children.label: siRNA binding specificity prediction

children.hasDefinition: Identify or predict siRNA duplexes in RNA.
children.label: siRNA duplex prediction

children.hasDefinition: Identify or predict functional RNA sequences with a gene regulatory role (trans-regulatory elements) or targets.
children.comment: Trans-regulatory elements regulate genes distant from the gene from which they were transcribed.
children.label: trans-regulatory element prediction

children.hasDefinition: Identify matrix/scaffold attachment regions (MARs/SARs) in DNA sequences.
children.comment: MAR/SAR sites often flank a gene or gene cluster and are found nearby cis-regulatory sequences. They might contribute to transcription regulation.
children.label: S/MAR prediction

comment: This includes comparative genomics approaches that identify common, conserved (homologous) or synonymous transcriptional regulatory elements.  For example cross-species comparison of transcription factor binding sites (TFBS). Methods might analyse co-regulated or co-expressed genes, or sets of oppositely expressed genes.

This includes promoters, enhancers, silencers and boundary elements / insulators, regulatory protein or transcription factor binding sites etc. Methods might be specific to a particular genome and use motifs, word-based / grammatical methods, position-specific frequency matrices, discriminative pattern analysis etc.
children.hasDefinition: Identify or predict transcriptional regulatory motifs, patterns, elements or regions in DNA sequences.
children.label: Transcriptional regulatory element prediction

children.hasDefinition: Identify or predict tRNA genes in genomic sequences (tRNA).
children.label: tRNA gene prediction

children.hasDefinition: Prediction of genes or gene components from first principles, i.e. without reference to existing genes.
children.label: Ab-initio gene prediction

children.hasDefinition: Prediction of genes or gene components by reference to homologous genes.
children.label: Homology-based gene prediction

comment: Includes methods that predict whole gene structure using a combination of multiple methods to achieve better predictions.
Methods for gene prediction might be ab initio, based on phylogenetic comparisons, use motifs, sequence features, support vector machine, alignment etc.
children.hasDefinition: Detect, predict and identify genes or components of genes in DNA sequences, including promoters, coding regions, splice sites, etc.
children.label: Gene prediction

children.hasDefinition: Detects chimeric sequences (chimeras) from a sequence alignment.
children.comment: A chimera includes regions from two or more phylogenetically distinct sequences. They are usually artifacts of PCR and are thought to occur when a prematurely terminated amplicon reanneals to another DNA strand and is subsequently copied to completion in later PCR cycles.
children.label: Chimera detection

children.hasDefinition: Detect recombination (hotspots and coldspots) and identify recombination breakpoints in a sequence alignment.
children.comment: Tools might use a genetic algorithm, quartet-mapping, bootscanning, graphical methods, random forest model and so on.
children.label: Recombination detection

children.hasDefinition: Design or predict oligonucleotide primers for PCR and DNA amplification etc.
hasNarrowSynonym: PCR primer design (based on gene structure)
PCR primer design (for gene transcription profiling)
PCR primer design (for large scale sequencing)
comment: Primer design involves predicting or selecting primers that are specific to a provided PCR template. Primers can be designed with certain properties such as size of product desired, primer size etc. The output might be a minimal or overlapping primer set.

This includes predicting primers based on gene structure, promoters, exon-exon junctions, predicting primers that are conserved across multiple genomes or species, primers for for gene transcription profiling,  for genotyping polymorphisms, for example single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs),  for large scale sequencing, or for methylation PCRs.
children.label: PCR primer design

children.hasDefinition: Predict and/or optimize oligonucleotide probes for DNA microarrays, for example for transcription profiling of genes, or for genomes and gene families.
children.label: Microarray probe design

children.hasDefinition: Predict oligonucleotide primers or probes.
children.label: Primer and probe design

children.hasDefinition: Predict or optimise RNA sequences (sequence pools) with likely secondary and tertiary structure for in vitro selection.
children.label: RNA inverse folding

children.hasDefinition: Predict or optimise DNA to elicit (via DNA vaccination) an immunological response.
children.label: DNA vaccine design

children.hasDefinition: A technique whereby molecules with desired properties and function are isolated from libraries of random molecules, through iterative cycles of selection, amplification, and mutagenesis.
children.label: In vitro selection

children.hasDefinition: Design (or predict) nucleic acid sequences with specific chemical or physical properties.
children.label: Nucleic acid design

children.hasDefinition: Evaluate a DNA sequence assembly, typically for purposes of quality control.
children.label: Sequence assembly validation

children.hasDefinition: Identify and filter a (typically large) sequence data set to remove sequences from contaminants in the sample that was sequenced.
children.label: Sequence contamination filtering

children.hasDefinition: Pre-process sequence reads to ensure (or improve) quality and reliability.
children.comment: For example process paired end reads to trim low quality ends remove short sequences, identify sequence inserts, detect chimeric reads, or remove low quality sequnces including vector, adaptor, low complexity and contaminant sequences. Sequences might come from genomic DNA library, EST libraries, SSH library and so on.
children.label: Read pre-processing

children.hasDefinition: Variant filtering is used to eliminate false positive variants based for example on base calling quality, strand and position information, and mapping info.
children.label: Variant filtering

children.hasDefinition: Raw sequence data quality control.
children.comment: Analyse raw sequence data from a sequencing pipeline and identify (and possiby fix) problems.
children.label: Sequencing quality control

children.hasDefinition: The mapping of methylation sites in a DNA (genome) sequence.  Typically, the mapping of high-throughput bisulfite reads to the reference genome.
children.comment: Bisulfite mapping follows high-throughput sequencing of DNA which has undergone bisulfite treatment followed by PCR amplification; unmethylated cytosines are specifically converted to thymine, allowing the methylation status of cytosine in the DNA to be detected.
children.label: Bisulfite mapping

children.hasDefinition: Measure the overall level of methyl cytosines in a genome from analysis of experimental data, typically from chromatographic methods and methyl accepting capacity assay.
children.label: Whole genome methylation analysis

children.hasDefinition: Analysing the DNA methylation of specific genes or regions of interest.
children.label: Gene methylation analysis

children.hasDefinition: Identify and assess specific genes or regulatory regions of interest that are differentially methylated.
children.label: DMR identification

children.hasDefinition: The determination of cytosine methylation status of specific positions in a nucleic acid sequences (usually reads from a bisulfite sequencing experiment).
children.label: Methylation calling

children.hasDefinition: Analyse cytosine methylation states in nucleic acid sequences.
children.label: Methylation analysis

children.hasDefinition: A varient of oligonucleotide mapping where a read is mapped to two separate locations because of possible structural variation.
children.label: Split read mapping

children.hasDefinition: Align short oligonucleotide sequences (reads) to a larger (genomic) sequence.
children.comment: The purpose of read mapping is to identify the location of sequenced fragments within a reference genome and assumes that there is, in fact, at least local similarity between the fragment and reference sequences.
children.label: Read mapping

children.hasDefinition: Pre-process sequence reads to ensure (or improve) quality and reliability.
children.comment: For example process paired end reads to trim low quality ends remove short sequences, identify sequence inserts, detect chimeric reads, or remove low quality sequnces including vector, adaptor, low complexity and contaminant sequences. Sequences might come from genomic DNA library, EST libraries, SSH library and so on.
children.label: Read pre-processing

children.hasDefinition: Analyse mapping density (read depth) of (typically) short reads from sequencing platforms, for example, to detect deletions and duplications.
children.label: Read depth analysis

children.hasDefinition: Analyze read counts from RNA-seq experiments.
children.label: RNA-seq read count analysis

children.hasDefinition: Analyze time series data from an RNA-seq experiment.
children.label: RNA-seq time series data analysis

children.hasDefinition: Analyze data from RNA-seq experiments.
children.label: RNA-Seq analysis

children.hasDefinition: Counting and summarising the number of short sequence reads that map to genomic features.
children.label: Read summarisation

children.hasDefinition: An operation which groups reads or contigs and assigns them to operational taxonomic units.
children.comment: Binning methods use one or a combination of compositional features or sequence similarity.
children.label: Read binning

children.hasDefinition: Assigning sequence reads to separate groups / files based on their index tag (sample origin).
children.comment: NGS sequence runs are often performed with multiple samples pooled together.  In such cases, an index tag (or "barcode") - a unique sequence of between 6 and 12bp - is ligated to each sample's genetic material so that the sequence reads from different samples can be identified. The process of demultiplexing (dividing sequence reads into separate files for each index tag/sample) may be performed automatically by the sequencing hardware. Alternatively the reads may be lumped together in one file with barcodes still attached, requiring you to do the splitting using software. In such cases, a "mapping" file is used which indicates which barcodes correspond to which samples.
children.label: Demultiplexing

children.hasDefinition: The processing of reads from high-throughput sequencing machines.
children.label: Sequence read processing

children.hasDefinition: Analyse DNA sequences in order to identify a DNA 'barcode'; marker genes or any short fragment(s) of DNA that are useful to diagnose the taxa of biological organisms.
children.label: DNA barcoding

children.hasDefinition: Estimate the frequencies of different species from analysis of the molecular sequences, typically of DNA recovered from environmental samples.
children.label: Species frequency estimation

children.hasDefinition: Analyse DNA sequences in order to determine an individual's DNA characteristics, for example in criminal forensics, parentage testing and so on.
children.label: DNA profiling

children.hasDefinition: The identification of changes in DNA sequence or chromosome structure, usually in the context of diagnostic tests for disease, or to study ancestry or phylogeny.
children.comment: This can include indirect methods which reveal the results of genetic changes, such as RNA analysis to indicate gene expression, or biochemical analysis to identify expressed proteins.
children.label: DNA testing

children.hasDefinition: The detection of genetic selection, or (the end result of) the process by which certain traits become more prevalent in a species than other traits.
children.label: Selection detection

children.hasDefinition: Analyse a nucleic acid sequence (using methods that are only applicable to nucleic acid sequences).
children.label: Nucleic acid sequence analysis

children.hasDefinition: Identify and plot third base position variability in a nucleotide sequence.
children.label: Base position variability plotting

children.hasDefinition: Calculate the hydrophobic moment of a peptide sequence and recognize amphiphilicity.
children.comment: Hydrophobic moment is a peptides hydrophobicity measured for different angles of rotation.
children.label: Protein hydrophobic moment plotting

children.hasDefinition: Render a representation of a distribution that consists of group of data points plotted on a simple scale.
children.comment: Dot plots are useful when having not too many (e.g. 20) data points for each category. Example: draw a dotplot of sequence similarities identified from word-matching or character comparison.
children.label: Dot plot plotting

children.hasDefinition: Calculate a density plot (of base composition) for a nucleotide sequence.
children.label: Nucleic acid density plotting

children.hasDefinition: Render and visualise a DNA sequence assembly.
children.label: Sequence assembly visualisation

children.hasDefinition: Visualise, format or render a nucleic acid sequence that is part of (and in context of) a complete genome sequence.
children.label: Genome visualisation

children.hasDefinition: Visualise, format or render a molecular sequence or sequences such as a sequence alignment, possibly with sequence features or properties shown.
children.label: Sequence visualisation

children.hasDefinition: Align molecular sequences using sequence and structural information.
children.label: Structure-based sequence alignment

children.hasDefinition: Align molecular sequence(s) to sequence profile(s), or profiles to other profiles.  A profile typically represents a sequence alignment.
children.comment: A sequence profile typically represents a sequence alignment. Methods might perform one-to-one, one-to-many or many-to-many comparisons.
children.label: Sequence profile alignment

children.hasDefinition: Align exactly two molecular sequences.
children.comment: Methods might perform one-to-one, one-to-many or many-to-many comparisons.
children.label: Pairwise sequence alignment

children.hasDefinition: Align more than two molecular sequences.
children.comment: This includes methods that use an existing alignment, for example to incorporate sequences into an alignment, or combine several multiple alignments into a single, improved alignment.
children.label: Multiple sequence alignment

children.hasDefinition: Locally align two or more molecular sequences.
children.comment: Local alignment methods identify regions of local similarity.
children.label: Local alignment

children.hasDefinition: Globally align two or more molecular sequences.
children.comment: Global alignment methods identify similarity across the entire length of the sequences.
children.label: Global alignment

children.hasDefinition: Align multiple sequences using relative gap costs calculated from neighbors in a supplied phylogenetic tree.
hasExactSynonym: Phylogenetic tree-based multiple sequence alignment construction
children.comment: This is supposed to give a more biologically meaningful alignment than standard alignments.
children.label: Tree-based sequence alignment

children.hasDefinition: Align two or more (tpyically huge) molecular sequences that represent genomes.
children.label: Genome alignment

comment: Includes methods that align sequence profiles (representing sequence alignments): ethods might perform one-to-one, one-to-many or many-to-many comparisons.  See also 'Sequence alignment comparison'.
See also "Read mapping"
children.hasDefinition: Align (identify equivalent sites within) molecular sequences.
children.label: Sequence alignment

children.hasDefinition: Search a sequence database and retrieve sequences that are similar to a query sequence.
children.label: Sequence similarity search

children.hasDefinition: Search a sequence database and retrieve sequences with a specified property, typically a physicochemical or compositional property.
children.label: Sequence database search (by property)

children.hasDefinition: Search a sequence database by sequence comparison and retrieve similar sequences.sequences matching a given sequence motif or pattern, such as a Prosite pattern or regular expression.
children.comment: This excludes direct retrieval methods (e.g. the dbfetch program).
children.label: Sequence database search

children.hasDefinition: Phylogenetic tree construction from molecular sequences.
children.comment: Methods typically compare multiple molecular sequence and estimate evolutionary distances and relationships to infer gene families or make functional predictions.
children.label: Phylogenetic inference (from molecular sequences)

children.hasDefinition: Perform basic (non-analytical) operations on a report or file of sequences (which might include features), such as file concatenation, removal or ordering of sequences, creation of subset or a new file of sequences.
children.label: Sequence file editing

children.hasDefinition: Classify variants based on their potential effect on genes, especially functional effects on the expressed proteins.
children.comment: Variants are typically classified by their position (intronic, exonic, etc.) in a gene transcript and (for variants in coding exons) by their effect on the protein sequence (synonymous, non-synonymous, frameshifting, etc.)
children.label: Variant classification

children.hasDefinition: Classifiication (typically of molecular sequences) by assignment to some taxonomic hierarchy.
children.label: Taxonomic classification

children.hasDefinition: Assign molecular sequence(s) to a group or category.
children.label: Sequence classification

children.hasDefinition: The prediction of the degree of pathogenicity of a microorganism from analysis of molecular sequences.
children.label: Virulence prediction

children.hasDefinition: Identify or predict causes for antibiotic resistance from molecular sequence analysis.
children.label: Antimicrobial resistance prediction

children.hasDefinition: Analyse one or more known molecular sequences.
children.label: Sequence analysis

children.hasDefinition: Predict antigenicity, allergenicity / immunogenicity, allergic cross-reactivity etc of peptides and proteins.
comment: Immunological system are cellular or humoral. In vaccine design to induces a cellular immune response, methods must search for antigens that can be recognized by the major histocompatibility complex (MHC) molecules present in T lymphocytes.  If a humoral response is required, antigens for B cells must be identified.
This includes methods that generate a graphical rendering of antigenicity of a protein, such as a Hopp and Woods plot.
This is usually done in the development of peptide-specific antibodies or multi-epitope vaccines. Methods might use sequence data (for example motifs) and / or structural data.
children.label: Peptide immunogenicity prediction

children.hasDefinition: Analyse a network of protein interactions.
children.label: Protein interaction network analysis

children.hasDefinition: Predict the interactions of proteins with other proteins.
children.label: Protein interaction prediction

children.hasDefinition: Predict a network of protein interactions.
children.label: Protein interaction network prediction

children.comment: Includes analysis of raw experimental protein-protein interaction data from for example yeast two-hybrid analysis, protein microarrays, immunoaffinity chromatography followed by mass spectrometry, phage display etc.
children.hasDefinition: Analyse the interactions of proteins with other proteins.
children.label: Protein-protein interaction analysis

children.hasDefinition: Predict DNA-binding proteins.
children.label: DNA-binding protein prediction

children.hasDefinition: Predict RNA-binding proteins.
children.label: RNA-binding protein prediction

children.hasDefinition: Analyse the interaction of protein with nucleic acids, e.g. RNA or DNA-binding sites, interfaces etc.
children.label: Protein-nucleic acid interaction analysis

children.hasDefinition: Detect or predict signal peptides and signal peptide cleavage sites in protein sequences.
children.comment: Methods might use sequence motifs and features, amino acid composition, profiles, machine-learned classifiers, etc.
children.label: Protein signal peptide detection

children.hasDefinition: Predict or detect RNA-binding sites in protein sequences.
children.label: RNA binding site prediction

children.hasDefinition: Predict or detect DNA-binding sites in protein sequences.
children.label: DNA binding site prediction

children.hasDefinition: Predict or detect RNA and DNA-binding binding sites in protein sequences.
children.comment: This includes methods that predict and optimise zinc finger protein domains for DNA/RNA binding (for example for transcription factors and nucleases).
children.label: Nucleic acids-binding site prediction

children.hasDefinition: Identify or predict protein-protein binding sites.
children.label: Protein-protein binding site prediction

children.hasDefinition: Predict or detect active sites in proteins; the region of an enzyme which binds a substrate bind and catalyses a reaction.
children.label: Active site prediction

children.hasDefinition: Predict or detect ligand-binding sites in proteins; a region of a protein which reversibly binds a ligand for some biochemical purpose, such as transport or regulation of protein function.
children.label: Ligand-binding site prediction

children.hasDefinition: Predict or detect metal ion-binding sites in proteins.
children.label: Metal-binding site prediction

children.hasDefinition: Identify or predict catalytic residues, active sites or other ligand-binding sites in protein sequences or structures.
children.label: Binding site prediction

children.hasDefinition: Virtual screening is used in drug discovery to identify potential drug compounds.  It involves searching libraries of small molecules in order to identify those molecules which are most likely to bind to a drug target (typically a protein receptor or enzyme).
children.comment: Virtual screening is widely used for lead identification, lead optimization, and scaffold hopping during drug design and discovery.
children.label: Virtual screening

children.hasDefinition: Model protein-ligand (for example protein-peptide) binding using comparative modelling or other techniques.
comment: Methods aim to predict the position and orientation of a ligand bound to a protein receptor or enzyme.

Virtual screening is used in drug discovery to search libraries of small molecules in order to identify those molecules which are most likely to bind to a drug target (typically a protein receptor or enzyme).
children.label: Protein-ligand docking

children.hasDefinition: Model or simulate protein-protein binding using comparative modelling or other techniques.
children.label: Protein-protein docking

children.hasDefinition: Model the structure of a protein in complex with a small molecule or another macromolecule.
children.comment: This includes protein-protein interactions, protein-nucleic acid, protein-ligand binding etc. Methods might predict whether the molecules are likely to bind in vivo, their conformation when bound, the strength of the interaction, possible mutations to achieve bonding and so on.
children.label: Molecular docking

children.hasDefinition: Compare the functional properties of two or more proteins.
children.label: Protein function comparison

children.hasDefinition: Predict the subcellular localisation of a protein sequence.
children.comment: The prediction might include subcellular localisation (nuclear, cytoplasmic, mitochondrial, chloroplast, plastid, membrane etc) or export (extracellular proteins) of a protein.
children.label: Subcellular localisation prediction

children.hasDefinition: Predict the biological or biochemical role of a protein, or other aspects of a protein function.
children.comment: For functional properties that can be mapped to a sequence, use 'Sequence feature detection (protein)' instead.
children.label: Protein function prediction

children.hasDefinition: Predict and/or classify transmembrane proteins or transmembrane (helical) domains or regions in protein sequences.
children.label: Transmembrane protein prediction

children.hasDefinition: Visualise transmembrane proteins, typically the transmembrane regions within a sequence.
children.label: Transmembrane protein visualisation

children.hasDefinition: Analyse transmembrane protein(s), typically by processing sequence and / or structural data, and write an informative report for example about the protein and its transmembrane domains / regions.
children.comment: Use this (or child) concept for analysis of transmembrane domains (buried and exposed faces), transmembrane helices, helix topology, orientation, inter-helical contacts, membrane dipping (re-entrant) loops and other secondary structure etc. Methods might use pattern discovery, hidden Markov models, sequence alignment, structural profiles, amino acid property analysis, comparison to known domains or some combination (hybrid methods).
children.label: Transmembrane protein analysis

children.hasDefinition: Analyse a network of protein interactions.
children.label: Protein interaction network analysis

children.hasDefinition: Analyse a known network of gene regulation.
children.label: Gene regulatory network analysis

children.hasDefinition: Predict a network of gene regulation.
children.label: Gene regulatory network prediction

children.hasDefinition: Predict a network of protein interactions.
children.label: Protein interaction network prediction

children.hasDefinition: Model a metabolic network.  This can include 1) reconstruction to break down a metabolic pathways into reactions, enzymes, and other relevant information, and compilation of this into a mathematical model and 2) simulations of metabolism based on the model.
children.comment: The terms and synyonyms here reflect that for practical intents and purposes, "pathway" and "network" can be treated the same.
children.label: Metabolic network modelling

children.hasDefinition: A data mining method typically used for studying biological networks based on pairwise correlations between variables.
children.label: Weighted correlation network analysis

children.hasDefinition: Render (visualise) a network - typically a biological network of some sort.
children.label: Network visualisation

children.hasDefinition: Generate, process or analyse a biological network.
children.label: Network analysis

children.hasDefinition: Identify or screen for 3D structural motifs in protein structure(s).
children.comment: This includes conserved substructures and conserved geometry, such as spatial arrangement of secondary structure or protein backbone. Methods might use structure alignment, structural templates, searches for similar electrostatic potential and molecular surface shape, surface-mapping of phylogenetic information etc.
children.label: Structural motif discovery

children.hasDefinition: Decompose a structure into compact or globular fragments (protein peeling).
children.label: Protein peeling

children.hasDefinition: Identify structural domains in a protein structure from first principles (for example calculations on structural compactness).
children.label: Protein domain recognition

children.hasDefinition: Compare the architecture of two or more protein structures.
children.label: Protein architecture comparison

children.hasDefinition: Identify the architecture of a protein structure.
children.comment: Includes methods that try to suggest the most likely biological unit for a given protein X-ray crystal structure based on crystal symmetry and scoring of putative protein-protein interfaces.
children.label: Protein architecture recognition

children.hasDefinition: Analyse the architecture (spatial arrangement of secondary structure) of protein structure(s).
children.label: Protein architecture analysis

children.hasDefinition: Predict super-secondary structure of protein sequence(s).
children.comment: Super-secondary structures include leucine zippers, coiled coils, Helix-Turn-Helix etc.
children.label: Protein super-secondary structure prediction

children.hasDefinition: Predict and/or classify transmembrane proteins or transmembrane (helical) domains or regions in protein sequences.
children.label: Transmembrane protein prediction

children.hasDefinition: Predict helical secondary structure of protein sequences.
children.label: Protein secondary structure prediction (helices)

children.hasDefinition: Predict turn structure (for example beta hairpin turns) of protein sequences.
children.label: Protein secondary structure prediction (turns)

children.hasDefinition: Predict open coils, non-regular secondary structure and intrinsically disordered / unstructured regions of protein sequences.
children.label: Protein secondary structure prediction (coils)

children.hasDefinition: Predict secondary structure of protein sequences.
children.comment: Methods might use amino acid composition, local sequence information, multiple sequence alignments, physicochemical features, estimated energy content, statistical algorithms, hidden Markov models, support vector machines, kernel machines, neural networks etc.
children.label: Protein secondary structure prediction

children.hasDefinition: Compare protein secondary structures.
children.label: Protein secondary structure comparison

children.hasDefinition: Analyse protein secondary structure data.
children.label: Protein secondary structure analysis

comment: This includes sequence-to-3D-profile alignment methods, which align molecular sequence(s) to structural (3D) profile(s) or template(s) (representing a structure or structure alignment) - methods might perform one-to-one, one-to-many or many-to-many comparisons.
Use this concept for methods that evaluate sequence-structure compatibility by assessing residue interactions in 3D. Methods might perform one-to-one, one-to-many or many-to-many comparisons.
children.hasDefinition: Align molecular sequence to structure in 3D space (threading).
children.label: Protein threading

children.hasDefinition: Recognize (predict and identify) known protein structural domains or folds in protein sequence(s) which (typically) are not accompanied by any significant sequence similarity to know structures.
children.comment: Methods use some type of mapping between sequence and fold, for example secondary structure prediction and alignment, profile comparison, sequence properties, homologous sequence search, kernel machines etc. Domains and folds might be taken from SCOP or CATH.
children.label: Fold recognition

children.comment: Includes secondary structure assignment from circular dichroism (CD) spectroscopic data, and from protein coordinate data.
children.hasDefinition: Assign secondary structure from protein coordinate or experimental data.
children.label: Protein secondary structure assignment

children.hasDefinition: Detect cysteine bridges (from coordinate data) in a protein structure.
children.label: Cysteine bridge detection

children.hasDefinition: Detect free cysteines in a protein structure.
children.comment: A free cysteine is neither involved in a cysteine bridge, nor functions as a ligand to a metal.
children.label: Free cysteine detection

children.hasDefinition: Detect cysteines that are bound to metal in a protein structure.
children.label: Metal-bound cysteine detection

children.hasDefinition: Assign cysteine bonding state and disulfide bond partners in protein structures.
children.label: Protein cysteine and disulfide bond assignment

children.hasDefinition: Assign a protein tertiary structure (3D coordinates), or other aspects of protein structure, from raw experimental data.
children.label: Protein structure assignment

children.hasDefinition: Detect 'bumps' between residues in a structure, i.e. those with pairs of atoms whose Van der Waals' radii interpenetrate more than a defined distance.
children.label: Residue bump detection

children.hasDefinition: Identify poorly packed residues in protein structures.
children.label: Residue packing validation

children.hasDefinition: Validate protein geometry, for example bond lengths, bond angles, torsion angles, chiralities, planaraties etc.  An example is validation of a Ramachandran plot of a protein structure.
children.label: Protein geometry validation

children.hasDefinition: A method for making numerical assessments about the maximum percent of time that a conformer of a flexible macromolecule can exist and still be compatible with the experimental data.
children.label: Maximum occurence analysis

children.hasDefinition: Evaluate the quality or correctness a protein three-dimensional model.
comment: Model validation might involve checks for atomic packing, steric clashes (bumps), volume irregularities, agreement with electron density maps, number of amino acid residues, percentage of residues with missing or bad atoms, irregular Ramachandran Z-scores, irregular Chi-1 / Chi-2 normality scores, RMS-Z score on bonds and angles etc.

The PDB file format has had difficulties, inconsistencies and errors. Corrections can include identifying a meaningful sequence, removal of alternate atoms, correction of nomenclature problems, removal of incomplete residues and spurious waters, addition or removal of water, modelling of missing side chains, optimisation of cysteine bonds, regularisation of bond lengths, bond angles and planarities etc.

This includes methods that calculate poor quality residues. The scoring function to identify poor quality residues may consider residues with bad atoms or atoms with high B-factor, residues in the N- or C-terminal position, adjacent to an unstructured residue, non-canonical residues, glycine and proline (or adjacent to these such residues).
children.label: Protein structure validation

children.hasDefinition: Predict tertiary structure of protein sequence(s) without homologs of known structure.
children.label: Ab initio structure prediction

children.hasDefinition: Model protein backbone conformation.
comment: Methods might require a preliminary C(alpha) trace.
Scaffold selection, scaffold search, epitope grafting and design optimization are stages of backbone modelling done during rational vaccine design.
children.label: Backbone modelling

children.hasDefinition: Model, analyse or edit amino acid side chain conformation in protein structure, optimize side-chain packing, hydrogen bonding etc.
comment: Antibody optimisation is to optimize the antibody-interacting surface of the antigen (epitope).  Antigen optimisation is to optimize the antigen-interacting surface of the antibody (paratope). Antigen resurfacing is to resurface the antigen by varying the sequence of non-epitope regions.
Methods might use a residue rotamer library.

This includes rotamer likelihood prediction: the prediction of rotamer likelihoods for all 20 amino acid types at each position in a protein structure, where output typically includes, for each residue position, the likelihoods for the 20 amino acid types with estimated reliability of the 20 likelihoods.
children.label: Side chain modelling

children.hasDefinition: Model loop conformation in protein structures.
children.label: Loop modelling

children.hasDefinition: Build a three-dimensional protein model based on known (for example homologs) structures.
children.comment: The model might be of a whole, part or aspect of protein structure. Molecular modelling methods might use sequence-structure alignment, structural templates, molecular dynamics, energy minimisation etc.
children.label: Protein modelling

children.comment: This includes methods that predict the folding pathway(s) or non-native structural intermediates of a protein.
children.hasDefinition: Predict tertiary structure (backbone and side-chain conformation) of protein sequences.
children.label: Protein structure prediction

children.hasDefinition: Analyse, simulate or predict protein folding, typically by processing sequence and / or structural data.  For example, predict sites of nucleation or stabilisation key to protein folding.
children.label: Protein folding analysis

children.hasDefinition: Compare protein tertiary structures.
children.comment: Methods might identify structural neighbors, find structural similarities or define a structural core.
children.label: Protein structure comparison

children.hasDefinition: Analyse protein structural data.
children.label: Protein structure analysis

children.hasDefinition: Predict RNA secondary structure (for example knots, pseudoknots, alternative structures etc).
children.comment: Methods might use RNA motifs, predicted intermolecular contacts, or RNA sequence-structure compatibility (inverse RNA folding).
children.label: RNA secondary structure prediction

children.hasDefinition: Analyse some aspect of RNA/DNA folding, typically by processing sequence and/or structural data.  For example, compute folding energies such as minimum folding energies for DNA or RNA sequences or energy landscape of RNA mutants.
children.label: Nucleic acid folding analysis

children.hasDefinition: Predict RNA tertiary structure.
children.label: RNA structure prediction

children.hasDefinition: Predict DNA tertiary structure.
children.label: DNA structure prediction

children.hasDefinition: Predict structure of DNA or RNA.
children.comment: Methods might identify thermodynamically stable or evolutionarily conserved structures.
children.label: Nucleic acid structure prediction

children.hasDefinition: Predict RNA secondary structure (for example knots, pseudoknots, alternative structures etc).
children.comment: Methods might use RNA motifs, predicted intermolecular contacts, or RNA sequence-structure compatibility (inverse RNA folding).
children.label: RNA secondary structure prediction

children.hasDefinition: Align RNA secondary structures.
children.label: RNA secondary structure alignment

children.hasDefinition: Compute the covariance model for (a family of) RNA secondary structures.
children.label: RNA structure covariance model generation

children.hasDefinition: Process (read and / or write) RNA secondary structure data.
children.label: RNA secondary structure analysis

children.hasDefinition: Analyse some aspect of RNA/DNA folding, typically by processing sequence and/or structural data.  For example, compute folding energies such as minimum folding energies for DNA or RNA sequences or energy landscape of RNA mutants.
children.label: Nucleic acid folding analysis

children.hasDefinition: Compare nucleic acid tertiary structures.
children.label: Nucleic acid structure comparison

children.hasDefinition: Compute Essential Dynamics (ED) on a simulation trajectory: an analysis of molecule dynamics using PCA (Principal Component Analysis) applied to the atomic positional fluctuations.
children.comment: Principal Component Analysis (PCA) is a multivariate statistical analysis to obtain collective variables and reduce the dimensionality of the system.
children.label: Essential dynamics

children.hasDefinition: Analyse nucleic acid tertiary structural data.
children.label: Nucleic acid structure analysis

children.hasDefinition: Align (superimpose) exactly two molecular tertiary structures.
children.label: Pairwise structure alignment

children.hasDefinition: Align (superimpose) more than two molecular tertiary structures.
children.comment: This includes methods that use an existing alignment.
children.label: Multiple structure alignment

children.hasDefinition: Locally align (superimpose) two or more molecular tertiary structures.
children.comment: Local alignment methods identify regions of local similarity, common substructures etc.
children.label: Local structure alignment

children.hasDefinition: Globally align (superimpose) two or more molecular tertiary structures.
children.comment: Global alignment methods identify similarity across the entire structures.
children.label: Global structure alignment

children.comment: Includes methods that align structural (3D) profiles or templates (representing structures or structure alignments) - including methods that perform one-to-one, one-to-many or many-to-many comparisons.
children.hasDefinition: Align (superimpose) molecular tertiary structures.
children.label: Structure alignment

children.hasDefinition: Align (superimpose) exactly two molecular tertiary structures.
children.label: Pairwise structure alignment

children.hasDefinition: Align (superimpose) more than two molecular tertiary structures.
children.comment: This includes methods that use an existing alignment.
children.label: Multiple structure alignment

children.hasDefinition: Locally align (superimpose) two or more molecular tertiary structures.
children.comment: Local alignment methods identify regions of local similarity, common substructures etc.
children.label: Local structure alignment

children.hasDefinition: Globally align (superimpose) two or more molecular tertiary structures.
children.comment: Global alignment methods identify similarity across the entire structures.
children.label: Global structure alignment

children.comment: Includes methods that align structural (3D) profiles or templates (representing structures or structure alignments) - including methods that perform one-to-one, one-to-many or many-to-many comparisons.
children.hasDefinition: Align (superimpose) molecular tertiary structures.
children.label: Structure alignment

children.hasDefinition: Search a database of molecular structure and retrieve structures that are similar to a query structure.
children.label: Structural similarity search

children.hasDefinition: Compare protein tertiary structures.
children.comment: Methods might identify structural neighbors, find structural similarities or define a structural core.
children.label: Protein structure comparison

children.hasDefinition: Compare nucleic acid tertiary structures.
children.label: Nucleic acid structure comparison

children.hasDefinition: Identify and remove redudancy from a set of small molecule structures.
children.label: Chemical redundancy removal

children.hasDefinition: Compare two or more molecular surfaces.
children.label: Molecular surface comparison

children.hasDefinition: Compare two or more molecular tertiary structures.
children.label: Structure comparison

children.hasDefinition: Generate some type of structural (3D) profile or template from a structure or structure alignment.
children.label: 3D profile generation

children.hasDefinition: A technique used to construct an atomic model of an unknown structure from diffraction data, based upon an atomic model of a known structure, either a related protein or the same protein from a different crystal form.
children.comment: The technique solves the phase problem, i.e. retrieve information concern phases of the structure.
children.label: Molecular replacement

children.hasDefinition: A method used to refine a structure by moving the whole molecule or parts of it as a rigid unit, rather than moving individual atoms.
children.comment: Rigid body refinement usually follows molecular replacement in the assignment of a structure from diffraction data.
children.label: Rigid body refinement

children.hasDefinition: Refine (after evaluation) a model of a molecular structure (typically a protein structure) to reduce steric clashes, volume irregularities etc.
children.label: Molecular model refinement

children.hasDefinition: Calculate solvent accessible or buried surface areas in protein or other molecular structures.
children.comment: Solvent accessibility might be calculated for the backbone, sidechain and total (backbone plus sidechain).
children.label: Accessible surface calculation

children.hasDefinition: Calculate the molecular surface area in proteins and other macromolecules.
children.label: Molecular surface calculation

children.hasDefinition: Calculate the positions of dots that are homogeneously distributed over the surface of a molecule.
children.comment: A dot has three coordinates (x,y,z) and (typically) a color.
children.label: Surface rendering

children.hasDefinition: Compare two or more molecular surfaces.
children.label: Molecular surface comparison

children.hasDefinition: Analyse the surface properties of proteins or other macromolecules, including surface accessible pockets, interior inaccessible cavities etc.
children.label: Molecular surface analysis

children.hasDefinition: Virtual screening is used in drug discovery to identify potential drug compounds.  It involves searching libraries of small molecules in order to identify those molecules which are most likely to bind to a drug target (typically a protein receptor or enzyme).
children.comment: Virtual screening is widely used for lead identification, lead optimization, and scaffold hopping during drug design and discovery.
children.label: Virtual screening

children.hasDefinition: Model protein-ligand (for example protein-peptide) binding using comparative modelling or other techniques.
comment: Methods aim to predict the position and orientation of a ligand bound to a protein receptor or enzyme.

Virtual screening is used in drug discovery to search libraries of small molecules in order to identify those molecules which are most likely to bind to a drug target (typically a protein receptor or enzyme).
children.label: Protein-ligand docking

children.hasDefinition: Model or simulate protein-protein binding using comparative modelling or other techniques.
children.label: Protein-protein docking

children.hasDefinition: Model the structure of a protein in complex with a small molecule or another macromolecule.
children.comment: This includes protein-protein interactions, protein-nucleic acid, protein-ligand binding etc. Methods might predict whether the molecules are likely to bind in vivo, their conformation when bound, the strength of the interaction, possible mutations to achieve bonding and so on.
children.label: Molecular docking

children.hasDefinition: Calculate the positions of dots that are homogeneously distributed over the surface of a molecule.
children.comment: A dot has three coordinates (x,y,z) and (typically) a color.
children.label: Surface rendering

children.hasDefinition: Visualise transmembrane proteins, typically the transmembrane regions within a sequence.
children.label: Transmembrane protein visualisation

children.hasDefinition: Render a helical wheel representation of protein secondary structure.
children.label: Helical wheel drawing

children.hasDefinition: Render a topology diagram of protein secondary structure.
children.label: Topology diagram drawing

children.hasDefinition: 3D visualization of a molecular trajectory.
children.label: Trajectory visualization

children.hasDefinition: Visualise or render molecular 3D structure, for example a high-quality static picture or animation.
children.comment: This includes visualisation of protein secondary structure such as knots, pseudoknots etc. as well as tertiary and quaternary structure.
children.label: Structure visualisation

children.hasDefinition: Identify the architecture of a protein structure.
children.comment: Includes methods that try to suggest the most likely biological unit for a given protein X-ray crystal structure based on crystal symmetry and scoring of putative protein-protein interfaces.
children.label: Protein architecture recognition

children.hasDefinition: Assign molecular structure(s) to a group or category.
children.label: Structure classification

children.hasDefinition: The simulation of molecular (typically protein) conformation using a computational model of physical forces and computer simulation.
children.label: Molecular dynamics

children.hasDefinition: Processing of diffraction data into a corrected, ordered, and simplified form.
children.label: Diffraction data reduction

children.hasDefinition: The evaluation of diffraction intensities and integration of diffraction maxima from a diffraction experiment.
children.label: Diffraction data integration

children.hasDefinition: Phase a macromolecular crystal structure, for example by using molecular replacement or experimental phasing methods.
children.label: Phasing

children.hasDefinition: Analysis of data from a diffraction experiment.
children.label: Diffraction data analysis

children.hasDefinition: Compare (align and classify) multiple particle images from a micrograph in order to produce a representative image of the particle.
children.comment: A micrograph can include particles in multiple different orientations and/or conformations. Particles are compared and organised into sets based on their similarity. Typically iterations of classification and alignment and are performed to optimise the final 3D EM map.
children.label: Single particle alignment and classification

children.hasDefinition: An image processing technique that combines and analyze multiple images of a particulate sample, in order to produce an image with clearer features that are more easily interpreted.
children.comment: Single particle analysis is used to improve the information that can be obtained by relatively low resolution techniques, , e.g. an image of a protein or virus from transmission electron microscopy (TEM).
children.label: Single particle analysis

children.hasDefinition: Analyse known molecular tertiary structures.
children.label: Structure analysis

children.hasDefinition: Retrieve an entry (or part of an entry) from a data resource that matches a supplied query. This might include some primary data and annotation. The query is a data identifier or other indexed term. For example, retrieve a sequence record with the specified accession number, or matching supplied keywords.
children.label: Data retrieval

children.hasDefinition: Retrieve resources from information systems matching a specific information need.
children.label: Information retrieval

children.hasDefinition: Recognise named entities, ontology concepts, tags, events, and dictionary terms within documents.
children.label: Named-entity and concept recognition

children.hasDefinition: Extract structured information from unstructured ("free") or semi-structured textual documents.
children.label: Information extraction

children.hasDefinition: Identify semantic relations among entities and concepts within a text, using text mining techniques.
children.label: Relation extraction

children.hasDefinition: Process and analyse text (typically scientific literature) to extract information from it.
children.label: Text mining

children.hasDefinition: Perform cluster analysis of expression data to identify groups with similar expression profiles, for example by clustering.
children.label: Expression profile clustering

children.hasDefinition: Analyse the correlation patterns among features/molecules across across a variety of experiments, samples etc.
children.label: Expression correlation analysis

children.hasDefinition: Comparison of expression profiles.
children.label: Expression profile comparison

children.hasDefinition: Identify from molecular sequence analysis (typically from analysis of microarray or RNA-seq data) genes whose expression levels are significantly different between two sample groups.
children.comment: Differential gene expression analysis is used, for example, to identify which genes are up-regulated (increased expression) or down-regulated (decreased expression) between a group treated with a drug and a control groups.
children.label: Differential gene expression profiling

children.hasDefinition: The analysis, using proteomics techniques, to identify proteins whose encoding genes are differentially expressed under a given experimental setup.
children.label: Differential protein expression profiling

children.hasDefinition: The measurement of the activity (expression) of multiple genes in a cell, tissue, sample etc., in order to get an impression of biological function.
children.comment: Gene expression profiling generates some sort of gene expression profile, for example from microarray data.
children.label: Gene expression profiling

children.hasDefinition: Generate a heat map of expression data from e.g. microarray data.
children.comment: The heat map usually uses a coloring scheme to represent expression values. They can show how quantitative measurements were influenced by experimental conditions.
children.label: Heat map generation

children.comment: In the case of microarray data, visualise clustered gene expression data as a set of profiles, where each profile shows the gene expression values of a cluster across samples on the X-axis.
children.hasDefinition: Visualise clustered quantitative data as set of different profiles, where each profile is plotted versus different entities or samples on the X-axis.
children.label: Clustering profile plotting

children.hasDefinition: Generate a plot of distances (distance or correlation matrix) between expression values.
children.label: Proximity map plotting

children.hasDefinition: Visualise clustered expression data using a tree diagram.
hasExactSynonym: Expression data tree or dendrogram rendering
children.label: Dendrogram visualisation

children.hasDefinition: Visualise gene expression data after hierarchical clustering for representing hierarchical relationships.
children.label: Treemap visualisation

children.hasDefinition: Visualise microarray or other expression data.
children.label: Expression data visualisation

children.hasDefinition: Map an expression profile to known biological pathways, for example, to identify or reconstruct a pathway.
children.label: Expression profile pathway mapping

children.hasDefinition: Analyse a known network of gene regulation.
children.label: Gene regulatory network analysis

comment: Analyse gene expression patterns to identify sets of genes that are associated with a specific trait, condition, clinical outcome etc.
Gene sets can be defined beforehand by biological function, chromosome locations and so on.

"Gene set analysis" (often used interchangeably or in an overlapping sense with "gene-set enrichment analysis") refers to the functional analysis (term enrichment) of a differentially expressed set of genes, rather than all genes analysed.
The Gene Ontology (GO) is typically used, the input is a set of Gene IDs, and the output of the analysis is typically a ranked list of GO concepts, each associated with a p-value.
children.hasDefinition: Identify classes of genes or proteins that are over or under-represented in a large set of genes or proteins.  For example analysis of a set of genes corresponding to a gene expression profile, annotated with Gene Ontology (GO) concepts, where eventual over-/under-representation of certain GO concept within the studied set of genes is revealed.
children.label: Gene-set enrichment analysis

children.hasDefinition: Predict a network of gene regulation.
children.label: Gene regulatory network prediction

children.hasDefinition: Combine classical quantitative trait loci (QTL) analysis with gene expression profiling, for example, to describe describe cis- and trans-controlling elements for the expression of phenotype associated genes.
hasExactSynonym: Gene expression quantitative trait loci profiling
children.label: Gene expression QTL analysis

children.hasDefinition: Analyze read counts from RNA-seq experiments.
children.label: RNA-seq read count analysis

children.hasDefinition: Analyze time series data from an RNA-seq experiment.
children.label: RNA-seq time series data analysis

children.hasDefinition: Analyze data from RNA-seq experiments.
children.label: RNA-Seq analysis

children.hasDefinition: The analysis of microRNAs (miRNAs) : short, highly conserved small noncoding RNA molecules that are naturally occurring plant and animal genomes.
children.label: miRNA expression analysis

children.comment: Metagenomic inference is the profiling of phylogenetic marker genes in order to predict metagenome function.
children.hasDefinition: Process (read and/or write) expression data from experiments measuring molecules (e.g. omics data), including analysis of one or more expression profiles, typically to interpret them in functional terms.
children.label: Expression analysis

children.hasDefinition: Comparison of a DNA sequence to orthologous sequences in different species and inference of a phylogenetic tree, in order to identify regulatory elements such as transcription factor binding sites (TFBS).
children.comment: Phylogenetic shadowing is a type of footprinting where many closely related species are used.  A phylogenetic 'shadow' represents the additive differences between individual sequences. By masking or 'shadowing' variable positions a conserved sequence is produced with few or none of the variations, which is then compared to the sequences of interest to identify significant regions of conservation.
children.label: Phylogenetic footprinting

children.hasDefinition: Phylogenetic tree construction from molecular sequences.
children.comment: Methods typically compare multiple molecular sequence and estimate evolutionary distances and relationships to infer gene families or make functional predictions.
children.label: Phylogenetic inference (from molecular sequences)

children.hasDefinition: Phylogenetic tree construction from continuous quantitative character data.
hasExactSynonym: Phylogenetic tree construction (from continuous quantitative characters)
Phylogenetic tree generation (from continuous quantitative characters)
children.label: Phylogenetic inference (from continuous quantitative characters)

children.hasDefinition: Phylogenetic tree construction from gene frequency data.
children.label: Phylogenetic inference (from gene frequencies)

children.hasDefinition: Phylogenetic tree construction from polymorphism data including microsatellites, RFLP (restriction fragment length polymorphisms), RAPD (random-amplified polymorphic DNA) and AFLP (amplified fragment length polymorphisms) data.
children.label: Phylogenetic inference (from polymorphism data)

children.hasDefinition: Construct a phylogenetic tree from a specific type of data.
children.comment: Subconcepts of this concept reflect different types of data used to generate a tree, and provide an alternate axis for curation.
children.label: Phylogenetic inference (data centric)

children.hasDefinition: Construct a phylogenetic tree by computing a sequence alignment and searching for the tree with the fewest number of character-state changes from the alignment.
children.comment: This includes evolutionary parsimony (invariants) methods.
children.label: Phylogenetic inference (parsimony methods)

children.hasDefinition: Construct a phylogenetic tree by computing (or using precomputed) distances between sequences and searching for the tree with minimal discrepancies between pairwise distances.
children.comment: This includes neighbor joining (NJ) clustering method.
children.label: Phylogenetic inference (minimum distance methods)

children.hasDefinition: Construct a phylogenetic tree by relating sequence data to a hypothetical tree topology using a model of sequence evolution.
hasExactSynonym: Phylogenetic tree construction (maximum likelihood and Bayesian methods)
Phylogenetic tree generation (maximum likelihood and Bayesian methods)
children.comment: Maximum likelihood methods search for a tree that maximizes a likelihood function, i.e. that is most likely given the data and model. Bayesian analysis estimate the probability of tree for branch lengths and topology, typically using a Monte Carlo algorithm.
children.label: Phylogenetic inference (maximum likelihood and Bayesian methods)

children.hasDefinition: Construct a phylogenetic tree by computing four-taxon trees (4-trees) and searching for the phylogeny that matches most closely.
children.label: Phylogenetic inference (quartet methods)

children.hasDefinition: Construct a phylogenetic tree by using artificial-intelligence methods, for example genetic algorithms.
children.label: Phylogenetic inference (AI methods)

children.hasDefinition: Construct a phylogenetic tree using a specific method.
children.comment: Subconcepts of this concept reflect different computational methods used to generate a tree, and provide an alternate axis for curation.
children.label: Phylogenetic inference (method centric)

children.hasDefinition: Construct a phylogenetic species tree, for example, from a genome-wide sequence comparison.
children.label: Species tree construction

children.hasDefinition: Construct a "gene tree" which represents the evolutionary history of the genes included in the study.  This can be used to predict families of genes and gene function based on their position in a phylogenetic tree.
children.comment: Gene trees can provide evidence for gene duplication events, as well as speciation events. Where sequences from different homologs are included in a gene tree, subsequent clustering of the orthologs can demonstrate evolutionary history of the orthologs.
children.label: Gene tree construction

children.hasDefinition: Compare two or more phylogenetic trees to produce a consensus tree.
children.comment: Methods typically test for topological similarity between trees using for example a congruence index.
children.label: Consensus tree construction

children.hasDefinition: Reconstructing the inner node labels of a phylogenetic tree from its leafes.
children.comment: Note that this is somewhat different from simply analysing an existing tree or constructing a completely new one.
children.label: Phylogenetic reconstruction

children.hasDefinition: Construct a phylogenetic tree.
children.comment: Phylogenetic trees are usually constructed from a set of sequences from which an alignment (or data matrix) is calculated.
children.label: Phylogenetic inference

children.hasDefinition: Compare two or more phylogenetic trees to produce a consensus tree.
children.comment: Methods typically test for topological similarity between trees using for example a congruence index.
children.label: Consensus tree construction

children.hasDefinition: Compare two or more phylogenetic trees to detect subtrees or supertrees.
children.label: Phylogenetic sub/super tree construction

children.hasDefinition: Compare two or more phylogenetic trees to calculate distances between trees.
children.label: Phylogenetic tree distances calculation

children.hasDefinition: Mapping between gene tree nodes and species tree nodes or branches, to analyse and account for possible differences between gene histories and species histories, explaining this in terms of gene-scale events such as duplication, loss, transfer etc.
children.comment: Methods typically test for topological similarity between trees using for example a congruence index.
children.label: Phylogenetic tree reconciliation

children.hasDefinition: Compare two or more phylogenetic trees.
children.comment: For example, to produce a consensus tree, subtrees, supertrees, calculate distances between trees or test topological similarity between trees (e.g. a congruence index) etc.
children.label: Phylogenetic tree comparison

children.hasDefinition: Edit a phylogenetic tree.
children.label: Phylogenetic tree editing

children.hasDefinition: Analyse the shape (topology) of a phylogenetic tree.
children.label: Phylogenetic tree topology analysis

children.hasDefinition: Apply bootstrapping or other measures to estimate confidence of a phylogenetic tree.
children.label: Phylogenetic tree bootstrapping

children.hasDefinition: Analyse a phylogenetic tree to identify allele frequency distribution and change that is subject to evolutionary pressures (natural selection, genetic drift, mutation and gene flow). Identify type of natural selection (such as stabilizing, balancing or disruptive).
children.comment: Stabilizing/purifying (directional) selection favors a single phenotype and tends to decrease genetic diversity as a population stabilizes on a particular trait, selecting out trait extremes or deleterious mutations. In contrast, balancing selection maintain genetic polymorphisms (or multiple alleles), whereas disruptive (or diversifying) selection favors individuals at both extremes of a trait.
children.label: Allele frequency distribution analysis

children.hasDefinition: Render or visualise a phylogenetic tree.
children.label: Phylogenetic tree visualisation

children.hasDefinition: The extrapolation of empirical characteristics of individuals or populations, backwards in time, to their common ancestors.
children.comment: Ancestral reconstruction is often used to recover possible ancestral character states of ancient, extinct organisms.
children.label: Ancestral reconstruction

children.hasDefinition: The application of phylogenetic and other methods to estimate paleogeographical events such as speciation.
children.label: Tree dating

children.hasDefinition: Analyse an existing phylogenetic tree or trees, typically to detect features or make predictions.
children.comment: Phylgenetic modelling is the modelling of trait evolution and prediction of trait values using phylogeny as a basis.
children.label: Phylogenetic analysis

children.hasDefinition: Map an expression profile to known biological pathways, for example, to identify or reconstruct a pathway.
children.label: Expression profile pathway mapping

children.hasDefinition: Model a metabolic network.  This can include 1) reconstruction to break down a metabolic pathways into reactions, enzymes, and other relevant information, and compilation of this into a mathematical model and 2) simulations of metabolism based on the model.
children.comment: The terms and synyonyms here reflect that for practical intents and purposes, "pathway" and "network" can be treated the same.
children.label: Metabolic network modelling

children.hasDefinition: Render (visualise) a biological pathway.
children.label: Pathway visualisation

children.hasDefinition: Predict a metabolic pathway.
children.label: Metabolic pathway prediction

children.hasDefinition: Generate, process or analyse a biological pathway.
children.label: Pathway analysis

comment: Analyse gene expression patterns to identify sets of genes that are associated with a specific trait, condition, clinical outcome etc.
Gene sets can be defined beforehand by biological function, chromosome locations and so on.

"Gene set analysis" (often used interchangeably or in an overlapping sense with "gene-set enrichment analysis") refers to the functional analysis (term enrichment) of a differentially expressed set of genes, rather than all genes analysed.
The Gene Ontology (GO) is typically used, the input is a set of Gene IDs, and the output of the analysis is typically a ranked list of GO concepts, each associated with a p-value.
children.hasDefinition: Identify classes of genes or proteins that are over or under-represented in a large set of genes or proteins.  For example analysis of a set of genes corresponding to a gene expression profile, annotated with Gene Ontology (GO) concepts, where eventual over-/under-representation of certain GO concept within the studied set of genes is revealed.
children.label: Gene-set enrichment analysis

children.hasDefinition: Analyse a dataset with respect to concepts from an ontology of chemical structure, leveraging chemical similarity information.
children.label: Chemical similarity enrichment

children.hasDefinition: Analysis of a set of objects, such as genes, annotated with given categories, where eventual over-/under-representation of certain categories within the studied set of objects is revealed.
children.comment: Categories from a relevant ontology can be used. The input is typically a set of genes or other biological objects, possibly represented by their identifiers, and the output of the analysis is typically a ranked list of categories, each associated with a statistical metric of over-/under-representation within the studied data.
children.label: Enrichment analysis

children.hasDefinition: Detect frameshifts in DNA sequences, including frameshift sites and signals, and frameshift errors from sequencing projects.
children.comment: Methods include sequence alignment (if related sequences are available) and word-based sequence comparison.
children.label: Frameshift detection

children.hasDefinition: Identify insertion, deletion and duplication events from a sequence alignment.
children.comment: Tools might use a genetic algorithm, quartet-mapping, bootscanning, graphical methods, random forest model and so on.
children.label: Indel detection

children.hasDefinition: Find single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) - single nucleotide change in base positions - between sequences. Typically done for sequences from a high-throughput sequencing experiment that differ from a reference genome and which might, especially by reference to population frequency or functional data, indicate a polymorphism.
children.comment: This includes functional SNPs for large-scale genotyping purposes, disease-associated non-synonymous SNPs etc.
children.label: SNP detection

children.hasDefinition: Detect, identify and map mutations, such as single nucleotide polymorphisms, short indels and structural variants, in multiple DNA sequences. Typically the alignment and comparison of the fluorescent traces produced by DNA sequencing hardware, to study genomic alterations.
comment: Methods often utilise a database of aligned reads.
Somatic variant calling is the detection of variations established in somatic cells and hence not inherited as a germ line variant.
Variant detection
children.label: Variant calling

children.hasDefinition: Genotyping of multiple loci, typically characterizing microbial species isolates using internal fragments of multiple housekeeping genes.
children.label: Multilocus sequence typing

children.hasDefinition: Analyse DNA sequence data to identify differences between the genetic composition (genotype) of an individual compared to other individual's or a reference sequence.
children.comment: Methods might consider cytogenetic analyses, copy number polymorphism (and calculate copy number calls for copy-number variation(CNV) regions), single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP), , rare copy number variation (CNV) identification, loss of heterozygosity data and so on.
children.label: Genotyping

children.hasDefinition: Classify variants based on their potential effect on genes, especially functional effects on the expressed proteins.
children.comment: Variants are typically classified by their position (intronic, exonic, etc.) in a gene transcript and (for variants in coding exons) by their effect on the protein sequence (synonymous, non-synonymous, frameshifting, etc.)
children.label: Variant classification

children.hasDefinition: Identify biologically interesting variants by prioritizing individual variants, for example, homozygous variants absent in control genomes.
children.comment: Variant prioritisation can be used for example to produce a list of variants responsible for 'knocking out' genes in specific genomes. Methods amino acid substitution, aggregative approaches, probabilistic approach, inheritance and unified likelihood-frameworks.
children.label: Variant prioritisation

children.hasDefinition: Estimate the number of copies of loci of particular gene(s) in DNA sequences typically from gene-expression profiling technology based on microarray hybridisation-based experiments. For example, estimate copy number (or marker dosage) of a dominant marker in samples from polyploid plant cells or tissues, or chromosomal gains and losses in tumors.
children.comment: Methods typically implement some statistical model for hypothesis testing, and methods estimate total copy number, i.e. do not distinguish the two inherited chromosomes quantities (specific copy number).
children.label: Copy number estimation

children.hasDefinition: Identify deletion events causing the number of repeats in the genome to vary between individuals.
children.label: Deletion detection

children.hasDefinition: Identify duplication events causing the number of repeats in the genome to vary between individuals.
