children.label: Duplication detection

children.hasDefinition: Identify copy number variations which are complex, e.g. multi-allelic variations that have many structural alleles and have rearranged multiple times in the ancestral genomes.
children.label: Complex CNV detection

children.hasDefinition: Identify amplification events causing the number of repeats in the genome to vary between individuals.
children.label: Amplification detection

children.hasDefinition: Identify where sections of the genome are repeated and the number of repeats in the genome varies between individuals.
children.label: Copy number variation detection

children.hasDefinition: Detect large regions in a genome subject to copy-number variation, or other structural variations in genome(s).
children.comment: Methods might involve analysis of whole-genome array comparative genome hybridisation or single-nucleotide polymorphism arrays, paired-end mapping of sequencing data, or from analysis of short reads from new sequencing technologies.
children.label: Structural variation detection

children.hasDefinition: Identify and map patterns of genomic variations.
children.comment: Methods often utilise a database of aligned reads.
children.label: Variant pattern analysis

children.hasDefinition: Identification of the best reference for mapping for a specific dataset from a list of potential references, when performing genetic variation analysis.
children.label: Reference identification

children.hasDefinition: A method whereby data on several variants are "collapsed" into a single covariate based on regions such as genes.
children.comment: Genome-wide association studies (GWAS) analyse a genome-wide set of genetic variants in different individuals to see if any variant is associated with a trait. Traditional association techniques can lack the power to detect the significance of rare variants individually, or measure their compound effect (rare variant burden).  "Collapsing methods" were developed to overcome these problems.
children.label: Collapsing methods

children.hasDefinition: Analyse a genetic variation, for example to annotate its location, alleles, classification, and effects on individual transcripts predicted for a gene model.
children.comment: Genetic variation annotation provides contextual interpretation of coding SNP consequences in transcripts. It allows comparisons to be made between variation data in different populations or strains for the same transcript.
children.label: Genetic variation analysis

children.hasDefinition: Identify peaks in a spectrum from a mass spectrometry, NMR, or some other spectrum-generating experiment.
children.label: Peak detection

children.hasDefinition: Re-adjust the output of mass spectrometry experiments with shifted ppm values.
children.label: Mass spectra calibration

children.hasDefinition: Align multiple data sets using information from chromatography and/or peptide identification, from mass spectrometry experiments.
children.label: Chromatographic alignment

children.hasDefinition: The removal of isotope peaks in a spectrum, to represent the fragment ion as one data point.
children.comment: Deisotoping is commonly done to reduce complexity, and done in conjunction with the charge state deconvolution.
children.label: Deisotoping

children.hasDefinition: Calculate number of identified MS2 spectra as approximation of peptide / protein quantity.
children.label: Spectral counting

children.hasDefinition: Label-free quantification by integration of ion current (ion counting).
children.label: Ion counting

children.hasDefinition: Quantification without the use of chemical tags.
children.label: Label-free quantification

children.hasDefinition: Quantification analysis using stable isotope labeling by amino acids in cell culture.
children.label: SILAC

children.hasDefinition: Quantification analysis using the AB SCIEX iTRAQ isobaric labelling workflow, wherein 2-8 reporter ions are measured in MS2 spectra near 114 m/z.
children.label: iTRAQ

children.hasDefinition: Quantification analysis using labeling based on 18O-enriched H2O.
children.label: 18O labeling

children.hasDefinition: Quantification analysis using the Thermo Fisher tandem mass tag labelling workflow.
children.label: TMT-tag

children.hasDefinition: Quantification analysis using chemical labeling by stable isotope dimethylation
children.label: Dimethyl

children.hasDefinition: Chemical tagging free amino groups of intact proteins with stable isotopes.
children.label: Isotope-coded protein label

children.hasDefinition: Labeling all proteins and (possibly) all amino acids using C-13 or N-15 enriched grown medium or feed.
children.comment: This includes N-15 metabolic labeling (labeling all proteins and (possibly) all amino acids using N-15 enriched grown medium or feed) and C-13 metabolic labeling (labeling all proteins and (possibly) all amino acids using C-13 enriched grown medium or feed).
children.label: Metabolic labeling

children.hasDefinition: Quantification based on the use of chemical tags.
children.label: Labeled quantification

children.hasDefinition: Quantification by Selected/multiple Reaction Monitoring workflow (XIC quantitation of precursor / fragment mass pair).
children.label: MRM/SRM

children.hasDefinition: Technique for determining the amount of proteins in a sample.
children.label: Protein quantification

children.hasDefinition: Peptide sequence tags are used as piece of information about a peptide obtained by tandem mass spectrometry.
children.label: Tag-based peptide identification

children.hasDefinition: Analytical process that derives a peptide's amino acid sequence from its tandem mass spectrum (MS/MS) without the assistance of a sequence database.
children.label: de Novo sequencing

children.hasDefinition: Site localisation of post-translational modifications in peptide or protein mass spectra.
children.label: PTM localisation

children.hasDefinition: Identification of post-translational modifications (PTMs) of peptides/proteins in mass spectrum.
children.label: PTM identification

children.hasDefinition: Peptide database search for identification of known and unknown PTMs looking for mass difference mismatches.
children.label: Blind peptide database search

children.hasDefinition: Statistical estimation of false discovery rate from score distribution for peptide-spectrum-matches, following a peptide database search, and by comparison to search results with a database containing incorrect information.
children.label: Target-Decoy

children.hasDefinition: Determination of best matches between MS/MS spectrum and a database of protein or nucleic acid sequences.
children.label: Peptide database search

children.hasDefinition: Match experimentally measured mass spectrum to a spectrum in a spectral library or database.
children.label: Spectral library search

children.hasDefinition: Determination of peptide sequence from mass spectrum.
children.label: Peptide identification

children.hasDefinition: Identification of protein, for example from one or more peptide identifications by tandem mass spectrometry.
children.label: Protein identification

children.hasDefinition: Mass spectra identification of compounds that are produced by living systems. Including polyketides, terpenoids, phenylpropanoids, alkaloids and antibiotics.
children.label: Natural product identification

children.hasDefinition: Calculate a theoretical mass spectrometry spectra for given sequences.
children.label: Spectrum calculation

children.hasDefinition: Analyse one or more spectra from mass spectrometry (or other) experiments.
children.label: Spectral analysis

children.hasDefinition: Analysis of cell migration images in order to study cell migration, typically in order to study the processes that play a role in the disease progression.
children.label: Cell migration analysis

children.hasDefinition: Measurement of neurites; projections (axons or dendrites) from the cell body of a neuron, from analysis of neuron images.
children.label: Neurite measurement

children.hasDefinition: Compare (align and classify) multiple particle images from a micrograph in order to produce a representative image of the particle.
children.comment: A micrograph can include particles in multiple different orientations and/or conformations. Particles are compared and organised into sets based on their similarity. Typically iterations of classification and alignment and are performed to optimise the final 3D EM map.
children.label: Single particle alignment and classification

children.hasDefinition: An image processing technique that combines and analyze multiple images of a particulate sample, in order to produce an image with clearer features that are more easily interpreted.
children.comment: Single particle analysis is used to improve the information that can be obtained by relatively low resolution techniques, , e.g. an image of a protein or virus from transmission electron microscopy (TEM).
children.label: Single particle analysis

children.hasDefinition: The analysis of a image (typically a digital image) of some type in order to extract information from it.
children.label: Image analysis

children.hasDefinition: Apply analytical methods to existing data of a specific type.
children.comment: This excludes non-analytical methods that read and write the same basic type of data (for that, see 'Data handling').
children.label: Analysis

children.hasDefinition: Predict splicing alternatives or transcript isoforms from analysis of sequence data.
children.label: Alternative splicing prediction

children.hasDefinition: Identify, predict or analyse splice sites in nucleotide sequences.
children.comment: Methods might require a pre-mRNA or genomic DNA sequence.
children.label: Splice site prediction

children.hasDefinition: Predict, analyse, characterize or model splice sites, splicing events and so on, typically by comparing multiple nucleic acid sequences.
children.label: Splicing analysis

children.hasDefinition: Analyse some aspect of RNA/DNA folding, typically by processing sequence and/or structural data.  For example, compute folding energies such as minimum folding energies for DNA or RNA sequences or energy landscape of RNA mutants.
children.label: Nucleic acid folding analysis

children.hasDefinition: Model protein backbone conformation.
comment: Methods might require a preliminary C(alpha) trace.
Scaffold selection, scaffold search, epitope grafting and design optimization are stages of backbone modelling done during rational vaccine design.
children.label: Backbone modelling

children.hasDefinition: Model, analyse or edit amino acid side chain conformation in protein structure, optimize side-chain packing, hydrogen bonding etc.
comment: Antibody optimisation is to optimize the antibody-interacting surface of the antigen (epitope).  Antigen optimisation is to optimize the antigen-interacting surface of the antibody (paratope). Antigen resurfacing is to resurface the antigen by varying the sequence of non-epitope regions.
Methods might use a residue rotamer library.

This includes rotamer likelihood prediction: the prediction of rotamer likelihoods for all 20 amino acid types at each position in a protein structure, where output typically includes, for each residue position, the likelihoods for the 20 amino acid types with estimated reliability of the 20 likelihoods.
children.label: Side chain modelling

children.hasDefinition: Model loop conformation in protein structures.
children.label: Loop modelling

children.hasDefinition: Build a three-dimensional protein model based on known (for example homologs) structures.
children.comment: The model might be of a whole, part or aspect of protein structure. Molecular modelling methods might use sequence-structure alignment, structural templates, molecular dynamics, energy minimisation etc.
children.label: Protein modelling

children.hasDefinition: Identify a plausible model of DNA substitution that explains a molecular (DNA or protein) sequence alignment.
children.label: DNA substitution modelling

children.hasDefinition: Analyse, simulate or predict protein folding, typically by processing sequence and / or structural data.  For example, predict sites of nucleation or stabilisation key to protein folding.
children.label: Protein folding analysis

children.hasDefinition: The simulation of molecular (typically protein) conformation using a computational model of physical forces and computer simulation.
children.label: Molecular dynamics

children.hasDefinition: Simulate gene expression data, e.g. for purposes of benchmarking.
children.label: Simulated gene expression data generation

children.hasDefinition: Obtain force field parameters (charge, bonds, dihedrals, etc.) from a molecule, to be used in molecular simulations
children.label: Forcefield parameterisation

children.hasDefinition: The development and use of mathematical models and systems analysis for the description of ecological processes, and applications such as the sustainable management of resources.
children.label: Ecological modelling

children.hasDefinition: Model or simulate some biological entity or system, typically using mathematical techniques including  dynamical systems, statistical models, differential equations, and game theoretic models.
children.label: Modelling and simulation

children.hasDefinition: Clustering of molecular sequences on the basis of their function, typically using information from an ontology of gene function, or some other measure of functional phenotype.
children.label: Functional clustering

children.hasDefinition: Build clusters of similar sequences, typically using scores from pair-wise alignment or other comparison of the sequences.
children.comment: The clusters may be output or used internally for some other purpose.
children.label: Sequence clustering

children.hasDefinition: Perform cluster analysis of expression data to identify groups with similar expression profiles, for example by clustering.
children.label: Expression profile clustering

children.hasDefinition: Build clusters of similar structures, typically using scores from structural alignment methods.
children.label: Structure clustering

children.hasDefinition: Cluster (group) documents on the basis of their calculated similarity.
children.label: Document clustering

children.hasDefinition: Group together some data entities on the basis of similarities such that entities in the same group (cluster) are more similar to each other than to those in other groups (clusters).
children.label: Clustering

children.hasDefinition: Align molecular sequences using sequence and structural information.
children.label: Structure-based sequence alignment

children.hasDefinition: Align molecular sequence(s) to sequence profile(s), or profiles to other profiles.  A profile typically represents a sequence alignment.
children.comment: A sequence profile typically represents a sequence alignment. Methods might perform one-to-one, one-to-many or many-to-many comparisons.
children.label: Sequence profile alignment

children.hasDefinition: Align exactly two molecular sequences.
children.comment: Methods might perform one-to-one, one-to-many or many-to-many comparisons.
children.label: Pairwise sequence alignment

children.hasDefinition: Align more than two molecular sequences.
children.comment: This includes methods that use an existing alignment, for example to incorporate sequences into an alignment, or combine several multiple alignments into a single, improved alignment.
children.label: Multiple sequence alignment

children.hasDefinition: Locally align two or more molecular sequences.
children.comment: Local alignment methods identify regions of local similarity.
children.label: Local alignment

children.hasDefinition: Globally align two or more molecular sequences.
children.comment: Global alignment methods identify similarity across the entire length of the sequences.
children.label: Global alignment

children.hasDefinition: Align multiple sequences using relative gap costs calculated from neighbors in a supplied phylogenetic tree.
hasExactSynonym: Phylogenetic tree-based multiple sequence alignment construction
children.comment: This is supposed to give a more biologically meaningful alignment than standard alignments.
children.label: Tree-based sequence alignment

children.hasDefinition: Align two or more (tpyically huge) molecular sequences that represent genomes.
children.label: Genome alignment

comment: Includes methods that align sequence profiles (representing sequence alignments): ethods might perform one-to-one, one-to-many or many-to-many comparisons.  See also 'Sequence alignment comparison'.
See also "Read mapping"
children.hasDefinition: Align (identify equivalent sites within) molecular sequences.
children.label: Sequence alignment

children.hasDefinition: Align (superimpose) exactly two molecular tertiary structures.
children.label: Pairwise structure alignment

children.hasDefinition: Align (superimpose) more than two molecular tertiary structures.
children.comment: This includes methods that use an existing alignment.
children.label: Multiple structure alignment

children.hasDefinition: Locally align (superimpose) two or more molecular tertiary structures.
children.comment: Local alignment methods identify regions of local similarity, common substructures etc.
children.label: Local structure alignment

children.hasDefinition: Globally align (superimpose) two or more molecular tertiary structures.
children.comment: Global alignment methods identify similarity across the entire structures.
children.label: Global structure alignment

children.comment: Includes methods that align structural (3D) profiles or templates (representing structures or structure alignments) - including methods that perform one-to-one, one-to-many or many-to-many comparisons.
children.hasDefinition: Align (superimpose) molecular tertiary structures.
children.label: Structure alignment

comment: This includes sequence-to-3D-profile alignment methods, which align molecular sequence(s) to structural (3D) profile(s) or template(s) (representing a structure or structure alignment) - methods might perform one-to-one, one-to-many or many-to-many comparisons.
Use this concept for methods that evaluate sequence-structure compatibility by assessing residue interactions in 3D. Methods might perform one-to-one, one-to-many or many-to-many comparisons.
children.hasDefinition: Align molecular sequence to structure in 3D space (threading).
children.label: Protein threading

children.hasDefinition: Recognize (predict and identify) known protein structural domains or folds in protein sequence(s) which (typically) are not accompanied by any significant sequence similarity to know structures.
children.comment: Methods use some type of mapping between sequence and fold, for example secondary structure prediction and alignment, profile comparison, sequence properties, homologous sequence search, kernel machines etc. Domains and folds might be taken from SCOP or CATH.
children.label: Fold recognition

children.hasDefinition: Compare two or more entities, typically the sequence or structure (or derivatives) of macromolecules, to identify equivalent subunits.
children.label: Alignment

children.hasDefinition: Predict and/or optimize oligonucleotide probes for DNA microarrays, for example for transcription profiling of genes, or for genomes and gene families.
children.label: Microarray probe design

children.hasDefinition: Design or predict oligonucleotide primers for PCR and DNA amplification etc.
hasNarrowSynonym: PCR primer design (based on gene structure)
PCR primer design (for gene transcription profiling)
PCR primer design (for large scale sequencing)
comment: Primer design involves predicting or selecting primers that are specific to a provided PCR template. Primers can be designed with certain properties such as size of product desired, primer size etc. The output might be a minimal or overlapping primer set.

This includes predicting primers based on gene structure, promoters, exon-exon junctions, predicting primers that are conserved across multiple genomes or species, primers for for gene transcription profiling,  for genotyping polymorphisms, for example single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs),  for large scale sequencing, or for methylation PCRs.
children.label: PCR primer design

children.hasDefinition: Predict and/or optimize oligonucleotide probes for DNA microarrays, for example for transcription profiling of genes, or for genomes and gene families.
children.label: Microarray probe design

children.hasDefinition: Predict oligonucleotide primers or probes.
children.label: Primer and probe design

children.hasDefinition: Predict or optimise RNA sequences (sequence pools) with likely secondary and tertiary structure for in vitro selection.
children.label: RNA inverse folding

children.hasDefinition: Predict or optimise DNA to elicit (via DNA vaccination) an immunological response.
children.label: DNA vaccine design

children.hasDefinition: A technique whereby molecules with desired properties and function are isolated from libraries of random molecules, through iterative cycles of selection, amplification, and mutagenesis.
children.label: In vitro selection

children.hasDefinition: Design (or predict) nucleic acid sequences with specific chemical or physical properties.
children.label: Nucleic acid design

children.hasDefinition: Virtual screening is used in drug discovery to identify potential drug compounds.  It involves searching libraries of small molecules in order to identify those molecules which are most likely to bind to a drug target (typically a protein receptor or enzyme).
children.comment: Virtual screening is widely used for lead identification, lead optimization, and scaffold hopping during drug design and discovery.
children.label: Virtual screening

children.hasDefinition: The design of small molecules with specific biological activity, such as inhibitors or modulators for proteins that are of therapeutic interest.  This can involve the modification of individual atoms, the addition or removal of molecular fragments, and the use reaction-based design to explore tractable synthesis options for the small molecule.
comment: Small molecule design can involve assessment of target druggability and flexibility, molecular docking, in silico fragment screening, molecular dynamics, and homology modeling.

There are two broad categories of small molecule design techniques when applied to the design of drugs: ligand-based drug design (e.g. ligand similarity) and structure-based drug design (ligand docking) methods. Ligand similarity methods exploit structural similarities to known active ligands, whereas ligand docking methods use the 3D structure of a target protein to predict the binding modes and affinities of ligands to it.
children.label: Small molecule design

children.hasDefinition: Design new protein molecules with specific structural or functional properties.
children.label: Protein design

children.hasDefinition: Design a biological entity (typically a molecular sequence or structure) with specific properties.
children.label: Design

children.hasDefinition: Detect 'bumps' between residues in a structure, i.e. those with pairs of atoms whose Van der Waals' radii interpenetrate more than a defined distance.
children.label: Residue bump detection

children.hasDefinition: Identify poorly packed residues in protein structures.
children.label: Residue packing validation

children.hasDefinition: Validate protein geometry, for example bond lengths, bond angles, torsion angles, chiralities, planaraties etc.  An example is validation of a Ramachandran plot of a protein structure.
children.label: Protein geometry validation

children.hasDefinition: A method for making numerical assessments about the maximum percent of time that a conformer of a flexible macromolecule can exist and still be compatible with the experimental data.
children.label: Maximum occurence analysis

children.hasDefinition: Evaluate the quality or correctness a protein three-dimensional model.
comment: Model validation might involve checks for atomic packing, steric clashes (bumps), volume irregularities, agreement with electron density maps, number of amino acid residues, percentage of residues with missing or bad atoms, irregular Ramachandran Z-scores, irregular Chi-1 / Chi-2 normality scores, RMS-Z score on bonds and angles etc.

The PDB file format has had difficulties, inconsistencies and errors. Corrections can include identifying a meaningful sequence, removal of alternate atoms, correction of nomenclature problems, removal of incomplete residues and spurious waters, addition or removal of water, modelling of missing side chains, optimisation of cysteine bonds, regularisation of bond lengths, bond angles and planarities etc.

This includes methods that calculate poor quality residues. The scoring function to identify poor quality residues may consider residues with bad atoms or atoms with high B-factor, residues in the N- or C-terminal position, adjacent to an unstructured residue, non-canonical residues, glycine and proline (or adjacent to these such residues).
children.label: Protein structure validation

children.hasDefinition: Test and validate the format and content of a data file.
children.label: Format validation

children.hasDefinition: Evaluate molecular sequence alignment accuracy.
children.comment: Evaluation might be purely sequence-based or use structural information.
children.label: Sequence alignment validation

children.hasDefinition: Apply bootstrapping or other measures to estimate confidence of a phylogenetic tree.
children.label: Phylogenetic tree bootstrapping

children.hasDefinition: Evaluate a DNA sequence assembly, typically for purposes of quality control.
children.label: Sequence assembly validation

children.hasDefinition: Evaluate a DNA sequence assembly, typically for purposes of quality control.
children.label: Sequence assembly validation

children.hasDefinition: Identify and filter a (typically large) sequence data set to remove sequences from contaminants in the sample that was sequenced.
children.label: Sequence contamination filtering

children.hasDefinition: Pre-process sequence reads to ensure (or improve) quality and reliability.
children.comment: For example process paired end reads to trim low quality ends remove short sequences, identify sequence inserts, detect chimeric reads, or remove low quality sequnces including vector, adaptor, low complexity and contaminant sequences. Sequences might come from genomic DNA library, EST libraries, SSH library and so on.
children.label: Read pre-processing

children.hasDefinition: Variant filtering is used to eliminate false positive variants based for example on base calling quality, strand and position information, and mapping info.
children.label: Variant filtering

children.hasDefinition: Raw sequence data quality control.
children.comment: Analyse raw sequence data from a sequencing pipeline and identify (and possiby fix) problems.
children.label: Sequencing quality control

children.hasDefinition: Statistical estimation of false discovery rate from score distribution for peptide-spectrum-matches, following a peptide database search, and by comparison to search results with a database containing incorrect information.
children.label: Target-Decoy

children.hasDefinition: Validate some data.
children.label: Validation

children.hasDefinition: A technique used to construct an atomic model of an unknown structure from diffraction data, based upon an atomic model of a known structure, either a related protein or the same protein from a different crystal form.
children.comment: The technique solves the phase problem, i.e. retrieve information concern phases of the structure.
children.label: Molecular replacement

children.hasDefinition: A method used to refine a structure by moving the whole molecule or parts of it as a rigid unit, rather than moving individual atoms.
children.comment: Rigid body refinement usually follows molecular replacement in the assignment of a structure from diffraction data.
children.label: Rigid body refinement

children.hasDefinition: Refine (after evaluation) a model of a molecular structure (typically a protein structure) to reduce steric clashes, volume irregularities etc.
children.label: Molecular model refinement

children.hasDefinition: Refine an existing sequence alignment.
children.label: Sequence alignment refinement

children.hasDefinition: Refine or optimise some data model.
children.label: Optimisation and refinement

children.hasDefinition: Identify and plot third base position variability in a nucleotide sequence.
children.label: Base position variability plotting

children.hasDefinition: Calculate the hydrophobic moment of a peptide sequence and recognize amphiphilicity.
children.comment: Hydrophobic moment is a peptides hydrophobicity measured for different angles of rotation.
children.label: Protein hydrophobic moment plotting

children.hasDefinition: Render a representation of a distribution that consists of group of data points plotted on a simple scale.
children.comment: Dot plots are useful when having not too many (e.g. 20) data points for each category. Example: draw a dotplot of sequence similarities identified from word-matching or character comparison.
children.label: Dot plot plotting

children.hasDefinition: Calculate a density plot (of base composition) for a nucleotide sequence.
children.label: Nucleic acid density plotting

children.hasDefinition: Render and visualise a DNA sequence assembly.
children.label: Sequence assembly visualisation

children.hasDefinition: Visualise, format or render a nucleic acid sequence that is part of (and in context of) a complete genome sequence.
children.label: Genome visualisation

children.hasDefinition: Visualise, format or render a molecular sequence or sequences such as a sequence alignment, possibly with sequence features or properties shown.
children.label: Sequence visualisation

children.hasDefinition: Plot a protein titration curve.
children.label: Protein titration curve plotting

children.hasDefinition: Calculate and plot a DNA or DNA/RNA stitch profile.
children.comment: A stitch profile represents the alternative conformations that partly melted DNA can adopt in a temperature range.
children.label: Nucleic acid stitch profile plotting

children.hasDefinition: Calculate and plot a DNA or DNA/RNA melting curve.
children.label: Nucleic acid melting curve plotting

children.hasDefinition: Calculate and plot a DNA or DNA/RNA probability profile.
children.label: Nucleic acid probability profile plotting

children.hasDefinition: Calculate and plot a DNA or DNA/RNA temperature profile.
children.label: Nucleic acid temperature profile plotting

children.hasDefinition: Calculate and plot a DNA or DNA/RNA melting profile.
children.comment: A melting profile is used to visualise and analyse partly melted DNA conformations.
children.label: Nucleic acid melting profile plotting

children.hasDefinition: Generate a heat map of expression data from e.g. microarray data.
children.comment: The heat map usually uses a coloring scheme to represent expression values. They can show how quantitative measurements were influenced by experimental conditions.
children.label: Heat map generation

children.comment: In the case of microarray data, visualise clustered gene expression data as a set of profiles, where each profile shows the gene expression values of a cluster across samples on the X-axis.
children.hasDefinition: Visualise clustered quantitative data as set of different profiles, where each profile is plotted versus different entities or samples on the X-axis.
children.label: Clustering profile plotting

children.hasDefinition: Generate a plot of distances (distance or correlation matrix) between expression values.
children.label: Proximity map plotting

children.hasDefinition: Visualise clustered expression data using a tree diagram.
hasExactSynonym: Expression data tree or dendrogram rendering
children.label: Dendrogram visualisation

children.hasDefinition: Visualise gene expression data after hierarchical clustering for representing hierarchical relationships.
children.label: Treemap visualisation

children.hasDefinition: Visualise microarray or other expression data.
children.label: Expression data visualisation

children.hasDefinition: Visualise, format or render sequence clusters.
children.label: Sequence cluster visualisation

children.hasDefinition: Render or visualise a phylogenetic tree.
children.label: Phylogenetic tree visualisation

children.hasDefinition: Calculate the positions of dots that are homogeneously distributed over the surface of a molecule.
children.comment: A dot has three coordinates (x,y,z) and (typically) a color.
children.label: Surface rendering

children.hasDefinition: Visualise transmembrane proteins, typically the transmembrane regions within a sequence.
children.label: Transmembrane protein visualisation

children.hasDefinition: Render a helical wheel representation of protein secondary structure.
children.label: Helical wheel drawing

children.hasDefinition: Render a topology diagram of protein secondary structure.
children.label: Topology diagram drawing

children.hasDefinition: 3D visualization of a molecular trajectory.
children.label: Trajectory visualization

children.hasDefinition: Visualise or render molecular 3D structure, for example a high-quality static picture or animation.
children.comment: This includes visualisation of protein secondary structure such as knots, pseudoknots etc. as well as tertiary and quaternary structure.
children.label: Structure visualisation

children.hasDefinition: Draw or visualise restriction maps in DNA sequences.
children.label: Restriction map drawing

children.hasDefinition: Draw a circular maps of DNA, for example a plasmid map.
children.label: Plasmid map drawing

children.hasDefinition: Visualise operon structure etc.
children.label: Operon drawing

children.hasDefinition: Draw or visualise a DNA map.
children.label: Map drawing

comment: Examples for visualization are the distribution of variance over the components, loading and score plots.

The use of Principal Component Analysis (PCA), a multivariate statistical analysis to obtain collective variables on the atomic positional fluctuations, helps to separate the configurational space in two subspaces: an essential subspace containing relevant motions, and another one containing irrelevant local fluctuations.
children.hasDefinition: Visualize the results of a principal component analysis (orthogonal data transformation).  For example, visualization of the principal components (essential subspace) coming from a Principal Component Analysis (PCA) on the trajectory atomistic coordinates of a molecular structure.
children.label: Principal component visualisation

children.comment: Comparison of two sets of quantitative data such as two samples of gene expression values.
children.hasDefinition: Render a graph in which the values of two variables are plotted along two axes; the pattern of the points reveals any correlation.
children.label: Scatter plot plotting

children.comment: In the case of micorarray data, visualise raw and pre-processed gene expression data, via a plot showing over- and under-expression along with mean, upper and lower quartiles.
children.hasDefinition: Generate a box plot, i.e. a depiction of groups of numerical data through their quartiles.
children.label: Box-Whisker plot plotting

children.hasDefinition: Visualise, format or render an image of a Chromatogram.
children.label: Chromatogram visualisation

children.hasDefinition: Plot an incident curve such as a survival curve, death curve, mortality curve.
children.label: Incident curve plotting

children.hasDefinition: Visualise images resulting from various types of microscopy.
children.label: Microscope image visualisation

children.hasDefinition: Visualise, format or render data from an ontology, typically a tree of terms.
children.label: Ontology visualisation

children.hasDefinition: Visualise, format or render a mass spectrum.
children.label: Mass spectrum visualisation

children.hasDefinition: Visualise, format or render data arising from an analysis of multiple samples from a metagenomics/community experiment.
children.label: Multiple sample visualisation

children.hasDefinition: Render (visualise) a network - typically a biological network of some sort.
children.label: Network visualisation

children.hasDefinition: Render (visualise) a biological pathway.
children.label: Pathway visualisation

children.hasDefinition: Visualise, plot or render (graphically) biomolecular data such as molecular sequences or structures.
children.comment: This includes methods to render and visualise molecules.
children.label: Visualisation

children.hasDefinition: Infer haplotypes, either alleles at multiple loci that are transmitted together on the same chromosome, or a set of single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) on a single chromatid that are statistically associated.
children.comment: Haplotype inference can help in population genetic studies and the identification of complex disease genes, , and is typically based on aligned single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) fragments. Haplotype comparison is a useful way to characterize the genetic variation between individuals. An individual's haplotype describes which nucleotide base occurs at each position for a set of common SNPs. Tools might use combinatorial functions (for example parsimony) or a likelihood function or model with optimisation such as minimum error correction (MEC) model, expectation-maximisation algorithm (EM), genetic algorithm or Markov chain Monte Carlo (MCMC).
children.label: Haplotype mapping

children.hasDefinition: Generate a genetic (linkage) map of a DNA sequence (typically a chromosome) showing the relative positions of genetic markers based on estimation of non-physical distances.
comment: Mapping involves ordering genetic loci along a chromosome and estimating the physical distance between loci. A genetic map shows the relative (not physical) position of known genes and genetic markers.
This includes mapping of the genetic architecture of dynamic complex traits (functional mapping), e.g. by characterisation of the underlying quantitative trait loci (QTLs) or nucleotides (QTNs).
children.label: Genetic mapping

children.hasDefinition: Generate a physical (radiation hybrid) map of genetic markers in a DNA sequence using provided radiation hybrid (RH) scores for one or more markers.
children.label: Radiation Hybrid Mapping

children.hasDefinition: Generate a physical DNA map (sequence map) from analysis of sequence tagged sites (STS).
children.comment: An STS is a short subsequence of known sequence and location that occurs only once in the chromosome or genome that is being mapped. Sources of STSs include 1. expressed sequence tags (ESTs), simple sequence length polymorphisms (SSLPs), and random genomic sequences from cloned genomic DNA or database sequences.
children.label: Sequence tagged site (STS) mapping

children.hasDefinition: The mapping of methylation sites in a DNA (genome) sequence.  Typically, the mapping of high-throughput bisulfite reads to the reference genome.
children.comment: Bisulfite mapping follows high-throughput sequencing of DNA which has undergone bisulfite treatment followed by PCR amplification; unmethylated cytosines are specifically converted to thymine, allowing the methylation status of cytosine in the DNA to be detected.
children.label: Bisulfite mapping

children.hasDefinition: A varient of oligonucleotide mapping where a read is mapped to two separate locations because of possible structural variation.
children.label: Split read mapping

children.hasDefinition: Align short oligonucleotide sequences (reads) to a larger (genomic) sequence.
children.comment: The purpose of read mapping is to identify the location of sequenced fragments within a reference genome and assumes that there is, in fact, at least local similarity between the fragment and reference sequences.
children.label: Read mapping

children.hasDefinition: Generate a physical (sequence) map of a DNA sequence showing the physical distance (base pairs) between features or landmarks such as restriction sites, cloned DNA fragments, genes and other genetic markers.
children.label: Physical mapping

children.hasDefinition: Make sequence tag to gene assignments (tag mapping) of SAGE, MPSS and SBS data.
children.comment: Sequence tag mapping assigns experimentally obtained sequence tags to known transcripts or annotate potential virtual sequence tags in a genome.
children.label: Sequence tag mapping

children.hasDefinition: Generate a map of a DNA sequence annotated with positional or non-positional features of some type.
children.label: DNA mapping

children.hasDefinition: Predict antigenic determinant sites (epitopes) in protein sequences.
children.comment: Epitope mapping is commonly done during vaccine design.
children.label: Epitope mapping

children.hasDefinition: Map an expression profile to known biological pathways, for example, to identify or reconstruct a pathway.
children.label: Expression profile pathway mapping

children.hasDefinition: Map data identifiers to one another for example to establish a link between two biological databases for the purposes of data integration.
children.comment: The mapping can be achieved by comparing identifier values or some other means, e.g. exact matches to a provided sequence.
children.label: ID mapping

children.hasDefinition: Compare the models or schemas used by two or more databases, or any other general comparison of databases rather than a detailed comparison of the entries themselves.
children.label: Database comparison

children.hasDefinition: Predict adhesins in protein sequences.
children.comment: An adhesin is a cell-surface component that facilitate the adherence of a microorganism to a cell or surface. They are important virulence factors during establishment of infection and thus are targetted during vaccine development approaches that seek to block adhesin function and prevent adherence to host cell.
children.label: Adhesin prediction

children.hasDefinition: Map properties to positions on an biological entity (typically a molecular sequence or structure), or assemble such an entity from constituent parts.
children.label: Mapping

children.hasDefinition: Analyse correlations between sites in a molecular sequence alignment.
children.comment: This is typically done to identify possible covarying positions and predict contacts or structural constraints in protein structures.
children.label: Sequence alignment analysis (site correlation)

children.hasDefinition: Analyse the correlation patterns among features/molecules across across a variety of experiments, samples etc.
children.label: Expression correlation analysis

children.hasDefinition: Identify a correlation, i.e. a statistical relationship between two random variables or two sets of data.
children.label: Correlation

children.hasDefinition: Identify the architecture of a protein structure.
children.comment: Includes methods that try to suggest the most likely biological unit for a given protein X-ray crystal structure based on crystal symmetry and scoring of putative protein-protein interfaces.
children.label: Protein architecture recognition

children.hasDefinition: Assign molecular structure(s) to a group or category.
children.label: Structure classification

children.hasDefinition: Classify variants based on their potential effect on genes, especially functional effects on the expressed proteins.
children.comment: Variants are typically classified by their position (intronic, exonic, etc.) in a gene transcript and (for variants in coding exons) by their effect on the protein sequence (synonymous, non-synonymous, frameshifting, etc.)
children.label: Variant classification

children.hasDefinition: Classifiication (typically of molecular sequences) by assignment to some taxonomic hierarchy.
children.label: Taxonomic classification

children.hasDefinition: Assign molecular sequence(s) to a group or category.
children.label: Sequence classification

children.hasDefinition: Compare (align and classify) multiple particle images from a micrograph in order to produce a representative image of the particle.
children.comment: A micrograph can include particles in multiple different orientations and/or conformations. Particles are compared and organised into sets based on their similarity. Typically iterations of classification and alignment and are performed to optimise the final 3D EM map.
children.label: Single particle alignment and classification

children.hasDefinition: Assign molecular sequences, structures or other biological data to a specific group or category according to qualities it shares with that group or category.
children.label: Classification

children.hasDefinition: Calculate number of identified MS2 spectra as approximation of peptide / protein quantity.
children.label: Spectral counting

children.hasDefinition: Label-free quantification by integration of ion current (ion counting).
children.label: Ion counting

children.hasDefinition: Quantification without the use of chemical tags.
children.label: Label-free quantification

children.hasDefinition: Quantification analysis using stable isotope labeling by amino acids in cell culture.
children.label: SILAC

children.hasDefinition: Quantification analysis using the AB SCIEX iTRAQ isobaric labelling workflow, wherein 2-8 reporter ions are measured in MS2 spectra near 114 m/z.
children.label: iTRAQ

children.hasDefinition: Quantification analysis using labeling based on 18O-enriched H2O.
children.label: 18O labeling

children.hasDefinition: Quantification analysis using the Thermo Fisher tandem mass tag labelling workflow.
children.label: TMT-tag

children.hasDefinition: Quantification analysis using chemical labeling by stable isotope dimethylation
children.label: Dimethyl

children.hasDefinition: Chemical tagging free amino groups of intact proteins with stable isotopes.
children.label: Isotope-coded protein label

children.hasDefinition: Labeling all proteins and (possibly) all amino acids using C-13 or N-15 enriched grown medium or feed.
children.comment: This includes N-15 metabolic labeling (labeling all proteins and (possibly) all amino acids using N-15 enriched grown medium or feed) and C-13 metabolic labeling (labeling all proteins and (possibly) all amino acids using C-13 enriched grown medium or feed).
children.label: Metabolic labeling

children.hasDefinition: Quantification based on the use of chemical tags.
children.label: Labeled quantification

children.hasDefinition: Quantification by Selected/multiple Reaction Monitoring workflow (XIC quantitation of precursor / fragment mass pair).
children.label: MRM/SRM

children.hasDefinition: Technique for determining the amount of proteins in a sample.
children.label: Protein quantification

children.hasDefinition: Quantification of data arising from RNA-Seq high-throughput sequencing, typically the quantification of transcript abundances durnig transcriptome analysis in a gene expression study.
children.label: RNA-Seq quantification

children.hasDefinition: Counting and measuring experimentally determined observations into quantities.
children.label: Quantification

children.hasDefinition: An operation supporting the browsing or discovery of other tools and services.
children.label: Service discovery

children.hasDefinition: An operation supporting the aggregation of other services (at least two) into a funtional unit, for the automation of some task.
children.label: Service composition

children.hasDefinition: An operation supporting the calling (invocation) of other tools and services.
children.label: Service invocation

children.hasDefinition: Operations concerning the handling and use of other tools.
children.label: Service management

children.hasDefinition: A function that processes a set of inputs and results in a set of outputs, or associates arguments (inputs) with values (outputs).
children.comment: Special cases are: a) An operation that consumes no input (has no input arguments). Such operation is either a constant function, or an operation depending only on the underlying state. b) An operation that may modify the underlying state but has no output. c) The singular-case operation with no input or output, that still may modify the underlying state.
children.label: Operation

children.hasDefinition: The archival, curation, processing and analysis of nucleic acid structural information, such as whole structures, structural features and alignments, and associated annotation.
children.comment: Includes secondary and tertiary nucleic acid structural data, nucleic acid thermodynamic, thermal and conformational properties including DNA or DNA/RNA denaturation (melting) etc.
children.label: Nucleic acid structure analysis

children.hasDefinition: Non-coding or functional RNA sequences, including regulatory RNA sequences, ribosomal RNA (rRNA) and transfer RNA (tRNA).
children.comment: Non-coding RNA includes  piwi-interacting RNA (piRNA), small nuclear RNA (snRNA) and small nucleolar RNA (snoRNA).  Regulatory RNA includes microRNA (miRNA) - short single stranded RNA molecules that regulate gene expression, and small interfering RNA (siRNA).
children.label: Functional, regulatory and non-coding RNA

children.hasDefinition: RNA splicing; post-transcription RNA modification involving the removal of introns and joining of exons.
children.comment: This includes the study of splice sites, splicing patterns, alternative splicing events and variants, isoforms, etc..
children.label: RNA splicing

children.hasDefinition: Transcription of DNA into RNA and features of a messenger RNA (mRNA) molecules including precursor RNA, primary (unprocessed) transcript and fully processed molecules.
comment: This includes 5'untranslated region (5'UTR), coding sequences (CDS), exons, intervening sequences (intron) and 3'untranslated regions (3'UTR).

This includes Introns, and protein-coding regions including coding sequences (CDS), exons, translation initiation sites and open reading frames.  Also expressed sequence tag (EST) or complementary DNA (cDNA) sequences.

This includes coding sequences for a signal or transit peptide.  A signal peptide coding sequence encodes an N-terminal domain of a secreted protein, which is involved in attaching the polypeptide to a membrane leader sequence. A transit peptide coding sequence encodes an N-terminal domain of a nuclear-encoded organellar protein; which is involved in import of the protein into the organelle.

This includes regions or sites in a eukaryotic and eukaryotic viral RNA sequence which directs endonuclease cleavage or polyadenylation of an RNA transcript.  A polyA signal is required for endonuclease cleavage of an RNA transcript that is followed by polyadenylation. A polyA site is a site on an RNA transcript to which adenine residues will be added during post-transcriptional polyadenylation.
children.label: Gene transcripts

children.hasDefinition: RNA sequences and structures.
children.label: RNA

children.hasDefinition: Proteins that bind to DNA and control transcription of DNA to mRNA (transcription factors) and also transcriptional regulatory sites, elements and regions (such as promoters, enhancers, silencers and boundary elements / insulators) in nucleotide sequences.
comment: This includes CpG rich regions (isochores) in a nucleotide sequence.

This includes promoters, CAAT signals, TATA signals, -35 signals, -10 signals, GC signals, primer binding sites for initiation of transcription or reverse transcription, enhancer, attenuator, terminators and ribosome binding sites.

Transcription factor proteins either promote (as an activator) or block (as a repressor) the binding to DNA of RNA polymerase.  Regulatory sites including transcription factor binding site as well as promoters, enhancers, silencers and boundary elements / insulators.
children.label: Transcription factors and regulatory sites

children.hasDefinition: Nucleic acids binding to some other molecule.
comment: This includes ribosome binding sites (Shine-Dalgarno sequence in prokaryotes), restriction enzyme recognition sites (restriction sites) etc.

This includes sites involved with DNA replication and recombination.  This includes binding sites for initiation of replication (origin of replication), regions where transfer is initiated during the conjugation or mobilisation (origin of transfer), starting sites for DNA duplication (origin of replication) and regions which are eliminated through any of kind of recombination.  Also nucleosome exclusion regions, i.e. specific patterns or regions which exclude nucleosomes (the basic structural units of eukaryotic chromatin which play a significant role in regulating gene expression).
children.label: DNA binding sites

children.hasDefinition: DNA mutation.
children.label: DNA mutation

children.hasDefinition: DNA polymorphism.
hasNarrowSynonym: Variable number of tandem repeat polymorphism
comment: Includes microsatellite polymorphism in a DNA sequence.  A microsatellite polymorphism is a very short subsequence that is repeated a variable number of times between individuals. These repeats consist of the nucleotides cytosine and adenosine.
Includes restriction fragment length polymorphisms (RFLP) in a DNA sequence.  An RFLP is defined by the presence or absence of a specific restriction site of a bacterial restriction enzyme.

Includes single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNP) and associated data, for example, the discovery and annotation of SNPs.  A SNP is a DNA sequence variation where a single nucleotide differs between members of a species or paired chromosomes in an individual.

Includes variable number of tandem repeat (VNTR) polymorphism in a DNA sequence.  VNTRs occur in non-coding regions of DNA and consists sub-sequence that is repeated a multiple (and varied) number of times.
children.label: DNA polymorphism

children.hasDefinition: DNA replication or recombination.
children.label: DNA replication and recombination

children.hasDefinition: A DNA structural variation, specifically a duplication or deletion event, resulting in sections of the genome to be repeated, or the number of repeats in the genome to vary between individuals.
children.label: Copy number variation

children.hasDefinition: Variation in chromosome structure including microscopic and submicroscopic types of variation such as deletions, duplications, copy-number variants, insertions, inversions and translocations.
children.label: Structural variation

children.hasDefinition: DNA-histone complexes (chromatin), organisation of chromatin into nucleosomes and packaging into higher-order structures.
children.label: DNA packaging

children.hasDefinition: DNA sequences and structure, including processes such as methylation and replication.
children.comment: The DNA sequences might be coding or non-coding sequences.
children.label: DNA

children.hasDefinition: Proteins that bind to DNA and control transcription of DNA to mRNA (transcription factors) and also transcriptional regulatory sites, elements and regions (such as promoters, enhancers, silencers and boundary elements / insulators) in nucleotide sequences.
comment: This includes CpG rich regions (isochores) in a nucleotide sequence.

This includes promoters, CAAT signals, TATA signals, -35 signals, -10 signals, GC signals, primer binding sites for initiation of transcription or reverse transcription, enhancer, attenuator, terminators and ribosome binding sites.

Transcription factor proteins either promote (as an activator) or block (as a repressor) the binding to DNA of RNA polymerase.  Regulatory sites including transcription factor binding site as well as promoters, enhancers, silencers and boundary elements / insulators.
children.label: Transcription factors and regulatory sites

children.hasDefinition: Nucleic acids binding to some other molecule.
comment: This includes ribosome binding sites (Shine-Dalgarno sequence in prokaryotes), restriction enzyme recognition sites (restriction sites) etc.

This includes sites involved with DNA replication and recombination.  This includes binding sites for initiation of replication (origin of replication), regions where transfer is initiated during the conjugation or mobilisation (origin of transfer), starting sites for DNA duplication (origin of replication) and regions which are eliminated through any of kind of recombination.  Also nucleosome exclusion regions, i.e. specific patterns or regions which exclude nucleosomes (the basic structural units of eukaryotic chromatin which play a significant role in regulating gene expression).
children.label: DNA binding sites

children.hasDefinition: The biology, archival, detection, prediction and analysis of positional features such as functional and other key sites, in nucleic acid sequences and the conserved patterns (motifs, profiles etc.) that may be used to describe them.
children.comment: Sequence tagged sites are short DNA sequences that are unique within a genome and serve as a mapping landmark, detectable by PCR they allow a genome to be mapped via an ordering of STSs.
children.label: Nucleic acid sites, features and motifs

children.hasDefinition: The processing and analysis of nucleic acid sequence, structural and other data.
children.label: Nucleic acids

children.hasDefinition: The study of how proteins are transported within and without the cell, including signal peptides, protein subcellular localisation and export.
children.label: Protein targeting and localisation

children.hasDefinition: Protein chemical modifications, e.g. post-translational modifications.
children.comment: EDAM does not describe all possible protein modifications. For fine-grained annotation of protein modification use the Gene Ontology (children of concept GO:0006464) and/or the Protein Modifications ontology (children of concept MOD:00000)
children.label: Protein modifications

children.hasDefinition: Protein sequence variants produced e.g. from alternative splicing, alternative promoter usage, alternative initiation and ribosomal frameshifting.
children.label: Protein variants

children.hasDefinition: The translation of mRNA into protein and subsequent protein processing in the cell.
children.label: Protein expression

children.hasDefinition: The study of the physical and biochemical properties of peptides and proteins, for example the hydrophobic, hydrophilic and charge properties of a protein.
children.label: Protein properties

children.hasDefinition: Protein-protein, protein-DNA/RNA and protein-ligand interactions, including analysis of known interactions and prediction of putative interactions.
children.comment: This includes experimental (e.g. yeast two-hybrid) and computational analysis techniques.
children.label: Protein interactions

children.hasDefinition: Protein stability, folding (in 3D space) and protein sequence-structure-function relationships.  This includes for example study of inter-atomic or inter-residue interactions in protein (3D) structures, the effect of mutation, and the design of proteins with specific properties, typically by designing changes (via site-directed mutagenesis) to an existing protein.
children.label: Protein folding, stability and design

children.hasDefinition: Structural features or common 3D motifs within protein structures, including the surface of a protein structure, such as biological interfaces with other molecules.
children.comment: This includes conformation of conserved substructures, conserved geometry (spatial arrangement) of secondary structure or protein backbone, solvent-exposed surfaces, internal cavities, the analysis of shape, hydropathy, electrostatic patches, role and functions etc.
children.label: Protein structural motifs and surfaces

children.hasDefinition: Protein tertiary structural domains and folds in a protein or polypeptide chain.
comment: This includes topological domains such as cytoplasmic regions in a protein.

This includes trans- or intra-membrane regions of a protein, typically describing physicochemical properties of the secondary structure elements.  For example, the location and size of the membrane spanning segments and intervening loop regions, transmembrane region IN/OUT orientation relative to the membrane, plus the following data for each amino acid: A Z-coordinate (the distance to the membrane center), the free energy of membrane insertion (calculated in a sliding window over the sequence) and a reliability score. The z-coordinate implies information about re-entrant helices, interfacial helices, the tilt of a transmembrane helix and loop lengths.
children.label: Protein folds and structural domains

children.hasDefinition: Disordered structure in a protein.
children.label: Protein disordered structure

children.hasDefinition: Secondary structure (predicted or real) of a protein, including super-secondary structure.
comment: Super-secondary structures include leucine zippers, coiled coils, Helix-Turn-Helix etc.

The location and size of the secondary structure elements and intervening loop regions is typically given.  The report can include disulphide bonds and post-translationally formed peptide bonds (crosslinks).
children.label: Protein secondary structure

children.hasDefinition: Protein secondary or tertiary structural data and/or associated annotation.
children.label: Protein structure analysis

children.hasDefinition: Immunity-related proteins and their ligands.
children.comment: This includes T cell receptors (TR), major histocompatibility complex (MHC), immunoglobulin superfamily (IgSF) / antibodies, major histocompatibility complex superfamily (MhcSF), etc."
children.label: Immunoproteins and antigens

children.hasDefinition: Particular gene(s), gene family or other gene group or system and their encoded proteins.Primarily the classification of proteins (from sequence or structural data) into clusters, groups, families etc., curation of a particular protein or protein family, or any other proteins that have been classified as members of a common group.
children.comment: A protein families database might include the classifier (e.g. a sequence profile) used to build the classification.
children.label: Gene and protein families

children.hasDefinition: Proteins that bind to DNA and control transcription of DNA to mRNA (transcription factors) and also transcriptional regulatory sites, elements and regions (such as promoters, enhancers, silencers and boundary elements / insulators) in nucleotide sequences.
comment: This includes CpG rich regions (isochores) in a nucleotide sequence.

This includes promoters, CAAT signals, TATA signals, -35 signals, -10 signals, GC signals, primer binding sites for initiation of transcription or reverse transcription, enhancer, attenuator, terminators and ribosome binding sites.

Transcription factor proteins either promote (as an activator) or block (as a repressor) the binding to DNA of RNA polymerase.  Regulatory sites including transcription factor binding site as well as promoters, enhancers, silencers and boundary elements / insulators.
children.label: Transcription factors and regulatory sites

children.hasDefinition: Lipoproteins (protein-lipid assemblies), and proteins or region of a protein that spans or are associated with a membrane.
children.label: Membrane and lipoproteins

children.hasDefinition: Proteins that catalyze chemical reaction, the kinetics of enzyme-catalysed reactions, enzyme nomenclature etc.
children.label: Enzymes

children.hasDefinition: Binding sites in proteins, including cleavage sites (for a proteolytic enzyme or agent), key residues involved in protein folding, catalytic residues (active site) of an enzyme, ligand-binding (non-catalytic) residues of a protein, such as sites that bind metal, prosthetic groups or lipids, RNA and DNA-binding proteins and binding sites etc.
children.label: Protein binding sites

children.hasDefinition: The biology, archival, detection, prediction and analysis of positional features such as functional and other key sites, in protein sequences and the conserved patterns (motifs, profiles etc.) that may be used to describe them.
children.comment: A signal peptide coding sequence encodes an N-terminal domain of a secreted protein, which is involved in attaching the polypeptide to a membrane leader sequence. A transit peptide coding sequence encodes an N-terminal domain of a nuclear-encoded organellar protein; which is involved in import of the protein into the organelle.
children.label: Protein sites, features and motifs

children.hasDefinition: Archival, processing and analysis of protein data, typically molecular sequence and structural data.
children.label: Proteins

children.hasDefinition: The mapping of complete (typically nucleotide) sequences. Mapping (in the sense of short read alignment, or more generally, just alignment) has application in RNA-Seq analysis (mapping of transcriptomics reads), variant discovery (e.g. mapping of exome capture), and re-sequencing (mapping of WGS reads).
children.comment: This includes resources that aim to identify, map or analyse genetic markers in DNA sequences, for example to produce a genetic (linkage) map of a chromosome or genome or to analyse genetic linkage and synteny. It also includes resources for physical (sequence) maps of a DNA sequence showing the physical distance (base pairs) between features or landmarks such as restriction sites, cloned DNA fragments, genes and other genetic markers.  It also covers for example the alignment of sequences of (typically millions) of short reads to a reference genome.
children.label: Mapping

children.hasDefinition: The archival, processing and analysis of the basic character composition of molecular sequences, for example character or word frequency, ambiguity, complexity, particularly regions of low complexity, and repeats or the repetitive nature of molecular sequences.
comment: This includes repetitive elements within a nucleic acid sequence, e.g. long terminal repeats (LTRs); sequences (typically retroviral) directly repeated at  both ends of a sequence and other types of repeating unit.
This includes short repetitive subsequences (repeat sequences) in a protein sequence.
children.label: Sequence composition, complexity and repeats

children.hasDefinition: The integrated study of evolutionary relationships and whole genome data, for example, in the analysis of species trees, horizontal gene transfer and evolutionary reconstruction.
children.label: Phylogenomics

children.hasDefinition: The assembly of fragments of a DNA sequence to reconstruct the original sequence.
children.comment: Assembly has two broad types, de-novo and re-sequencing. Re-sequencing is a specialised case of assembly, where an assembled (typically de-novo assembled) reference genome is available and is about 95% identical to the re-sequenced genome. All other cases of assembly are 'de-novo'.
children.label: Sequence assembly

children.hasDefinition: Molecular probes (e.g. a peptide probe or DNA microarray probe) or PCR primers and hybridisation oligos in a nucleic acid sequence.
children.comment: This includes the design of primers for PCR and DNA amplification or the design of molecular probes.
children.label: Probes and primers

children.hasDefinition: The study of evolutionary relationships amongst organisms from analysis of genetic information (typically gene or protein sequences).
children.label: Phylogenetics

children.hasDefinition: The biological classification of organisms by categorizing them in groups ("clades") based on their most recent common ancestor.
children.label: Cladistics

children.hasDefinition: The archival, processing and analysis of molecular sequences (monomer composition of polymers) including molecular sequence data resources, sequence sites, alignments, motifs and profiles.
children.label: Sequence analysis

children.hasDefinition: The study and simulation of molecular (typically protein) conformation using a computational model of physical forces and computer simulation.
children.comment: This includes methods such as Molecular Dynamics, Coarse-grained dynamics, metadynamics, Quantum Mechanics, QM/MM, Markov State Models, etc. This includes resources concerning flexibility and motion in protein and other molecular structures.
children.label: Molecular dynamics

children.hasDefinition: The construction, analysis, evaluation, refinement etc. of models of a molecules properties or behaviour, including the modelling the structure of proteins in complex with small molecules or other macromolecules (docking).
children.label: Molecular modelling

children.hasDefinition: The prediction of molecular structure, including the prediction, modelling, recognition or design of protein secondary or tertiary structure or other structural features, and the folding of nucleic acid molecules and the prediction or design of nucleic acid (typically RNA) sequences with specific conformations.
children.comment: This includes the recognition (prediction and assignment) of known protein structural domains or folds in protein sequence(s), for example by threading, or the alignment of molecular sequences to structures, structural (3D) profiles or templates (representing a structure or structure alignment).
children.label: Structure prediction

children.hasDefinition: The archival, curation, processing and analysis of nucleic acid structural information, such as whole structures, structural features and alignments, and associated annotation.
children.comment: Includes secondary and tertiary nucleic acid structural data, nucleic acid thermodynamic, thermal and conformational properties including DNA or DNA/RNA denaturation (melting) etc.
children.label: Nucleic acid structure analysis

children.hasDefinition: Protein stability, folding (in 3D space) and protein sequence-structure-function relationships.  This includes for example study of inter-atomic or inter-residue interactions in protein (3D) structures, the effect of mutation, and the design of proteins with specific properties, typically by designing changes (via site-directed mutagenesis) to an existing protein.
children.label: Protein folding, stability and design

children.hasDefinition: Structural features or common 3D motifs within protein structures, including the surface of a protein structure, such as biological interfaces with other molecules.
children.comment: This includes conformation of conserved substructures, conserved geometry (spatial arrangement) of secondary structure or protein backbone, solvent-exposed surfaces, internal cavities, the analysis of shape, hydropathy, electrostatic patches, role and functions etc.
children.label: Protein structural motifs and surfaces

children.hasDefinition: Protein tertiary structural domains and folds in a protein or polypeptide chain.
comment: This includes topological domains such as cytoplasmic regions in a protein.

This includes trans- or intra-membrane regions of a protein, typically describing physicochemical properties of the secondary structure elements.  For example, the location and size of the membrane spanning segments and intervening loop regions, transmembrane region IN/OUT orientation relative to the membrane, plus the following data for each amino acid: A Z-coordinate (the distance to the membrane center), the free energy of membrane insertion (calculated in a sliding window over the sequence) and a reliability score. The z-coordinate implies information about re-entrant helices, interfacial helices, the tilt of a transmembrane helix and loop lengths.
children.label: Protein folds and structural domains

children.hasDefinition: Disordered structure in a protein.
children.label: Protein disordered structure

children.hasDefinition: Secondary structure (predicted or real) of a protein, including super-secondary structure.
comment: Super-secondary structures include leucine zippers, coiled coils, Helix-Turn-Helix etc.

The location and size of the secondary structure elements and intervening loop regions is typically given.  The report can include disulphide bonds and post-translationally formed peptide bonds (crosslinks).
children.label: Protein secondary structure

children.hasDefinition: Protein secondary or tertiary structural data and/or associated annotation.
children.label: Protein structure analysis

children.hasDefinition: Carbohydrates, typically including structural information.
children.label: Carbohydrates

children.hasDefinition: Lipids and their structures.
children.label: Lipids

children.hasDefinition: Small molecules of biological significance, typically archival, curation, processing and analysis of structural information.
comment: Small molecules include organic molecules, metal-organic compounds, small polypeptides, small polysaccharides and oligonucleotides.  Structural data is usually included.
This concept excludes macromolecules such as proteins and nucleic acids.

This includes the structures of drugs, drug target, their interactions and binding affinities.  Also the structures of reactants or products of metabolism, for example small molecules such as including vitamins, polyols, nucleotides and amino acids.  Also the physicochemical, biochemical or structural properties of amino acids or peptides.  Also structural and associated data for toxic chemical substances.
children.label: Small molecules

children.hasDefinition: The curation, processing, analysis and prediction of data about the structure of biological molecules, typically proteins and nucleic acids and other macromolecules.
children.comment: This includes related concepts such as structural properties, alignments and structural motifs.
children.label: Structure analysis

children.hasDefinition: The study of evolutionary relationships amongst organisms from analysis of genetic information (typically gene or protein sequences).
children.label: Phylogenetics

children.hasDefinition: The biological classification of organisms by categorizing them in groups ("clades") based on their most recent common ancestor.
children.label: Cladistics

children.hasDefinition: The study of evolutionary relationships amongst organisms.
children.comment: This includes diverse phylogenetic methods, including phylogenetic tree construction, typically from molecular sequence or morphological data, methods that simulate DNA sequence evolution, a phylogenetic tree or the underlying data, or which estimate or use molecular clock and stratigraphic (age) data, methods for studying gene evolution etc.
children.label: Phylogeny

children.hasDefinition: The study of gene or protein functions and their interactions in totality in a given organism, tissue, cell etc.
children.label: Functional genomics

children.hasDefinition: The study of gene and protein function including the prediction of functional properties of a protein.
children.label: Function analysis

children.hasDefinition: Non-coding or functional RNA sequences, including regulatory RNA sequences, ribosomal RNA (rRNA) and transfer RNA (tRNA).
children.comment: Non-coding RNA includes  piwi-interacting RNA (piRNA), small nuclear RNA (snRNA) and small nucleolar RNA (snoRNA).  Regulatory RNA includes microRNA (miRNA) - short single stranded RNA molecules that regulate gene expression, and small interfering RNA (siRNA).
children.label: Functional, regulatory and non-coding RNA

children.hasDefinition: Mobile genetic elements, such as transposons, Plasmids, Bacteriophage elements and Group II introns.
children.label: Mobile genetic elements

children.hasDefinition: Transcription of DNA into RNA and features of a messenger RNA (mRNA) molecules including precursor RNA, primary (unprocessed) transcript and fully processed molecules.
comment: This includes 5'untranslated region (5'UTR), coding sequences (CDS), exons, intervening sequences (intron) and 3'untranslated regions (3'UTR).

This includes Introns, and protein-coding regions including coding sequences (CDS), exons, translation initiation sites and open reading frames.  Also expressed sequence tag (EST) or complementary DNA (cDNA) sequences.

This includes coding sequences for a signal or transit peptide.  A signal peptide coding sequence encodes an N-terminal domain of a secreted protein, which is involved in attaching the polypeptide to a membrane leader sequence. A transit peptide coding sequence encodes an N-terminal domain of a nuclear-encoded organellar protein; which is involved in import of the protein into the organelle.

This includes regions or sites in a eukaryotic and eukaryotic viral RNA sequence which directs endonuclease cleavage or polyadenylation of an RNA transcript.  A polyA signal is required for endonuclease cleavage of an RNA transcript that is followed by polyadenylation. A polyA site is a site on an RNA transcript to which adenine residues will be added during post-transcriptional polyadenylation.
children.label: Gene transcripts

children.hasDefinition: Gene structure, regions which make an RNA product and features such as promoters, coding regions, gene fusion, splice sites etc.
comment: This includes the study of promoters, coding regions etc.
This incudes operons (operators, promoters and genes) from a bacterial genome.  For example the operon leader and trailer gene, gene composition of the operon and associated information.
children.label: Gene structure

children.hasDefinition: DNA mutation.
children.label: DNA mutation

children.hasDefinition: DNA polymorphism.
hasNarrowSynonym: Variable number of tandem repeat polymorphism
comment: Includes microsatellite polymorphism in a DNA sequence.  A microsatellite polymorphism is a very short subsequence that is repeated a variable number of times between individuals. These repeats consist of the nucleotides cytosine and adenosine.
Includes restriction fragment length polymorphisms (RFLP) in a DNA sequence.  An RFLP is defined by the presence or absence of a specific restriction site of a bacterial restriction enzyme.

Includes single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNP) and associated data, for example, the discovery and annotation of SNPs.  A SNP is a DNA sequence variation where a single nucleotide differs between members of a species or paired chromosomes in an individual.

Includes variable number of tandem repeat (VNTR) polymorphism in a DNA sequence.  VNTRs occur in non-coding regions of DNA and consists sub-sequence that is repeated a multiple (and varied) number of times.
children.label: DNA polymorphism

children.hasDefinition: A DNA structural variation, specifically a duplication or deletion event, resulting in sections of the genome to be repeated, or the number of repeats in the genome to vary between individuals.
children.label: Copy number variation

children.hasDefinition: Variation in chromosome structure including microscopic and submicroscopic types of variation such as deletions, duplications, copy-number variants, insertions, inversions and translocations.
children.label: Structural variation

children.hasDefinition: Stable, naturally occuring mutations in a nucleotide sequence including alleles, naturally occurring mutations such as single base nucleotide substitutions, deletions and insertions, RFLPs and other polymorphisms.
children.label: Genetic variation

children.hasDefinition: The regulation of gene expression.
