children.label: Gene regulation

children.hasDefinition: Proteins that bind to DNA and control transcription of DNA to mRNA (transcription factors) and also transcriptional regulatory sites, elements and regions (such as promoters, enhancers, silencers and boundary elements / insulators) in nucleotide sequences.
comment: This includes CpG rich regions (isochores) in a nucleotide sequence.

This includes promoters, CAAT signals, TATA signals, -35 signals, -10 signals, GC signals, primer binding sites for initiation of transcription or reverse transcription, enhancer, attenuator, terminators and ribosome binding sites.

Transcription factor proteins either promote (as an activator) or block (as a repressor) the binding to DNA of RNA polymerase.  Regulatory sites including transcription factor binding site as well as promoters, enhancers, silencers and boundary elements / insulators.
children.label: Transcription factors and regulatory sites

children.hasDefinition: The study of microbe gene expression within natural environments (i.e. the metatranscriptome).
children.comment: Metatranscriptomics methods can be used for whole gene expression profiling of complex microbial communities.
children.label: Metatranscriptomics

children.hasDefinition: The analysis of transcriptomes, or a set of all the RNA molecules in a specific cell, tissue etc.
children.label: Transcriptomics

children.hasDefinition: RNA splicing; post-transcription RNA modification involving the removal of introns and joining of exons.
children.comment: This includes the study of splice sites, splicing patterns, alternative splicing events and variants, isoforms, etc..
children.label: RNA splicing

children.hasDefinition: The study of microbe gene expression within natural environments (i.e. the metatranscriptome).
children.comment: Metatranscriptomics methods can be used for whole gene expression profiling of complex microbial communities.
children.label: Metatranscriptomics

children.hasDefinition: The analysis of levels and patterns of synthesis of gene products (proteins and functional RNA) including interpretation in functional terms of gene expression data.
comment: Gene expression levels are analysed by identifying, quantifying or comparing mRNA transcripts, for example using microarrays, RNA-seq, northern blots, gene-indexed expression profiles etc.
This includes the study of codon usage in nucleotide sequence(s), genetic codes and so on.
children.label: Gene expression

children.hasDefinition: Immunity-related proteins and their ligands.
children.comment: This includes T cell receptors (TR), major histocompatibility complex (MHC), immunoglobulin superfamily (IgSF) / antibodies, major histocompatibility complex superfamily (MhcSF), etc."
children.label: Immunoproteins and antigens

children.hasDefinition: Particular gene(s), gene family or other gene group or system and their encoded proteins.Primarily the classification of proteins (from sequence or structural data) into clusters, groups, families etc., curation of a particular protein or protein family, or any other proteins that have been classified as members of a common group.
children.comment: A protein families database might include the classifier (e.g. a sequence profile) used to build the classification.
children.label: Gene and protein families

children.hasDefinition: The branch of genetics concerned with the relationships between chromosomes and cellular behaviour, especially during mitosis and meiosis.
children.label: Cytogenetics

children.hasDefinition: The structure and function of genes at a molecular level.
children.label: Molecular genetics

children.hasDefinition: Protein-protein, protein-DNA/RNA and protein-ligand interactions, including analysis of known interactions and prediction of putative interactions.
children.comment: This includes experimental (e.g. yeast two-hybrid) and computational analysis techniques.
children.label: Protein interactions

children.hasDefinition: Molecular interactions, biological pathways, networks and other models.
children.label: Molecular interactions, pathways and networks

children.hasDefinition: Proteins that bind to DNA and control transcription of DNA to mRNA (transcription factors) and also transcriptional regulatory sites, elements and regions (such as promoters, enhancers, silencers and boundary elements / insulators) in nucleotide sequences.
comment: This includes CpG rich regions (isochores) in a nucleotide sequence.

This includes promoters, CAAT signals, TATA signals, -35 signals, -10 signals, GC signals, primer binding sites for initiation of transcription or reverse transcription, enhancer, attenuator, terminators and ribosome binding sites.

Transcription factor proteins either promote (as an activator) or block (as a repressor) the binding to DNA of RNA polymerase.  Regulatory sites including transcription factor binding site as well as promoters, enhancers, silencers and boundary elements / insulators.
children.label: Transcription factors and regulatory sites

children.hasDefinition: Nucleic acids binding to some other molecule.
comment: This includes ribosome binding sites (Shine-Dalgarno sequence in prokaryotes), restriction enzyme recognition sites (restriction sites) etc.

This includes sites involved with DNA replication and recombination.  This includes binding sites for initiation of replication (origin of replication), regions where transfer is initiated during the conjugation or mobilisation (origin of transfer), starting sites for DNA duplication (origin of replication) and regions which are eliminated through any of kind of recombination.  Also nucleosome exclusion regions, i.e. specific patterns or regions which exclude nucleosomes (the basic structural units of eukaryotic chromatin which play a significant role in regulating gene expression).
children.label: DNA binding sites

children.hasDefinition: The biology, archival, detection, prediction and analysis of positional features such as functional and other key sites, in nucleic acid sequences and the conserved patterns (motifs, profiles etc.) that may be used to describe them.
children.comment: Sequence tagged sites are short DNA sequences that are unique within a genome and serve as a mapping landmark, detectable by PCR they allow a genome to be mapped via an ordering of STSs.
children.label: Nucleic acid sites, features and motifs

children.hasDefinition: Binding sites in proteins, including cleavage sites (for a proteolytic enzyme or agent), key residues involved in protein folding, catalytic residues (active site) of an enzyme, ligand-binding (non-catalytic) residues of a protein, such as sites that bind metal, prosthetic groups or lipids, RNA and DNA-binding proteins and binding sites etc.
children.label: Protein binding sites

children.hasDefinition: The biology, archival, detection, prediction and analysis of positional features such as functional and other key sites, in protein sequences and the conserved patterns (motifs, profiles etc.) that may be used to describe them.
children.comment: A signal peptide coding sequence encodes an N-terminal domain of a secreted protein, which is involved in attaching the polypeptide to a membrane leader sequence. A transit peptide coding sequence encodes an N-terminal domain of a nuclear-encoded organellar protein; which is involved in import of the protein into the organelle.
children.label: Protein sites, features and motifs

children.hasDefinition: The archival, detection, prediction and analysis of positional features such as functional and other key sites, in molecular sequences and the conserved patterns (motifs, profiles etc.) that may be used to describe them.
children.label: Sequence sites, features and motifs

children.hasDefinition: The study and simulation of molecular (typically protein) conformation using a computational model of physical forces and computer simulation.
children.comment: This includes methods such as Molecular Dynamics, Coarse-grained dynamics, metadynamics, Quantum Mechanics, QM/MM, Markov State Models, etc. This includes resources concerning flexibility and motion in protein and other molecular structures.
children.label: Molecular dynamics

children.hasDefinition: The study and simulation of molecular conformations using a computational model and computer simulations.
children.comment: This includes methods such as Molecular Dynamics, Coarse-grained dynamics, metadynamics, Quantum Mechanics, QM/MM, Markov State Models, etc.
children.label: Biomolecular simulation

children.hasDefinition: The development and application of theory, analytical methods, mathematical models and computational simulation of biological systems.
children.comment: This includes the modeling and treatment of biological processes and systems in mathematical terms (theoretical biology).
children.label: Computational biology

children.hasDefinition: Interdisciplinary science focused on extracting information from chemical systems by data analytical approaches, for example multivariate statistics, applied mathematics, and computer science.
children.label: Chemometrics

children.hasDefinition: The application of information technology to chemistry in biological research environment.
children.label: Cheminformatics

children.hasDefinition: The conceptualisation, categorisation and nomenclature (naming) of entities or phenomena within biology or bioinformatics. This includes formal ontologies, controlled vocabularies, structured glossary, symbols and terminology or other related resource.
children.label: Ontology and terminology

children.hasDefinition: The archival, curation, processing and analysis of complex biological data.
children.comment: This includes data  processing in general, including basic handling of files and databases, datatypes, workflows and annotation.
children.label: Bioinformatics

children.hasDefinition: Deposition and curation of database accessions, including annotation, typically with terms from a controlled vocabulary.
children.label: Data submission, annotation and curation

children.hasDefinition: Biological or biomedical analytical workflows or pipelines.
children.label: Workflows

children.hasDefinition: The acquisition of data, typically measurements of physical systems using any type of sampling system, or by another other means.
children.label: Data acquisition

children.hasDefinition: The protection of data, such as patient health data, from damage or unwanted access from unauthorised users.
children.label: Data security

children.hasDefinition: Topic concerning the identity of biological entities, or reports on such entities, and the mapping of entities and records in different databases.
children.label: Data identity and mapping

children.hasDefinition: The development of policies, models and standards that cover data acquisition, storage and integration, such that it can be put to use, typically through a process of systematically applying statistical and / or logical techniques to describe, illustrate, summarise or evaluate data.
children.label: Data architecture, analysis and design

children.hasDefinition: The combination and integration of data from different sources, for example into a central repository or warehouse, to provide users with a unified view of these data.
children.label: Data integration and warehousing

children.hasDefinition: The general handling of data stored in digital archives such as databanks, databases proper, web portals and other data resources.
children.comment: This includes databases for the results of scientific experiments, the application of high-throughput technology, computational analysis and the scientific literature.  It covers the management and manipulation of digital documents, including database records, files and reports.
children.label: Database management

children.hasDefinition: The control of data entry and maintenance to ensure the data meets defined standards, qualities or constraints.
children.label: Data governance

children.hasDefinition: The quality, integrity, and cleaning up of data.
children.label: Data quality management

children.hasDefinition: The development and use of architectures, policies, practices and procedures for management of data.
children.label: Biological databases

children.hasDefinition: Laboratory management and resources, for example, catalogues of biological resources for use in the lab including cell lines, viruses, plasmids, phages, DNA probes and primers and so on.
children.label: Laboratory information management

children.hasDefinition: The application of information technology to health, disease and biomedicine.
children.label: Medical informatics

children.hasDefinition: Immunoinformatics is the field of computational biology that deals with the study of immunoloogical questions. Immunoinformatics is at the interface between immunology and computer science. It takes advantage of computational, statistical, mathematical approaches and enhances the understanding of immunological knowledge.
children.comment: This involves the study of often complex genetic traits underlying diseases involving defects in the immune system. For example, identifying target genes for therapeutic approaches, or genetic variations involved in immunological pathology.
children.label: Immunoinformatics

children.hasDefinition: The study and practice of information processing and use of computer information systems.
children.label: Informatics

children.hasDefinition: Rendering (drawing on a computer screen) or visualisation of molecular sequences, structures or other biomolecular data.
children.label: Data visualisation

children.hasDefinition: The processing and analysis of natural language, such as scientific literature in English, in order to extract data and information, or to enable human-computer interaction.
children.label: Natural language processing

children.hasDefinition: Topic concerning the development and application of theory, analytical methods, mathematical models and computational simulation of chemical systems.
children.label: Computational chemistry

children.hasDefinition: The process that leads from an original formulation of a computing problem to executable programs.
children.label: Software engineering

children.hasDefinition: The discovery of patterns in large data sets and the extraction and trasnsformation of those patterns into a useful format.
children.label: Data mining

children.hasDbXref: VT 1.2.2 Artificial Intelligence (expert systems, machine learning, robotics)
children.hasDefinition: A topic concerning the application of artificial intelligence methods to algorithms, in order to create methods that can learn from data in order to generate an ouput, rather than relying on explicitly encoded information only.
children.label: Machine learning

children.hasDefinition: The theory and practical use of computer systems.
children.label: Computer science

children.hasDefinition: The study of gene or protein functions and their interactions in totality in a given organism, tissue, cell etc.
children.label: Functional genomics

children.hasDefinition: The elucidation of the three dimensional structure for all (available) proteins in a given organism.
children.label: Structural genomics

children.hasDefinition: The integrated study of evolutionary relationships and whole genome data, for example, in the analysis of species trees, horizontal gene transfer and evolutionary reconstruction.
children.label: Phylogenomics

children.hasDefinition: The influence of genotype on drug response, for example by correlating gene expression or single-nucleotide polymorphisms with drug efficacy or toxicity.
children.label: Pharmacogenomics

children.hasDefinition: The study (typically comparison) of the sequence, structure or function of multiple genomes.
children.label: Comparative genomics

children.hasDefinition: The study of the epigenetic modifications of a whole cell, tissue, organism etc.
children.comment: Epigenetics concerns the heritable changes in gene expression owing to mechanisms other than DNA sequence variation.
children.label: Epigenomics

children.hasDefinition: The study of genetic material recovered from environmental samples, and associated environmental data.
children.label: Metagenomics

children.hasDefinition: The study of microbe gene expression within natural environments (i.e. the metatranscriptome).
children.comment: Metatranscriptomics methods can be used for whole gene expression profiling of complex microbial communities.
children.label: Metatranscriptomics

children.hasDefinition: The analysis of transcriptomes, or a set of all the RNA molecules in a specific cell, tissue etc.
children.label: Transcriptomics

children.hasDefinition: Large-scale study (typically comparison) of DNA sequences of populations.
children.label: Population genomics

children.hasDefinition: A field of biological research focused on the discovery and identification of peptides, typically by comparing mass spectra against a protein database.
children.label: Proteogenomics

children.hasDefinition: The reconstruction and analysis of genomic information in extinct species.
children.label: Paleogenomics

children.hasDefinition: The study of the epigenetic modifications of a whole cell, tissue, organism etc.
children.comment: The study of the phenomena whereby the effects of one locus mask the allelic effects of another, such as how dominant alleles mask the effects of the recessive alleles at the same locus.
children.label: Epistasis

children.hasDefinition: Whole genomes of one or more organisms, or genomes in general, such as meta-information on genomes, genome projects, gene names etc.
children.label: Genomics

children.hasDefinition: Protein and peptide identification, especially in the study of whole proteomes of organisms.
comment: Includes metaproteomics: proteomics analysis of an environmental sample.

Proteomics includes any methods (especially high-throughput) that separate, characterize and identify expressed proteins such as mass spectrometry, two-dimensional gel electrophoresis and protein microarrays, as well as in-silico methods that perform proteolytic or mass calculations on a protein sequence and other analyses of protein production data, for example in different cells or tissues.
children.label: Proteomics

children.hasDefinition: The systematic study of metabolites, the chemical processes they are involved, and the chemical fingerprints of specific cellular processes in a whole cell, tissue, organ or organism.
children.label: Metabolomics

children.hasDefinition: Phenomes, or the study of the change in phenotype (the physical and biochemical traits of organisms) in response to genetic and environmental factors.
children.label: Phenomics

children.hasDefinition: The study of the process and mechanism of change of biomolecules such as DNA, RNA, and proteins across generations.
children.label: Molecular evolution

children.hasDefinition: Experimental approaches to determine the rates of metabolic reactions - the metabolic fluxes - within a biological entity.
children.comment: The "fluxome" is the complete set of metabolic fluxes in a cell, and is a dynamic aspect of phenotype.
children.label: Fluxomics

children.hasDefinition: The study of immune system as a whole, its regulation and response to pathogens using genome-wide approaches.
children.label: Immunomics

children.hasDefinition: The collective characterisation and quantification of pools of biological molecules that translate into the structure, function, and dynamics of an organism or organisms.
children.label: Omics

children.hasDefinition: The influence of genotype on drug response, for example by correlating gene expression or single-nucleotide polymorphisms with drug efficacy or toxicity.
children.label: Pharmacogenomics

children.hasDefinition: The study of drugs and their effects or responses in living systems.
children.label: Pharmacology

children.hasDefinition: Immunity-related proteins and their ligands.
children.comment: This includes T cell receptors (TR), major histocompatibility complex (MHC), immunoglobulin superfamily (IgSF) / antibodies, major histocompatibility complex superfamily (MhcSF), etc."
children.label: Immunoproteins and antigens

children.hasDefinition: A biomedical field that bridges immunology and genetics, to study the genetic basis of the immune system.
children.comment: This involves the study of often complex genetic traits underlying diseases involving defects in the immune system. For example, identifying target genes for therapeutic approaches, or genetic variations involved in immunological pathology.
children.label: Immunogenetics

children.hasDefinition: Immunoinformatics is the field of computational biology that deals with the study of immunoloogical questions. Immunoinformatics is at the interface between immunology and computer science. It takes advantage of computational, statistical, mathematical approaches and enhances the understanding of immunological knowledge.
children.comment: This involves the study of often complex genetic traits underlying diseases involving defects in the immune system. For example, identifying target genes for therapeutic approaches, or genetic variations involved in immunological pathology.
children.label: Immunoinformatics

children.hasDefinition: The application of information technology to immunology such as immunological processes, immunological genes, proteins and peptide ligands, antigens and so on.
children.label: Immunology

children.hasDefinition: The form and function of the structures of living organisms.
children.label: Anatomy

children.hasDefinition: Repositories of biological samples, typically human, for basic biological and clinical research.
children.label: Biobank

children.hasDefinition: Laboratory study of mice, for example, phenotyping, and mutagenesis of mouse cell lines.
children.label: Mouse clinic

children.hasDefinition: Collections of microbial cells including bacteria, yeasts and moulds.
children.label: Microbial collection

children.hasDefinition: Collections of cells grown under laboratory conditions, specifically, cells from multi-cellular eukaryotes and especially animal cells.
children.label: Cell culture collection

children.hasDefinition: Collections of DNA, including both collections of cloned molecules, and populations of micro-organisms that store and propagate cloned DNA.
children.label: Clone library

children.hasDefinition: Biological samples and specimens.
children.label: Sample collections

children.hasDefinition: The biology of parasites.
children.label: Parasitology

children.hasDefinition: The study of the nervous system and brain; its anatomy, physiology and function.
children.label: Neurobiology

children.hasDefinition: The design and chemical synthesis of bioactive molecules, for example drugs or potential drug compounds, for medicinal purposes.
children.comment: This includes methods that search compound collections, generate or analyse drug 3D conformations, identify drug targets with structural docking etc.
children.label: Medicinal chemistry

children.hasDefinition: Collections of chemicals, typically for use in high-throughput screening experiments.
children.label: Compound libraries and screening

children.hasDefinition: The discovery and design of drugs or potential drug compounds.
children.comment: This includes methods that search compound collections, generate or analyse drug 3D conformations, identify drug targets with structural docking etc.
children.label: Drug discovery

children.hasDefinition: Toxins and the adverse effects of these chemical substances on living organisms.
children.label: Toxicology

children.hasDefinition: The detection, assesment, understanding and prevention of adverse effects of medicines.
children.comment: Pharmacovigilence concerns safety once a drug has gone to market.
children.label: Pharmacovigilance

children.hasDefinition: The safety (or lack) of drugs and other medical interventions.
children.label: Safety sciences

children.hasDefinition: The process of bringing a new drug to market once a lead compounds has been identified through drug discovery.
children.label: Drug development

children.hasDefinition: The process of formulating and administering a pharmaceutical compound to achieve a therapeutic effect.
children.label: Biotherapeutics

children.hasDefinition: The study of how a drug interacts with the body.
children.label: Drug metabolism

children.hasDefinition: The testing of new medicines, vaccines or procedures on animals (preclinical) and humans (clinical) prior to their approval by regulatory authorities.
children.label: Preclinical and clinical studies

children.hasDefinition: The processes that need to be in place to ensure the quality of products for human or animal use.
children.label: Quality affairs

children.hasDefinition: The protection of public health by controlling the safety and efficacy of products in areas including pharmaceuticals, veterinary medicine, medical devices, pesticides, agrochemicals, cosmetics, and complementary medicines.
children.label: Regulatory affairs

children.hasDefinition: The design of vaccines to protect against a particular pathogen, including antigens, delivery systems, and adjuvants to elicit a predictable immune response against specific epitopes.
children.label: Vaccinology

children.hasDefinition: The discovery, development and approval of medicines.
children.label: Medicines research and development

children.hasDefinition: The design of an experiment involving non-human animals.
children.label: Animal study

children.hasDefinition: The use of animals and alternatives in experimental research.
children.label: Laboratory animal science

children.hasDefinition: The study of the effects of food components on the metabolism, health, performance and disease resistance of humans and animals.  It also includes the study of human behaviours related to food choices.
children.label: Nutritional science

children.hasDefinition: Biomedical approaches to clinical interventions that involve the use of stem cells.
children.label: Regenerative medicine

children.hasDefinition: Topic concerning biological science that is (typically) performed in the context of medicine.
children.label: Biomedical science

children.hasDefinition: The processing and analysis of natural language, such as scientific literature in English, in order to extract data and information, or to enable human-computer interaction.
children.label: Natural language processing

children.hasDefinition: The scientific literature, language processing, reference information, and documentation.
children.comment: This includes the documentation of resources such as tools, services and databases, user support, how to get help etc.
children.label: Literature and language

children.hasDefinition: Biotechnology approach that seeks to optimize cellular genetic and regulatory processes in order to increase the cells' production of a certain substance.
children.label: Metabolic engineering

children.hasDefinition: Any matter, surface or construct that interacts with a biological system.
children.label: Biomaterials

children.hasDefinition: The application of biological concepts and methods to the analytical and synthetic methodologies of engineering.
children.label: Bioengineering

children.hasDefinition: Biotechnology applied to the medical sciences and the development of medicines.
children.label: Medical biotechnology

children.hasDefinition: The application of multi-disciplinary science and technology for the construction of artificial biological systems for diverse applications.
children.label: Synthetic biology

children.hasDefinition: The application of biotechnology to directly manipulate an organism's genes.
children.label: Genetic engineering

children.hasDefinition: The exploitation of biological process, structure and function for industrial purposes, for example the genetic manipulation of microorganisms for the antibody production.
children.label: Biotechnology

children.hasDefinition: The study of evolutionary relationships amongst organisms from analysis of genetic information (typically gene or protein sequences).
children.label: Phylogenetics

children.hasDefinition: The biological classification of organisms by categorizing them in groups ("clades") based on their most recent common ancestor.
children.label: Cladistics

children.hasDefinition: The study of evolutionary relationships amongst organisms.
children.comment: This includes diverse phylogenetic methods, including phylogenetic tree construction, typically from molecular sequence or morphological data, methods that simulate DNA sequence evolution, a phylogenetic tree or the underlying data, or which estimate or use molecular clock and stratigraphic (age) data, methods for studying gene evolution etc.
children.label: Phylogeny

children.hasDefinition: Organism classification, identification and naming.
children.label: Taxonomy

children.hasDefinition: Phenomes, or the study of the change in phenotype (the physical and biochemical traits of organisms) in response to genetic and environmental factors.
children.label: Phenomics

children.hasDefinition: The study of the process and mechanism of change of biomolecules such as DNA, RNA, and proteins across generations.
children.label: Molecular evolution

children.hasDefinition: The evolutionary processes, from the genetic to environmental scale, that produced life in all its diversity.
children.label: Evolutionary biology

children.hasDefinition: The elucidation of the three dimensional structure for all (available) proteins in a given organism.
children.label: Structural genomics

children.hasDefinition: An analytical technique that exploits the magenetic properties of certain atomic nuclei to provide information on the structure, dynamics, reaction state and chemical environment of molecules.
hasNarrowSynonym: Rotational Frame Nuclear Overhauser Effect Spectroscopy
children.label: NMR

children.hasDefinition: The study of matter by studying the interference pattern from firing electrons at a sample, to analyse structures at resolutions higher than can be achieved using light.
children.label: Electron microscopy

children.hasDefinition: The study of matter and their structure by means of the diffraction of X-rays, typically the diffraction pattern caused by the regularly spaced atoms of a crystalline sample.
children.label: X-ray diffraction

children.hasDefinition: The study of matter by studying the diffraction pattern from firing neutrons at a sample, typically to determine atomic and/or magnetic structure.
children.label: Neutron diffraction

children.hasDefinition: The molecular structure of biological molecules, particularly macromolecules such as proteins and nucleic acids.
children.comment: This includes experimental methods for biomolecular structure determination, such as X-ray crystallography, nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR), circular dichroism (CD) spectroscopy, microscopy etc., including the assignment or modelling of molecular structure from such data.
children.label: Structural biology

children.hasDefinition: The degree of variation of life forms within a given ecosystem, biome or an entire planet.
children.label: Biodiversity

children.hasDefinition: The study of genetic material recovered from environmental samples, and associated environmental data.
children.label: Metagenomics

children.hasDefinition: The ecology of microorganisms including their relationship with one another and their environment.
children.label: Microbial ecology

children.hasDefinition: The ecological and environmental sciences and especially the application of information technology (ecoinformatics).
children.label: Ecology

children.hasDefinition: A specific organism, or group of organisms, used to study a particular aspect of biology.
children.comment: This may include information on the genome (including molecular sequences and map, genes and annotation), proteome, as well as more general information about an organism.
children.label: Model organisms

children.hasDefinition: Non-coding or functional RNA sequences, including regulatory RNA sequences, ribosomal RNA (rRNA) and transfer RNA (tRNA).
children.comment: Non-coding RNA includes  piwi-interacting RNA (piRNA), small nuclear RNA (snRNA) and small nucleolar RNA (snoRNA).  Regulatory RNA includes microRNA (miRNA) - short single stranded RNA molecules that regulate gene expression, and small interfering RNA (siRNA).
children.label: Functional, regulatory and non-coding RNA

children.hasDefinition: Mobile genetic elements, such as transposons, Plasmids, Bacteriophage elements and Group II introns.
children.label: Mobile genetic elements

children.hasDefinition: Transcription of DNA into RNA and features of a messenger RNA (mRNA) molecules including precursor RNA, primary (unprocessed) transcript and fully processed molecules.
comment: This includes 5'untranslated region (5'UTR), coding sequences (CDS), exons, intervening sequences (intron) and 3'untranslated regions (3'UTR).

This includes Introns, and protein-coding regions including coding sequences (CDS), exons, translation initiation sites and open reading frames.  Also expressed sequence tag (EST) or complementary DNA (cDNA) sequences.

This includes coding sequences for a signal or transit peptide.  A signal peptide coding sequence encodes an N-terminal domain of a secreted protein, which is involved in attaching the polypeptide to a membrane leader sequence. A transit peptide coding sequence encodes an N-terminal domain of a nuclear-encoded organellar protein; which is involved in import of the protein into the organelle.

This includes regions or sites in a eukaryotic and eukaryotic viral RNA sequence which directs endonuclease cleavage or polyadenylation of an RNA transcript.  A polyA signal is required for endonuclease cleavage of an RNA transcript that is followed by polyadenylation. A polyA site is a site on an RNA transcript to which adenine residues will be added during post-transcriptional polyadenylation.
children.label: Gene transcripts

children.hasDefinition: Gene structure, regions which make an RNA product and features such as promoters, coding regions, gene fusion, splice sites etc.
comment: This includes the study of promoters, coding regions etc.
This incudes operons (operators, promoters and genes) from a bacterial genome.  For example the operon leader and trailer gene, gene composition of the operon and associated information.
children.label: Gene structure

children.hasDefinition: DNA mutation.
children.label: DNA mutation

children.hasDefinition: DNA polymorphism.
hasNarrowSynonym: Variable number of tandem repeat polymorphism
comment: Includes microsatellite polymorphism in a DNA sequence.  A microsatellite polymorphism is a very short subsequence that is repeated a variable number of times between individuals. These repeats consist of the nucleotides cytosine and adenosine.
Includes restriction fragment length polymorphisms (RFLP) in a DNA sequence.  An RFLP is defined by the presence or absence of a specific restriction site of a bacterial restriction enzyme.

Includes single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNP) and associated data, for example, the discovery and annotation of SNPs.  A SNP is a DNA sequence variation where a single nucleotide differs between members of a species or paired chromosomes in an individual.

Includes variable number of tandem repeat (VNTR) polymorphism in a DNA sequence.  VNTRs occur in non-coding regions of DNA and consists sub-sequence that is repeated a multiple (and varied) number of times.
children.label: DNA polymorphism

children.hasDefinition: A DNA structural variation, specifically a duplication or deletion event, resulting in sections of the genome to be repeated, or the number of repeats in the genome to vary between individuals.
children.label: Copy number variation

children.hasDefinition: Variation in chromosome structure including microscopic and submicroscopic types of variation such as deletions, duplications, copy-number variants, insertions, inversions and translocations.
children.label: Structural variation

children.hasDefinition: Stable, naturally occuring mutations in a nucleotide sequence including alleles, naturally occurring mutations such as single base nucleotide substitutions, deletions and insertions, RFLPs and other polymorphisms.
children.label: Genetic variation

children.hasDefinition: The regulation of gene expression.
children.label: Gene regulation

children.hasDefinition: Proteins that bind to DNA and control transcription of DNA to mRNA (transcription factors) and also transcriptional regulatory sites, elements and regions (such as promoters, enhancers, silencers and boundary elements / insulators) in nucleotide sequences.
comment: This includes CpG rich regions (isochores) in a nucleotide sequence.

This includes promoters, CAAT signals, TATA signals, -35 signals, -10 signals, GC signals, primer binding sites for initiation of transcription or reverse transcription, enhancer, attenuator, terminators and ribosome binding sites.

Transcription factor proteins either promote (as an activator) or block (as a repressor) the binding to DNA of RNA polymerase.  Regulatory sites including transcription factor binding site as well as promoters, enhancers, silencers and boundary elements / insulators.
children.label: Transcription factors and regulatory sites

children.hasDefinition: The study of microbe gene expression within natural environments (i.e. the metatranscriptome).
children.comment: Metatranscriptomics methods can be used for whole gene expression profiling of complex microbial communities.
children.label: Metatranscriptomics

children.hasDefinition: The analysis of transcriptomes, or a set of all the RNA molecules in a specific cell, tissue etc.
children.label: Transcriptomics

children.hasDefinition: RNA splicing; post-transcription RNA modification involving the removal of introns and joining of exons.
children.comment: This includes the study of splice sites, splicing patterns, alternative splicing events and variants, isoforms, etc..
children.label: RNA splicing

children.hasDefinition: The study of microbe gene expression within natural environments (i.e. the metatranscriptome).
children.comment: Metatranscriptomics methods can be used for whole gene expression profiling of complex microbial communities.
children.label: Metatranscriptomics

children.hasDefinition: The analysis of levels and patterns of synthesis of gene products (proteins and functional RNA) including interpretation in functional terms of gene expression data.
comment: Gene expression levels are analysed by identifying, quantifying or comparing mRNA transcripts, for example using microarrays, RNA-seq, northern blots, gene-indexed expression profiles etc.
This includes the study of codon usage in nucleotide sequence(s), genetic codes and so on.
children.label: Gene expression

children.hasDefinition: Immunity-related proteins and their ligands.
children.comment: This includes T cell receptors (TR), major histocompatibility complex (MHC), immunoglobulin superfamily (IgSF) / antibodies, major histocompatibility complex superfamily (MhcSF), etc."
children.label: Immunoproteins and antigens

children.hasDefinition: Particular gene(s), gene family or other gene group or system and their encoded proteins.Primarily the classification of proteins (from sequence or structural data) into clusters, groups, families etc., curation of a particular protein or protein family, or any other proteins that have been classified as members of a common group.
children.comment: A protein families database might include the classifier (e.g. a sequence profile) used to build the classification.
children.label: Gene and protein families

children.hasDefinition: The branch of genetics concerned with the relationships between chromosomes and cellular behaviour, especially during mitosis and meiosis.
children.label: Cytogenetics

children.hasDefinition: The structure and function of genes at a molecular level.
children.label: Molecular genetics

children.hasDefinition: The genes and genetic mechanisms such as Mendelian inheritance that underly continuous phenotypic traits (such as height or weight).
children.label: Quantitative genetics

children.hasDefinition: Phenomes, or the study of the change in phenotype (the physical and biochemical traits of organisms) in response to genetic and environmental factors.
children.label: Phenomics

children.hasDefinition: The study of the process and mechanism of change of biomolecules such as DNA, RNA, and proteins across generations.
children.label: Molecular evolution

children.hasDefinition: The study of genetic constitution of a living entity, such as an individual, and organism, a cell and so on, typically with respect to a particular observable phenotypic traits, or resources concerning such traits, which might be an aspect of biochemistry, physiology, morphology, anatomy, development and so on.
children.label: Genotype and phenotype

children.hasDefinition: The distribution of allele frequencies in a population of organisms and its change subject to evolutionary processes including natural selection, genetic drift, mutation and gene flow.
children.label: Population genetics

children.hasDefinition: The study of the epigenetic modifications of a whole cell, tissue, organism etc.
children.comment: Epigenetics concerns the heritable changes in gene expression owing to mechanisms other than DNA sequence variation.
children.label: Epigenomics

children.hasDefinition: The study of the epigenetic modifications of a whole cell, tissue, organism etc.
children.comment: The study of the phenomena whereby the effects of one locus mask the allelic effects of another, such as how dominant alleles mask the effects of the recessive alleles at the same locus.
children.label: Epistasis

children.hasDefinition: Topic concerning the study of heritable changes, for example in gene expression or phenotype, caused by mechanisms other than changes in the DNA sequence.
children.comment: This includes sub-topics such as histone modification and DNA methylation (methylation sites and analysis, for example of patterns and profiles of DNA methylation in a population, tissue etc.)
children.label: Epigenetics

children.hasDefinition: The study of inheritance in human beings.
children.label: Human genetics

children.hasDefinition: The application of biotechnology to directly manipulate an organism's genes.
children.label: Genetic engineering

children.hasDefinition: A biomedical field that bridges immunology and genetics, to study the genetic basis of the immune system.
children.comment: This involves the study of often complex genetic traits underlying diseases involving defects in the immune system. For example, identifying target genes for therapeutic approaches, or genetic variations involved in immunological pathology.
children.label: Immunogenetics

children.hasDefinition: The study of genes, genetic variation and heredity in living organisms.
children.label: Genetics

children.hasDefinition: Plants, e.g. information on a specific plant genome including molecular sequences, genes and annotation.
children.comment: The resource may be specific to a plant, a group of plants or all plants.
children.label: Plant biology

children.hasDefinition: Study of viruses, e.g. sequence and structural data, interactions of viral proteins, or a viral genome including molecular sequences, genes and annotation.
children.label: Virology

children.hasDefinition: Cells, such as key genes and proteins involved in the cell cycle.
children.label: Cell biology

children.hasDefinition: The holistic modelling and analysis of complex biological systems and the interactions therein.
children.comment: This includes databases of models and methods to construct or analyse a model.
children.label: Systems biology

children.hasDefinition: The study of human beings in general, including the human genome and proteome.
children.label: Human biology

children.hasDefinition: The molecular basis of biological activity, particularly the macromolecules (e.g. proteins and nucleic acids) that are essential to life.
children.label: Molecular biology

children.hasDefinition: The development of organisms between the one-cell stage (typically the zygote) and the end of the embryonic stage.
children.label: Embryology

children.hasDefinition: How organisms grow and develop.
children.label: Developmental biology

children.hasDefinition: Chemical substances and physico-chemical processes and that occur within living organisms.
children.label: Biochemistry

children.hasDefinition: The ecology of microorganisms including their relationship with one another and their environment.
children.label: Microbial ecology

children.hasDefinition: The biology of microorganisms.
children.label: Microbiology

children.hasDefinition: The use of physics to study biological system.
children.label: Biophysics

children.hasDefinition: Objective indicators of biological state often used to assess health, and determinate treatment.
children.label: Biomarkers

children.hasDefinition: The use of synthetic chemistry to study and manipulate biological systems.
children.label: Chemical biology

children.hasDefinition: The study of organisms in the ocean or brackish waters.
children.label: Marine biology

children.hasDefinition: Animals, e.g. information on a specific animal genome including molecular sequences, genes and annotation.
children.comment: The study of the animal kingdom.
children.label: Zoology

children.hasDefinition: The study of organisms in freshwater ecosystems.
children.label: Freshwater biology

children.hasDefinition: Multidisciplinary study, research and development within the field of agriculture.
children.label: Agricultural science

children.hasDefinition: Study of the environment, the interactions between its physical, chemical, and biological components and it's effect on life.  Also how humans impact upon the environment, and how we can manage and utilise natural resources.
children.label: Environmental science

children.hasDefinition: The application of multi-disciplinary science and technology for the construction of artificial biological systems for diverse applications.
children.label: Synthetic biology

children.hasDefinition: The study of life and living organisms, including their morphology, biochemistry, physiology, development, evolution, and so on.
children.label: Biology

children.hasDefinition: The branch of medicine that deals with the prevention, diagnosis and management of transmissable disease with clinically evident illness resulting from infection with pathogenic biological agents (viruses, bacteria, fungi, protozoa, parasites and prions).
children.label: Infectious disease

children.hasDefinition: The study of rare diseases.
children.label: Rare diseases

children.hasDefinition: Diseases, including diseases in general and the genes, gene variations and proteins involved in one or more specific diseases.
children.label: Pathology

children.hasDefinition: The study of cancer, for example, genes and proteins implicated in cancer.
children.label: Oncology

children.hasDefinition: Toxins and the adverse effects of these chemical substances on living organisms.
children.label: Toxicology

children.hasDefinition: The functions of living organisms and their constituent parts.
children.label: Physiology

children.hasDefinition: Topic concerning the the patterns, cause, and effect of disease within populations.
children.label: Public health and epidemiology

children.hasDefinition: The study of respiratory system.
children.label: Respiratory medicine

children.hasDefinition: The branch of medicine that deals with the anatomy, functions and disorders of the nervous system.
children.label: Neurology

children.hasDefinition: The diseases and abnormalities of the heart and circulatory system.
children.label: Cardiology

children.hasDefinition: The identification of molecular and genetic causes of disease and the development of interventions to correct them.
children.label: Molecular medicine

children.hasDefinition: 'translating' the output of basic and biomedical research into better diagnostic tools, medicines, medical procedures, policies and advice.
children.label: Translational medicine

children.hasDefinition: An interdisciplinary field of study that looks at the dynamic systems of the human body as part of an integrted whole, incoporating biochemical, physiological, and environmental interactions that sustain life.
children.label: Systems medicine

children.hasDefinition: Topic concerning the branch of medicine that deals with the prevention, diagnosis, and treatment of disease, disorder and injury in animals.
children.label: Veterinary medicine

children.hasDefinition: The branch of medicine dealing with the diagnosis, treatment and prevention of disease in older people, and the problems specific to aging.
children.label: Geriatric medicine

children.hasDefinition: Health issues related to the immune system and their prevention, diagnosis and mangement.
children.label: Allergy, clinical immunology and immunotherapeutics

children.hasDefinition: The prevention of pain and the evaluation, treatment and rehabilitation of persons in pain.
children.label: Pain medicine

children.hasDefinition: Anaesthesia and anaesthetics.
children.label: Anaesthesiology

children.hasDefinition: The multidisciplinary that cares for patients with acute, life-threatening illness or injury.
children.label: Critical care medicine

children.hasDefinition: The branch of medicine that deals with prevention, diagnosis and treatment of disorders of the skin, scalp, hair and nails.
children.label: Dermatology

children.hasDefinition: The study, diagnosis, prevention and treatments of disorders of the oral cavity, maxillofacial area and adjacent structures.
children.label: Dentistry

children.hasDefinition: The branch of medicine that deals with the prevention, diagnosis, and treatment of disorders of the ear, nose and throat.
children.label: Ear, nose and throat medicine

children.hasDefinition: The branch of medicine dealing with diseases of endocrine organs, hormone systems, their target organs, and disorders of the pathways of glucose and lipid metabolism.
children.label: Endocrinology and metabolism

children.hasDefinition: The branch of medicine that deals with the blood, blood-forming organs and blood diseases.
children.label: Haematology

children.hasDefinition: The branch of medicine that deals with disorders of the oesophagus, stomach, duodenum, jejenum, ileum, large intestine, sigmoid colon and rectum.
children.label: Gastroenterology

children.hasDefinition: The study of the biological and physiological differences between males and females and how they effect differences in disease presentation and management.
children.label: Gender medicine

children.hasDefinition: The branch of medicine that deals with the health of the female reproductive system, pregnancy and birth.
children.label: Gynaecology and obstetrics

children.hasDefinition: The branch of medicine that deals with the liver, gallbladder, bile ducts and bile.
children.label: Hepatic and biliary medicine

children.hasDefinition: The branch of medicine that treats body wounds or shock produced by sudden physical injury, as from violence or accident.
children.label: Trauma medicine

children.hasDefinition: The branch of medicine that deals with the diagnosis, management and prevention of poisoning and other adverse health effects caused by medications, occupational and environmental toxins, and biological agents.
children.label: Medical toxicology

children.hasDefinition: The branch of medicine that deals with the prevention, diagnosis, and treatment of disorders of the muscle, bone and connective tissue.  It incorporates aspects of orthopaedics, rheumatology, rehabilitation medicine and pain medicine.
children.label: Musculoskeletal medicine

children.hasDefinition: The branch of medicine that deals with disorders of the eye, including eyelid, optic nerve/visual pathways and occular muscles.
children.label: Opthalmology

children.hasDefinition: The branch of medicine that deals with the medical care of infants, children and adolescents.
children.label: Paediatrics

children.hasDefinition: The branch of medicine that deals with the mangement of mental illness, emotional disturbance and abnormal behaviour.
children.label: Psychiatry

children.hasDefinition: The health of the reproductive processes, functions and systems at all stages of life.
children.label: Reproductive health

children.hasDefinition: The use of operative, manual and instrumental techniques on a patient to investigate and/or treat a pathological condition or help improve bodily function or appearance.
children.label: Surgery

children.hasDefinition: The branches of medicine and physiology focussing on the function and disorders of the urinary system in males and females, the reproductive system in males, and the kidney.
children.label: Urology and nephrology

children.hasDefinition: Medical therapies that fall beyond the scope of conventional medicine but may be used alongside it in the treatment of disease and ill health.
children.label: Complementary medicine

children.hasDefinition: Health problems that are prevalent in tropical and subtropical regions.
children.label: Tropical medicine

children.hasDefinition: An approach to medicine whereby decisions, practices and are tailored to the individual patient based on their predicted response or risk of disease.
children.label: Personalised medicine

children.hasDefinition: Research in support of healing by diagnosis, treatment, and prevention of disease.
children.label: Medicine

children.hasDefinition: The application of statistical methods to biological problems.
children.label: Statistics and probability

children.hasDefinition: The application of mathematics to specific problems in science, typically by the formulation and analysis of mathematical models.
children.label: Applied mathematics

children.hasDefinition: The study of abstract mathematical concepts.
children.label: Pure mathematics

children.hasDefinition: The study of numbers (quantity) and other topics including structure, space, and change.
children.label: Mathematics

children.hasDefinition: Laboratory experiment to identify the differences between a specific genome (of an individual) and a reference genome (developed typically from many thousands of individuals).WGS re-sequencing is used as golden standard to detect variations compared to a given reference genome, including small variants (SNP and InDels) as well as larger genome re-organisations (CNVs, translocations, etc.).ows re-sequencing of complete genomes of any given organism with high resolution and high accuracy.
comment: Amplicon sequencing is the ultra-deep sequencing of PCR products (amplicons), usually for the purpose of efficient genetic variant identification and characterisation in specific genomic regions.
Ultra-deep sequencing
children.label: Genome resequencing

children.hasDefinition: The analysis of protein-DNA interactions where chromatin immunoprecipitation (ChIP) is used in combination with massively parallel DNA sequencing to identify the binding sites of DNA-associated proteins.
children.label: ChIP-seq

children.hasDefinition: A topic concerning high-throughput sequencing of cDNA to measure the RNA content (transcriptome) of a sample, for example, to investigate how different alleles of a gene are expressed, detect post-transcriptional mutations or identify gene fusions.
children.comment: This includes small RNA profiling (small RNA-Seq), for example to find novel small RNAs, characterize mutations and analyze expression of small RNAs.
children.label: RNA-Seq

children.hasDefinition: Laboratory technique to sequence the complete DNA sequence of an organism's genome at a single time.
children.label: Whole genome sequencing

children.hasDefinition: Laboratory technique to sequence all the protein-coding regions in a genome, i.e., the exome.
children.comment: Exome sequencing is considered a cheap alternative to whole genome sequencing.
children.label: Exome sequencing

children.hasDefinition: Approach which samples, in parallel, all genes in all organisms present in a given sample, e.g. to provide insight into biodiversity and function.
children.label: Metagenomic sequencing

children.hasDefinition: The determination of complete (typically nucleotide) sequences, including those of genomes (full genome sequencing, de novo sequencing and resequencing), amplicons and transcriptomes.
children.label: Sequencing

children.hasDefinition: An analytical technique that exploits the magenetic properties of certain atomic nuclei to provide information on the structure, dynamics, reaction state and chemical environment of molecules.
hasNarrowSynonym: Rotational Frame Nuclear Overhauser Effect Spectroscopy
children.label: NMR

children.hasDefinition: The study of matter by studying the interference pattern from firing electrons at a sample, to analyse structures at resolutions higher than can be achieved using light.
children.label: Electron microscopy

children.hasDefinition: The study of matter and their structure by means of the diffraction of X-rays, typically the diffraction pattern caused by the regularly spaced atoms of a crystalline sample.
children.label: X-ray diffraction

children.hasDefinition: The use of imaging techniques to understand biology.
children.label: Bioimaging

children.hasDefinition: The use of imaging techniques for clinical purposes for medical research.
children.label: Medical imaging

children.hasDefinition: The use of optical instruments to magnify the image of an object.
children.label: Light microscopy

children.hasDefinition: Techniques that uses magnetic fields and radiowaves to form images, typically to investigate the anatomy and physiology of the human body.
children.label: MRI

children.hasDefinition: The study of matter by studying the diffraction pattern from firing neutrons at a sample, typically to determine atomic and/or magnetic structure.
children.label: Neutron diffraction

children.hasDefinition: Imaging in sections (sectioning), through the use of a wave-generating device (tomograph) that generates an image (a tomogram).
children.label: Tomography

children.hasDefinition: A diagnostic imaging technique based on the application of ultrasound.
children.label: Echography

children.hasDefinition: The visual representation of an object.
children.comment: This includes diffraction experiments that are based upon the interference of waves, typically electromagnetic waves such as  X-rays or visible light, by some object being studied, typical in order to produce an image of the object or determine its structure.
children.label: Imaging

children.hasDefinition: The analysis of protein-DNA interactions where chromatin immunoprecipitation (ChIP) is used in combination with massively parallel DNA sequencing to identify the binding sites of DNA-associated proteins.
children.label: ChIP-seq

children.hasDefinition: Experimental techniques that combine chromatin immunoprecipitation ('ChIP') with microarray ('chip'). ChIP-on-chip is used for high-throughput study protein-DNA interactions.
children.label: ChIP-on-chip

children.hasDefinition: Laboratory technique to sequence the methylated regions in DNA.
children.label: Methylated DNA immunoprecipitation

children.hasDefinition: An antibody-based technique used to map in vivo RNA-protein interactions.
children.label: RNA immunoprecipitation

children.hasDefinition: Experimental techniques to purify a protein-DNA crosslinked complex.  Usually sequencing follows e.g. in the techniques ChIP-chip, ChIP-seq and MeDIP-seq.
children.label: Immunoprecipitation experiment

children.hasDefinition: Genotype experiment including case control, population, and family studies. These might use array based methods and re-sequencing methods.
children.label: Genotyping experiment

children.hasDefinition: Microarray experiments including conditions, protocol, sample:data relationships etc.
children.comment: This might specify which raw data file relates to which sample and information on hybridisations, e.g. which are technical and which are biological replicates.
children.label: Microarray experiment

children.hasDefinition: PCR experiments, e.g. quantitative real-time PCR.
children.label: PCR experiment

children.hasDefinition: Proteomics experiments.
children.comment: This includes two-dimensional gel electrophoresis (2D PAGE) experiments, gels or spots in a gel.  Also mass spectrometry - an analytical chemistry technique that measures the mass-to-charge ratio and abundance of ions in the gas phase.  Also Northern blot experiments.
children.label: Proteomics experiment

children.hasDefinition: RNAi experiments.
children.label: RNAi experiment

children.hasDefinition: Biological computational model experiments (simulation), for example the minimum information required in order to permit its correct interpretation and reproduction.
children.label: Simulation experiment

children.hasDefinition: The procedures used to conduct an experiment.
children.label: Laboratory techniques

children.hasDefinition: The design and chemical synthesis of bioactive molecules, for example drugs or potential drug compounds, for medicinal purposes.
children.comment: This includes methods that search compound collections, generate or analyse drug 3D conformations, identify drug targets with structural docking etc.

children.hasDefinition: Collections of chemicals, typically for use in high-throughput screening experiments.
children.label: Compound libraries and screening

children.hasDefinition: The discovery and design of drugs or potential drug compounds.
children.comment: This includes methods that search compound collections, generate or analyse drug 3D conformations, identify drug targets with structural docking etc.
children.label: Drug discovery

children.hasDefinition: The design and chemical synthesis of bioactive molecules, for example drugs or potential drug compounds, for medicinal purposes.
children.comment: This includes methods that search compound collections, generate or analyse drug 3D conformations, identify drug targets with structural docking etc.
children.label: Medicinal chemistry

children.hasDefinition: The use of synthetic chemistry to study and manipulate biological systems.
children.label: Chemical biology

children.hasDefinition: The use of chemistry to create new compounds.
children.label: Synthetic chemistry

children.hasDefinition: Chemical substances and physico-chemical processes and that occur within living organisms.
children.label: Biochemistry

children.hasDefinition: Topic concerning the development and application of theory, analytical methods, mathematical models and computational simulation of chemical systems.
children.label: Computational chemistry

children.hasDefinition: The study of the separation, identification, and quantification of the chemical components of natural and artificial materials.
children.label: Analytical chemistry

children.hasDefinition: The composition and properties of matter, reactions, and the use of reactions to create new substances.

children.hasDefinition: The use of physics to study biological system.

children.hasDefinition: The study of matter, space and time, and related concepts such as energy and force.
children.label: Physics

children.hasDefinition: The testing of new medicines, vaccines or procedures on animals (preclinical) and humans (clinical) prior to their approval by regulatory authorities.
children.label: Preclinical and clinical studies

children.hasDefinition: Genome-wide association study experiments.

children.hasDefinition: The design of an experiment involving non-human animals.

children.hasDefinition: The design of an experiment intended to test a hypothesis, and describe or explain empirical data obtained under various experimental conditions.

children.hasDefinition: A category denoting a rather broad domain or field of interest, of study, application, work, data, or technology. Topics have no clearly defined borders between each other.
